Meaning 1: someone’s favorite person or thing.
Sentence 1: Tom is the apple of Mary’s eye. She thinks he’s great.
Sentence 2: Jean is the apple of her father’s eye.

Meaning 1: heavily armed with weapons.
Sentence 1: The bank robber was armed to the teeth when he was caught.
Sentence 2: There are too many guns around. The entire country is armed to the teeth.

Idioms: as a duck takes to water
Meaning 1: easily and naturally.
Sentence 1: She took to singing just as a duck takes to water.
Sentence 2: The baby adapted to the feeding-bottle as a duck takes to water.

Idioms: as black as one is painted
Meaning 1: as evil or unpleasant as one is thought to be. (Usually negative.)
Sentence 1: The landlord is not as black as he is painted. He seems quite generous.
Sentence 2: Young people are rarely as black as they are painted in the media.

Meaning 1: very black
Sentence 1: The night was as black as pitch.
Sentence 2: The rocks seemed black as pitch against the silver sand.

Meaning 1: brazen
Sentence 1: She went up to her lover’s wife, bold as brass.
Sentence 2: The girl arrives late every morning as bold as brass.

Meaning 1: very intelligent
Sentence 1: The little girl is as bright as a button.
Sentence 2: Her new dog is bright as a button.

Meaning 1: [for water to be] exceptionally calm. (Referring to the still water in a pond around a mill in contrast to the fast-flowing stream which supplies it.)
Sentence 1: The English Channel was calm as a millpond that day.
Sentence 2: Jane gets seasick even when the sea is calm as a millpond.

Meaning 1: very cold
Sentence 1: The room was as cold as charity.
Sentence 2: It was snowing, and the moors were cold as charity.
Sentence 3: Their mother keeps them clean and fed, but she is cold as charity.
Sentence 4: John’s sister is generous and welcoming, but John is as cold as charity.

Meaning 1: healthy and physically fit.
Sentence 1: In spite of her age, Mary is as fit as a fiddle.
Sentence 2: Tom used to be fit as a fiddle. Look at him now!

Meaning 1: visibly happy and cheerful.
Sentence 1: Sally walked along whistling, as happy as a lark.
Sentence 2: The children danced and sang, happy as larks.

Meaning 1: very happy
Sentence 1: Mary’s as happy as a sand boy now that she is at home all day with her children.

Idioms: (as) happy as the day is long
Meaning 1: very happy
Sentence 1: The old lady has many friends and is happy as the day is long.

Meaning 1: very hungry.
Sentence 1: I’m as hungry as a hunter. I could eat anything!
Sentence 2: Whenever I jog, I get hungry as a hunter.

Idioms: (as) large as life (and twice as ugly)
Meaning 1: an exaggerated way of saying that a person or a thing actually appeared in a particular place.
Sentence 1: The little child just stood there as large as life and laughed very hard.
Sentence 2: I opened the door, and there was Tom, large as life.
Sentence 3: I came home and found this cat in my chair, as large as life and twice as ugly.

Meaning 1: very happy or carefree.
Sentence 1: Peter earns very little money, but he is happy as Larry in his job.

Meaning 1: very nearly.
Sentence 1: He earns sixty thousand pounds a year as near as dammit.
Sentence 2: She was naked near as dammit.

Meaning 1: not attending to one’s assigned task
Meaning 2: failing to do one’s duty at the proper time.
Sentence 1: I should have spotted the error. I must have been asleep at the wheel.
Sentence 2: The management must have been asleep at the wheel to let the firm get into such a state.

Meaning 1: very obvious
Meaning 2: clearly visible. (Pikestaff was originally pack staff, a stick on which a peddler’s or traveler’s pack was supported. The original reference was to the smoothness of this staff, although the allusion is to another sense of plain: clear or obvious.)
Sentence 1: The ‘no parking’ sign was as plain as a pikestaff. How did he miss it?
Sentence 2: It’s plain as a pikestaff. The children are unhappy.

Meaning 1: very pleased or happy. (From the puppet show character, who is depicted as smiling gleefully.)
Sentence 1: The little girl was pleased as Punch with her new dress.
Sentence 2: Jack’s as pleased as Punch with his new car.

Meaning 1: very quiet
Sentence 1: The house is as quiet as the grave when the children are at school.
Sentence 2: This town is quiet as the grave now that the offices have closed.

Meaning 1: completely safe.
Sentence 1: The children will be as safe as houses on holiday with your parents.
Sentence 2: The dog will be safe as houses in the boarding kennels.

Meaning 1: in perfect condition or health
Sentence 1: The doctor says the old man’s heart is as sound as a bell.
Sentence 2: I thought the vase was broken when it fell, but it was sound as a bell.

Meaning 1: very close-knit
Sentence 1: Mary, Tom, and Sally are as thick as thieves. They go everywhere together.
Sentence 2: Those two families are thick as thieves.

Meaning 1: very stupid.
Sentence 1: Jim must be as thick as two short planks, not able to understand the plans.
Sentence 2: Some of the children are clever, but the rest are as thick as two short planks.

Meaning 1: very thin
Sentence 1: Mary’s thin as a rake since she’s been ill.
Sentence 2: Jean’s been on a diet and is now as thin as a rake.

Meaning 1: restless and unsettled
Sentence 1: Just before school starts, all the children are at a loose end.
Sentence 2: When Tom is home at the weekends, he’s always at a loose end.
Sentence 3: Jane has been at a loose end ever since she lost her job.

Meaning 1: if absolutely necessary.
Sentence 1: At a pinch, I could come tomorrow, but it’s not really convenient.
Sentence 2: He could commute to work from home at a pinch, but it is a long way.

Meaning 1: very fast.
Sentence 1: They’ll have to drive at a rate of knots to get there on time.
Sentence 2: They were travelling at a rate of knots when they passed us.

Meaning 1: near death. (Euphemistic.)
Sentence 1: I was so ill that I was at death’s door.
Sentence 2: The family dog was at death’s door for three days, and then it finally died.

Meaning 1: when first examined
Sentence 1: At first glance, the problem appeared quite simple. Later we learned just how complex it really was.
Sentence 2: He appeared quite healthy at first glance.

Meaning 1: with as much energy and strength as possible.
Sentence 1: The police are working at full stretch to find the murderer.
Sentence 2: We cannot accept any more work. We are already working at full stretch.

Meaning 1: half-way up or down. (Primarily referring to flags. Can be used for things other than flags as a joke.)
Sentence 1: The flag was flying at half-mast because the general had died.
Sentence 2: We fly flags at half- mast when someone important dies.
Sentence 3: The little boy ran out of the house with his trousers at half-mast.

Meaning 1: free
Meaning 2: uncaptured. (Usually said of criminals running loose.)
Sentence 1: At midday the day after the robbery, the thieves were still at large.
Sentence 2: There is a murderer at large in the city.

Meaning 1: free
Sentence 1: You’re at liberty to go anywhere you wish.
Sentence 2: I’m not at liberty to discuss the matter.

Meaning 1: in opposition
Sentence 1: Mr. and Mrs. Jones have been at loggerheads with each other for years.
Sentence 2: The two political parties were at loggerheads during the entire legislative session.

Meaning 1: at the limits of one’s mental resources.
Sentence 1: I’m at my wits’ end trying to solve this problem.
Sentence 2: Tom could do no more to earn money. He was at his wits’ end.

Meaning 1: disorderly
Sentence 1: Mrs. Smith is at sixes and sevens since the death of her husband.
Sentence 2: The house is always at sixes and sevens when Bill’s home by himself.

Meaning 1: always ready to obey someone.
Sentence 1: What makes you think I wait around here at your beck and call? I live here, too, you know!
Sentence 2: It was a fine hotel. There were dozens of maids and waiters at our beck and call.

Idioms: at the bottom of the ladder
Meaning 1: at the lowest level of pay and status.
Sentence 1: Most people start work at the bottom of the ladder.
Sentence 2: When Ann was declared redundant, she had to start all over again at the bottom of the ladder.

Idioms: at the drop of a hat
Meaning 1: immediately and without urging.
Sentence 1: John was always ready to go fishing at the drop of a hat.
Sentence 2: If you need help, just call on me. I can come at the drop of a hat.

Meaning 1: at the last possible moment. (Biblical.)
Sentence 1: She always handed her term essays in at the eleventh hour.
Sentence 2: We don’t worry about death until the eleventh hour.

Idioms: at the end of one’s tether
Meaning 1: at the limits of one’s endurance.
Sentence 1: I’m at the end of my tether! I just can’t go on this way!
Sentence 2: These children are driving me out of my mind. I’m at the end of my tether.

Idioms: at the expense of someone or something
Meaning 1: to the detriment of someone or something
Meaning 2: to the harm or disadvantage of someone or something.
Sentence 1: He had a good laugh at the expense of his brother.
Sentence 2: He took employment in a better place at the expense of a larger income.

Idioms: at the top of one’s voice
Meaning 1: with a very loud voice.
Sentence 1: Bill called to Mary at the top of his voice.
Sentence 2: How can I work when you’re all talking at the top of your voices?

Idioms: avoid someone or something like the plague
Meaning 1: to avoid someone or something totally.
Sentence 1: What’s wrong with Bob? Everyone avoids him like the plague.
Sentence 2: I don’t like opera. I avoid it like the plague.

Meaning 1: an innocent or naive person.
Sentence 1: He’s a babe in arms when it comes to taking girls out.
Sentence 2: Mary has no idea how to fight the election. Politically, she’s a babe in arms.

Meaning 1: the most remote place
Sentence 1: John hardly ever comes to the city. He lives at the back of beyond.
Sentence 2: Mary likes lively entertainment, but her husband likes to holiday in the back of beyond.

Meaning 1: [it is] time to start over again
Meaning 2: [it is] time to plan something over again, especially if it has gone wrong.
Sentence 1: The scheme didn’t work. Back to the drawing-board.
Sentence 2: I failed English this term. Well, back to the old drawing-board.

Meaning 1: with one’s luggage
Sentence 1: Sally showed up at our door bag and baggage one Sunday morning.
Sentence 2: All right, if you won’t pay the rent, out with you, bag and baggage!

Meaning 1: a first experience of something, usually something difficult or unpleasant.
Sentence 1: My son’s just had his first visit to the dentist. He stood up to the baptism of fire very well.
Sentence 2: Mary’s had her baptism of fire as a teacher. She had to take the worst class in the school.

Idioms: beard the lion in his den
Meaning 1: to face an adversary on the adversary’s home ground.
Sentence 1: I went to the solicitor’s office to beard the lion in his den.
Sentence 2: He said he hadn’t wanted to come to my home, but it was better to beard the lion in his den.

Meaning 1: to avoid answering a question or discussing a subject directly
Sentence 1: Let’s stop beating about the bush and discuss this matter.
Sentence 2: Stop beating about the bush and answer my question.

Meaning 1: to retreat or withdraw very quickly.
Sentence 1: We went out into the cold weather but beat a retreat to the warmth of our fire.

Idioms: be a thorn in someone’s side
Meaning 1: to be a constant source of annoyance to someone.
Sentence 1: This problem is a thorn in my side. I wish I had a solution to it.
Sentence 2: John was a thorn in my side for years before I finally got rid of him.

Meaning 1: a situation or way of life that is always happy and comfortable.
Sentence 1: Living with Pat can’t be a bed of roses, but her husband is always smiling.
Sentence 2: Being the boss isn’t exactly a bed of roses. There are so many problems to sort out.

Idioms: before you can say Jack Robinson
Meaning 1: almost immediately.
Sentence 1: And before you could say Jack Robinson, the bird flew away.
Sentence 2: I’ll catch a plane and be there before you can say Jack Robinson.

Meaning 1: to be close to something
Meaning 2: to be nearly at something, such as a time, date, age, etc.
Sentence 1: It’s getting on for midnight.
Sentence 2: He must be getting on for fifty.

Meaning 1: to be impossible to describe well enough to give an accurate picture
Meaning 2: to be impossible to do justice to in words.
Sentence 1: Her cruelty to her child beggar’s description.
Sentence 2: The soprano’s voice beggars description.

Meaning 1: to ask to be released from something
Sentence 1: I have an important meeting, so I’ll have to beg off.
Sentence 2: I wanted to go to the affair, but I had to beg off.

Meaning 1: to choose to believe something or not.
Sentence 1: Believe it or not, I just got home from work.
Sentence 2: I’m over fifty years old, believe it or not.

Meaning 1: to talk to someone at length, perhaps annoyingly.
Sentence 1: Tom is over there bending Jane’s ear about something.
Sentence 2: I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to bend your ear for an hour, but I’m upset.

Meaning 1: to be old-fashioned
Sentence 1: That’s a silly idea. It’s old hat.
Sentence 2: Nobody does that anymore. That’s just old hat.

Idioms: beyond the shadow of a doubt
Meaning 1: completely without doubt.
Sentence 1: We accepted her story as true beyond the shadow of a doubt.

Meaning 1: to be very different, especially in opinions or attitudes
Meaning 2: to be far from coming to an agreement.
Sentence 1: Mr. and Mrs. Jones don’t get along well. They are poles apart.
Sentence 2: They’ll never sign the contract because they are poles apart.

Meaning 1: one’s best clothing.
Sentence 1: I always put on my best bib and tucker on Sundays.
Sentence 2: Put on your best bib and tucker, and let’s go to the city.

Meaning 1: to be grateful for any small benefits or advantages one has, especially in a generally difficult situation.
Sentence 1: We have very little money, but we must be grateful for small mercies. At least we have enough food.
Sentence 2: Bob was badly injured in the accident, but at least he’s still alive. Let’s be grateful for small mercies.

Meaning 1: outside the extent of one’s knowledge or understanding.
Sentence 1: Why she married him is beyond our ken.
Sentence 2: His attitude to others is quite beyond my ken.

Meaning 1: unacceptable
Meaning 2: outlawed. (The Pale historically was the area of English government around Dublin. The people who lived outside this area were regarded as uncivilized.)
Sentence 1: Your behavior is simply beyond the pale.
Sentence 2: Because of Tom’s rudeness, he’s considered beyond the pale and is never asked to party anymore.

Meaning 1: completely without doubt. (Said of a fact, not a person.)
Sentence 1: Please assure us that you are certain of the facts beyond any shadow of doubt.

Meaning 1: more than one can say. (Especially with grateful and thankful.)
Sentence 1: Sally was thankful beyond words at being released.
Sentence 2: I don’t know how to thank you. I’m grateful beyond words.

Meaning 1: to wait patiently.
Sentence 1: I’ve been biding my time for years, just waiting for a chance like this.
Sentence 2: He’s not the type to just sit there and bide his time. He wants some action.

Meaning 1: to speak sharply and angrily to someone.
Sentence 1: There was no need to bite Mary’s head off just because she was five minutes late.
Sentence 2: The boss has been biting everybody’s head off since his wife left him.

Idioms: bite the hand that feeds one
Meaning 1: to do harm to someone who does good things for you.
Sentence 1: I’m your mother! How can you bite the hand that feeds you?
Sentence 2: It’s a real case of biting the hand that feeds her. She’s reported her stepmother to the police for shoplifting.

Meaning 1: an unpleasant fact that has to be accepted.
Sentence 1: It was a bitter pill for her brother to swallow when she married his enemy.
Sentence 2: We found his deception a bitter pill to swallow.

Meaning 1: a member of a family or group who is unsatisfactory or not up to the standard of the rest
Meaning 2: the worst member of the family.
Sentence 1: Mary is the black sheep of the family. She’s always in trouble with the police.
Sentence 2: The others are all in well-paid jobs, but John is unemployed. He’s the black sheep of the family.

Meaning 1: freedom or permission to act as one thinks necessary or wishes for. (From a signed bank cheque with the amount left blank.)
Sentence 1: He’s been given a blank cheque with regard to reorganizing the workforce.
Sentence 2: The manager has been given no instructions about how to train the staff. He’s just been given a blank cheque.

Meaning 1: to be changeable or uncertain (about something).
Sentence 1: He keeps blowing hot and cold on the question of moving to the country.
Sentence 2: He blows hot and cold about this. I wish he’d make up his mind.

Meaning 1: to boast
Sentence 1: Tom is always blowing his own trumpet. Is he really as good as he says he is?
Sentence 2: I find it hard to blow my own trumpet, so no one takes any notice of me.

Meaning 1: to reveal something, especially wrongdoing
Sentence 1: The police blew the lid off the smuggling ring.
Sentence 2: The journalists blew the lid off the group’s illegal activities.

Meaning 1: [for something] suddenly to get ruined or destroyed while seeming to go well.
Sentence 1: All my plans blew up in my face when she broke off the engagement.
Sentence 2: It is terrible for your hopes of promotion to blow up in your face.

Meaning 1: the blood [heredity] of a noble family
Sentence 1: The earl refuses to allow anyone who is not of blue blood to marry his son.
Sentence 2: Although Mary’s family are poor, she has blue blood in her veins.

Meaning 1: the subject or point of an argument
Sentence 1: We’ve fought for so long that we’ve forgotten what the bone of contention is.
Sentence 2: The question of a fence between the houses has become quite a bone of contention.

Idioms: born with a silver spoon in one’s mouth
Meaning 1: born with many advantages
Sentence 1: Sally was born with a silver spoon in her mouth.
Sentence 2: It never rains when he goes on holiday. He was born with a silver spoon in his mouth.

Meaning 1: to be very humble and subservient.
Sentence 1: Please don’t bow and scrape. We are all equal here.
Sentence 2: The shop assistant came in, bowing and scraping, and asked if he could help us.

Meaning 1: two people who keep failing to meet. (Although they both sometimes go to the same place, they are never there at the same time. From characters in a nineteenth-century play, one of whom rented a room by day, the other the same room by night.)
Sentence 1: Since her husband started doing nightshifts, they are Box and Cox. She leaves for work in the morning before he gets home.
Sentence 2: The two teachers are Box and Cox. Mr. Smith takes class on Monday and Wednesday, and Mr. Brown on Tuesday and Thursday.

Meaning 1: to begin to do something which no one else has done
Sentence 1: Dr. Anderson was breaking new ground in cancer research.
Sentence 2: They were breaking new ground in consumer electronics.

Meaning 1: to have one’s first success at something. (From a cricketing expression meaning “to begin scoring.”)
Sentence 1: At last Jim’s broken his duck. He’s got a girl to go out with him.
Sentence 2: Jane has failed all her exams up until now, but she’s broken her duck by passing French.

Meaning 1: not to do what one said one would
Sentence 1: Don’t say you’ll visit your grandmother if you can’t go. She hates for people to break their word.
Sentence 2: If you break your word, she won’t trust you again.

Meaning 1: to cushion a falling person
Meaning 2: to lessen the impact of a falling person.
Sentence 1: When the little boy fell out of the window, the bushes broke his fall.
Sentence 2: The old lady slipped on the ice, but a snowbank broke her fall.

Meaning 1: to cause someone emotional pain.
Sentence 1: It just broke my heart when Tom ran away from home.
Sentence 2: Sally broke John’s heart when she refused to marry him.

Meaning 1: to start social communication and conversation.
Sentence 1: Tom is so outgoing. He’s always the first one to break the ice at parties.
Sentence 2: It’s hard to break the ice at formal events.

Meaning 1: to tell someone some important news, usually bad news.
Sentence 1: The doctor had to break the news to Jane about her husband’s cancer.
Sentence 2: I hope that the doctor broke the news gently.

Meaning 1: to keep close watch on someone, causing worry and irritation
Meaning 2: to watch someone’s activities, especially to try to hurry something along.
Sentence 1: I can’t work with you breathing down my neck all the time. Go away.
Sentence 2: I will get through my life with- out your help. Stop breathing down my neck.

Meaning 1: to die
Sentence 1: Mrs. Smith breathed her last this morning.
Sentence 2: I’ll keep running every day until I breathe my last.

Meaning 1: to earn a salary.
Sentence 1: I’ve got to get to work if I’m going to bring home the bacon.
Sentence 2: Go out and get a job so you can bring home the bacon.

Meaning 1: to cause someone to realize the truth of something.
Sentence 1: Seeing the starving refugees on television really brings home the tragedy of their situation.
Sentence 2: It wasn’t until she failed her exam that the importance of studying was brought home to her.

Meaning 1: to cause something to come to the point when a decision has to be made or action taken.
Sentence 1: The latest disagreement between management and the union has brought matters to a head. There will be an all-out strike now.
Sentence 2: It’s a relief that things have been brought to a head. The disputes have been going on for months.

Meaning 1: to make something known
Sentence 1: The scientists brought their findings to light.
Sentence 2: We must bring this new evidence to light.

Meaning 1: a very clumsy person around breakable things
Meaning 2: a thoughtless or tactless person. (China is fine crockery.)
Sentence 1: Look at Bill, as awkward as a bull in a china shop.
Sentence 2: Get that big dog out of my garden. It’s like a bull in a china shop.
Sentence 3: Bob is so rude, a real bull in a china shop.

Meaning 1: to go so far in a course of action that one cannot turn back
Meaning 2: to do something which makes it impossible to return to one’s former position.
Sentence 1: I don’t want to emigrate now, but I’ve rather burned my boats by giving up my job and selling my house.

Meaning 1: to stop fighting or arguing
Sentence 1: All right, you two. Calm down and bury the hatchet.
Sentence 2: I wish Mr. and Mrs. Franklin would bury the hatchet. They argue all the time.

Meaning 1: to go so far in a course of action that one cannot turn back.
Sentence 1: Mary would now like to marry Peter, but she burned her bridges behind her by breaking offthe engagement.

Idioms: burn the candle at both ends
Meaning 1: to exhaust oneself by doing too much, for example by working very hard during the day and also staying up very late at night.
Sentence 1: No wonder Mary is ill. She has been burning the candle at both ends for a long time.
Sentence 2: You can’t keep on burning the candle at both ends.

Meaning 1: to stay up working, especially studying, late at night. (Refers to working by the light of an oil-lamp.)
Sentence 1: I have to go home and burn the midnight oil tonight.
Sentence 2: If you burn the midnight oil night after night, you’ll probably become ill.

Meaning 1: the informal, usually rapid spreading of news or information by word of mouth.
Sentence 1: The bush telegraph tells me that the manager is leaving.
Sentence 2: How did John know that Kate was divorced? He must have heard it on the bush telegraph.

Meaning 1: the part or end of something that actually does the work or carries out the procedure.
Sentence 1: Keep awayfrom the business end of the electric drill in case you get hurt.
Sentence 2: Don’t point the business end of that gun at anyone. It might go off.

Meaning 1: leisure time spent doing something similar to what one does at work.
Sentence 1: Tutoring pupils in the evening is too much of a busman’s holiday for our English teacher.
Sentence 2: It’s a bit of a busman’s holiday to ask her to be wardrobe mistress for our amateur production in the summer. She’s a professional dressmaker.

Idioms: buy a pig in a poke
Meaning 1: to purchase or accept something without having seen or examined it. (Poke means “bag.”)
Sentence 1: Buying a car without test driving it is like buying a pig in a poke.
Sentence 2: He bought a pig in a poke when he ordered a diamond ring by mail order.

Meaning 1: to buy something cheaply.
Sentence 1: No one else wanted it, so I bought it for a song.
Sentence 2: I could buy this house for a song, because it’s so ugly.

Meaning 1: irregularly
Sentence 1: Somehow, they got the job done, by fits and starts.
Sentence 2: By fits and starts, the old car finally got us to town.

Meaning 1: rapidly
Sentence 1: Our garden is growing by leaps and bounds.

Meaning 1: rapidly
Sentence 1: The profits of my company are increasing in leaps and bounds.

Meaning 1: absolutely not
Sentence 1: I’m by no means angry with you.

Meaning 1: by a subsequent immediate posting (back to the sender). (A phrase indicating that an answer is expected soon, by mail.)
Sentence 1: Since this bill is overdue, would you kindly send us your cheque by return post?
Sentence 2: I answered your request by return post over a year ago. Please check your records.

Meaning 1: in the same way
Sentence 1: Tom must be good when he comes here, and, by the same token, I expect you to behave properly when you go to his house.
Sentence 2: The mayor votes for his friend’s causes. By the same token, the friend votes for the mayor’s causes.

Idioms: by the seat of one’s pants
Meaning 1: by sheer luck and very little skill.
Sentence 1: I got through school by the seat of my pants.
Sentence 2: The jungle pilot spent most of his days flying by the seat of his pants.

Idioms: by the skin of one’s teeth
Meaning 1: just barely
Meaning 2: by an amount equal to the thickness of the (imaginary) skin on one’s teeth.
Sentence 1: I got through that exam by the skin of my teeth.
Sentence 2: I got to the airport late and caught the plane by the skin of my teeth.

Idioms: by the sweat of one’s brow
Meaning 1: by one’s efforts
Sentence 1: Tom grew these vegetables by the sweat of his brow.
Sentence 2: Sally made her fortune by the sweat of her brow.

Meaning 1: because of something
Sentence 1: She’s permitted to vote by virtue of her age.
Sentence 2: They are members of the club by virtue of their great wealth.

Meaning 1: by speaking rather than writing.
Sentence 1: I learned about it by word of mouth.
Sentence 2: I need it in writing. I don’t trust things I hear about by word of mouth.

Meaning 1: to call something by its right name
Meaning 2: to speak frankly about something, even if it is unpleasant.
Sentence 1: Well, I believe it’s time to call a spade a spade. We are just avoiding the issue.
Sentence 2: Let’s call a spade a spade. The man is a liar.

Meaning 1: to leave work and go home
Meaning 2: to say that a day’s work has been completed
Meaning 3: to bring something to an end
Sentence 1: I’m tired. Let’s call it a day even though it’s only three o’clock.
Sentence 2: They’re not engaged any more. They called it a day.
Sentence 3: I haven’t finished this essay, but I’m calling it a day.

Meaning 1: the need to go to the lavatory. (Humorous.)
Sentence 1: Stop the car here! I have to answer the call of nature.
Sentence 2: There was no interval in the meeting to take account of the call of nature.

Idioms: can’t hold a candle to someone
Meaning 1: not equal to someone
Meaning 2: unable to measure up to someone.
Sentence 1: Mary can’t hold a candle to Ann when it comes to playing the piano.
Sentence 2: As for singing, John can’t hold a candle to Jane.

Idioms: can’t make head nor tail of someone or something
Meaning 1: unable to understand someone or something
Sentence 1: John is so strange. I can’t make head nor tail of him.
Sentence 2: Do this report again. I can’t make head nor tail of it.

Idioms: can’t see beyond the end of one’s nose
Meaning 1: unaware of and uncaring for the things which might happen in the future
Sentence 1: John is a very poor planner. He can’t see beyond the end of his nose.
Sentence 2: Ann can’t see beyond the end of her nose. She’s taken a job without finding out if the firm is financially secure.

Idioms: can’t see one’s hand in front of one’s face
Meaning 1: unable to see very far, usually owing to darkness or fog.
Sentence 1: It was so dark that I couldn’t see my hand in front of my face.
Sentence 2: Bob said that the fog was so thick he couldn’t see his hand in front of his face.

Meaning 1: to be exceptionally successful.
Sentence 1: He carried all before him on school prize day.
Sentence 2: In the sports event, Mary just carried all before her.

Meaning 1: to be in love with someone who does not return love
Meaning 2: to brood over a hopeless love affair.
Sentence 1: John is carrying a torch for Jane.
Sentence 2: Is John still carrying a torch for his lost love?

Idioms: carry the weight of the world on one’s shoulders
Meaning 1: to appear to be burdened by many problems.
Sentence 1: Look at Tom. He seems to be carrying the weight of the world on his shoulders.
Sentence 2: Cheer up, Tom! You don’t need to carry the weight of the world on your shoulders.

Meaning 1: complete freedom to act or proceed as one pleases. (Literally, a white or blank card.)
Sentence 1: We were given carte blanche to choose the color scheme.
Sentence 2: They were not instructed where to shop. It was a case of carte blanche.

Meaning 1: very similar.
Sentence 1: The two sisters are cast in the same mouldequally mean.
Sentence 2: All the members of that family are cast in the same mould, and all have ended up in prison.

Meaning 1: to resume one’s normal breathing after exertion
Meaning 2: to return to normal after being busy or very active.
Sentence 1: I ran so fast that it took me ten minutes to catch my breath.
Sentence 2: I don’t have time to catch my breath. I have to start work immediately.

Meaning 1: to find someone unprepared
Sentence 1: The unexpected exam caught some of the pupils on the hop.
Sentence 2: The police caught the suspect on the hop and with- out an alibi.

Meaning 1: to establish eye contact with someone
Sentence 1: Try and catch the barman’s eye.
Sentence 2: The shiny red car caught Mary’s eye.

Meaning 1: to become sunburnt.
Sentence 1: The baby’s face is red, she’s caught the sun.
Sentence 2: Fair-skinned people catch the sun easily.

Meaning 1: Why don’t you speak?
Sentence 1: Answer me! What’s the matter, cat got your tongue?
Sentence 2: Why don’t you speak up? Cat got your tongue?

Meaning 1: at the mercy of someone
Sentence 1: I’m caught over a barrel, and I have to do what he says.
Sentence 2: Ann will do exactly what I say. She’s caught over a barrel.

Meaning 1: to cause people to gossip
Meaning 2: to give people something to gossip about.
Sentence 1: The way John was looking at Mary will surely cause tongues to wag.
Sentence 2: The way Mary was dressed will also cause tongues to wag.

Meaning 1: to be ready and anxious to do something
Meaning 2: to be impatient. (Originally said about horses.)
Sentence 1: The children were champing at the bit to get into the swimming-pool.
Sentence 2: The hounds were champing at the bit to begin the hunt.

Meaning 1: to do something risky or dangerous.
Sentence 1: He certainly chanced his arm when he was rude to the boss’s wife.
Sentence 2: Don’t chance your arm by asking for yet another day off.

Meaning 1: [for something] to be sold. (Refers to the changing of owners.)
Sentence 1: How many times has this house changed hands in the last ten years?
Sentence 2: We built this house in 1920, and it has never changed hands.

Meaning 1: to make major changes in an activity which has already begun
Meaning 2: to choose someone or something else after it is too late.
Sentence 1: I’m already baking a cherry pie. I can’t bake an apple pie. It’s too late to change horses in mid-stream.
Sentence 2: The house is half built. It’s too late to employ a different architect. You can’t change horses in mid-stream.

Meaning 1: to change the manner, attitude, or behavior of a person, usually from bad to good, or from rude to pleasant.
Sentence 1: The cashier was most unpleasant until she learned that I’m a bank director. Then she changed her tune.
Sentence 2: “I shall fine you £150, and perhaps that will help change your tune,” said the judge to the rude defendant.

Meaning 1: detailed sources of information. (A reference to the method of referring to biblical texts.)
Sentence 1: He gave chapter and verse for his reasons for disputing that Shakespeare had written the play.
Sentence 2: The suspect gave chapter and verse of his associate’s activities.

Meaning 1: a series of misfortunes.
Sentence 1: Yesterday was just a chapter of accidents, nothing went right.
Sentence 2: The play rehearsal consisted of a chapter of accidents, but the opening performance was perfect.

Meaning 1: side by side
Sentence 1: The walkers had to walk cheek by jowl along the narrow streets.
Sentence 2: The two families lived cheek by jowl in one houseThe children worked cheek by jowl to make their mother’s birthday gift in time.
Sentence 3: All members of the transition team worked cheek by jowl late into the night to get the job done.

Meaning 1: bored
Sentence 1: He was cheesed off with his job.
Sentence 2: She was cheesed off when she missed the bus.

Meaning 1: mean
Sentence 1: He was too cheese paring to eat properly.
Sentence 2: The cheese paring old woman will not give to the poor.

Meaning 1: to think deeply. (From the cow’s habit of bringing food back from the first stomach into the mouth to chew it, called chewing the cud.)
Sentence 1: I can’t decide where to go on holiday. I’ll have to chew the cud.
Sentence 2: He’s chewing the cud about what to do next.

Meaning 1: very cold.
Sentence 1: I was chilled to the marrow in that snowstorm.

Meaning 1: very cold
Sentence 1: The children were chilled to the bone in that unheated room.

Meaning 1: a weakness or vulnerable point that pro- vides an opportunity for attacking or impressing someone who is otherwise invulnerable.
Sentence 1: His love for his child is the chink in his armour.
Sentence 2: Jane’s insecurity is the chink in her armour.

Meaning 1: a person (usually a male) who behaves in the same way as his father or resembles his father.
Sentence 1: John looks like his father, a real chip off the old block.
Sentence 2: Bill Jones is a chip off the old block. He’s a banker just like his father.

Meaning 1: to keep changing or altering something.
Sentence 1: The shop is always chopping and changing staff.
Sentence 2: The firm is constantly chopping and changing its plans.

Idioms: clap eyes on someone or something
Meaning 1: to see someone or something, perhaps for the first time
Meaning 2: to set eyes on someone or something.
Sentence 1: I wish she had never clapped eyes on her fiancé.
Sentence 2: I haven’t clapped eyes on a red squirrel for years.

Meaning 1: to get rid of doubts or hostile feelings. (Sometimes this is said about an argument or other unpleasantness. The literal meaning is also used.)
Sentence 1: All right let’s discuss this frankly. It’ll be better if we clear the air.
Sentence 2: Mr. and Mrs. Brown always seem to have to clear the air with a big argument before they can be sociable.

Meaning 1: to admit that one is wrong
Sentence 1: They were sure they were in the right, but they climbed down when we proved them wrong.
Sentence 2: The teacher was forced to climb down and admit she had made a mistake.

Meaning 1: to restrain someone
Meaning 2: to reduce or put an end to someone’s privileges or freedom.
Sentence 1: You had better learn to get home on time, or your father will clip your wings.
Sentence 2: My mother threatened to clip my wings if I kept staying out late.

Meaning 1: involving secrecy and plotting.
Sentence 1: A great deal of cloak-and-dagger stuff goes on in political circles.
Sentence 2: A lot of cloak- and-dagger activity was involved in the appointment of the director.

Meaning 1: to ignore something
Meaning 2: to pretend that something is not really happening.
Sentence 1: You can’t close your eyes to the hunger in the world.
Sentence 2: His mother closed her eyes to the fact that he was being beaten by his father.

Meaning 1: to seek something which is useless or unattainable
Meaning 2: to make a futile attempt at something.
Sentence 1: I really didn’t think that I would get the job. I was clutching at straws.
Sentence 2: She won’t accept that he was lost at sea. She’s still clutching at straws.

Meaning 1: to show or express defiance or scorn at someone.
Sentence 1: He cocked a snook at the traffic warden and tore up the ticket.
Sentence 2: The boy cocked a snook at the park attendant and walked on the grass.

Meaning 1: someone who acts in a more important manner than others in a group.
Sentence 1: The deputy manager was cock of the walk until the new manager arrived.
Sentence 2: He loved acting cock of the walk and ordering everyone about.

Meaning 1: no comfort or consolation at all.
Sentence 1: She knows there are others worse off than her, but that’s cold comfort.
Sentence 2: It was cold comfort to the student that others had failed also.

Meaning 1: to have a misfortune
Meaning 2: to fail. (Literally, to fall off one’s horse.)
Sentence 1: Bob invested all his money in the shares market just before it fell. Did he come a cropper!
Sentence 2: Jane was out all night before she took her exams. She really came a cropper.

Meaning 1: to return without anything.
Sentence 1: All right go gambling if you must. Don’t come away empty handed, though.
Sentence 2: Go to the bank and ask for the loan again. This time try not to come away empty handed.

Meaning 1: to lose one’s social position or financial standing.
Sentence 1: Mr. Jones has really come down in the world since he lost his job.
Sentence 2: If I were unemployed, I’m certain I’d come down in the world, too.

Meaning 1: to become realistic or practical, especially after a period of daydreaming
Meaning 2: to become alert to what is going on around one.
Sentence 1: You have very good ideas, John, but you must come down to earth. We can’t possibly afford any of your suggestions.
Sentence 2: Pay attention to what is going on. Come down to earth and join the discussion.

Meaning 1: to become ill with some disease.
Sentence 1: I’m afraid I’m coming down with a cold.
Sentence 2: I’ll probably come down with pneumonia.

Meaning 1: to come from many different places.
Sentence 1: Everyone was there. They came from far and wide.
Sentence 2: We have foods that come from far and wide.

Meaning 1: to return to the original position or state of affairs.
Sentence 1: The family sold the house generations ago, but the wheel has come full circle and one of their descendants lives there now.
Sentence 2: The employers’ power was reduced by the unions at one point, but the wheel has come full circle again.

Meaning 1: to return to cause trouble (for someone).
Sentence 1: As I feared, all my problems came home to roost.
Sentence 2: His lies finally came home to roost. His wife discovered his adultery.

Meaning 1: to receive something
Sentence 1: Mary came in for a tremendous amount of money when her aunt died.
Sentence 2: Her new play has come in for a lot of criticism.

Meaning 1: to inherit something.
Sentence 1: Jane came into a small fortune when her aunt died.
Sentence 2: Mary does not come into her inheritance until she comes of age.

Meaning 1: to reach an age when one is old enough to own property, get married, and sign legal contracts.
Sentence 1: When Jane comes of age, she will buy her own car.
Sentence 2: Sally, who came of age last month, entered into an agreement to purchase a house.

Meaning 1: to be in second place or worse
Sentence 1: You can fight with your brother if you like, but you’ll come off second best.
Sentence 2: Why do I always come off second best in an argument with you?

Meaning 1: to work out all right. (This means that problems or difficulties will go away as dirt goes away in the process of washing.)
Sentence 1: Don’t worry about their accusation. It’ll all come out in the wash.
Sentence 2: This trouble will go away. It’ll come out in the wash.

Meaning 1: to appear suddenly.
Sentence 1: Suddenly, a container lorry came out of nowhere.
Sentence 2: The storm came out of nowhere, and we were unprepared.

Meaning 1: to become more friendly
Sentence 1: Ann, you should come out of your shell and spend more time with your friends.
Sentence 2: Come out of your shell, Tom. Go out and make some friends.

Meaning 1: no matter whether it rains or the sun shines.
Sentence 1: Don’t worry. I’ll be there come rain or shine.
Sentence 2: We’ll hold the picnic, rain or shine.

Meaning 1: finally to agree or consent (to something)
Sentence 1: I thought he’d never agree, but in the end, he came around.
Sentence 2: She came around only after we argued for an hour.
Sentence 3: He came around after we threw cold water in his face.
Sentence 4: The boxer was knocked out but came around in a few seconds.

Meaning 1: to have a disaster, perhaps one which is deserved or expected
Sentence 1: I just know that the young man will come to a bad end.
Sentence 2: The miserly shopkeeper came to a bad end and was declared bankrupt.

Meaning 1: to come to a crucial point
Meaning 2: to come to a point when a problem must be solved.
Sentence 1: Remember my problem with my neighbors? Well, last night the whole thing came to a head.
Sentence 2: The battle between the two factions of the town council came to a head yesterday.

Meaning 1: to come to an early death.
Sentence 1: Poor Mr. Jones came to an untimely end in a car accident.
Sentence 2: The older brother came to an untimely end, but the twin boys lived to a ripe old age.

Meaning 1: to develop into a bad, unfortunate, or difficult situation.
Sentence 1: Things have come to a pretty pass when people have to beg in the streets.
Sentence 2: When parents are afraid of their children, things have come to a pretty pass.

Meaning 1: to fail or be unsuccessful
Sentence 1: The artist wept when her canvas came to grief.
Sentence 2: The wedding party came to grief when the bride passed out.

Meaning 1: to become known
Sentence 1: Some interesting facts about your past have just come to light.
Sentence 2: If too many bad things come to light, you may lose your job.

Meaning 1: to become obvious or prominent
Sentence 1: The question of salary has now come to the fore.
Sentence 2: Since his great showing in court, my solicitor has really come to the fore in his profession.

Meaning 1: having one’s absence noticed (at an event).
Sentence 1: We missed you last night. You were conspicuous by your absence.
Sentence 2: How could the bride’s father miss the wedding party? He was certainly conspicuous by his absence.

Meaning 1: a seeming contradiction in the wording of something.
Sentence 1: A wealthy pauper is a contradiction in terms.
Sentence 2: A straight talking politician may seem a contradiction in terms.

Meaning 1: to damage or ruin someone.
Sentence 1: I cooked my own goose by not showing up on time.
Sentence 2: Sally cooked Bob’s goose for treating her the way he did.

Meaning 1: to cheat in bookkeeping
Meaning 2: to make the accounts appear to balance when they do not.
Sentence 1: Jane was sent to jail for cooking the books of her mother’s shop.
Sentence 2: It’s hard to tell whether she really cooked the books or just didn’t know how to add.

Meaning 1: to wait impatiently (for someone).
Sentence 1: I spent all afternoon cooling my heels in the waiting room while the doctor talked on the telephone.
Sentence 2: All right. If you can’t behave properly, just sit down here and cool your heels until I call you.

Meaning 1: to cost a lot of money.
Sentence 1: I’ll bet that diamond cost a pretty penny.
Sentence 2: You can be sure that house cost a pretty penny.

Meaning 1: to cost an enormous sum of money. (Compare with pay the earth.)
Sentence 1: That huge car must have cost the earth!
Sentence 2: Do I look as though I can afford a house that costs the earth?

Meaning 1: to count people.
Sentence 1: I’ll tell you how many people are here after I count heads.
Sentence 2: Everyone is here. Let’s count heads so we can order the drinks.

Meaning 1: to open a bottle.
Sentence 1: Let’s crack a bottle of champagne to celebrate.
Sentence 2: We always crack a bottle of port at Christmas.

Meaning 1: to limit someone in some way.
Sentence 1: Having her young sister with her rather cramped her style on the dance floor.
Sentence 2: To ask him to keep regular hours would really be cramping his style.

Idioms: cross a bridge before one comes to it
Meaning 1: to worry excessively about something before it happens.
Sentence 1: There is no sense in crossing that bridge before you come to it.
Sentence 2: She’s always crossing bridges before coming to them. She needs to learn to relax.

Idioms: cross one’s heart (and hope to die)
Meaning 1: to pledge or vow that the truth is being told.
Sentence 1: It’s true, cross my heart and hope to die.
Sentence 2: It’s really true, cross my heart.

Meaning 1: to enter into an argument with someone.
Sentence 1: I don’t want to cross swords with Tom.
Sentence 2: The last time we crossed swords, we had a terrible time.

Meaning 1: to do something which inevitably commits one to a following course of action.
Sentence 1: Jane crossed the Rubicon by signing the contract.
Sentence 2: Find another job before you cross the Rubicon and resign from this one.

Meaning 1: the central issue of the matter.
Sentence 1: All right, this is the crux of the matter.
Sentence 2: It’s about time that we looked at the crux of the matter.

Meaning 1: to cry very hard.
Sentence 1: When we heard the news, we cried our eyes out with joy.
Sentence 2: She cried her eyes out after his death.

Meaning 1: to be unhappy about having done something which cannot be undone.
Sentence 1: I’m sorry that you broke your bicycle, Tom. But there is nothing that can be done now. Don’t cry over spilled milk.
Sentence 2: Ann is always crying over spilt milk.

Meaning 1: to cry out for help or to complain about something when nothing is really wrong.
Sentence 1: Pay no attention. She’s just crying wolf again.
Sentence 2: Don’t cry wolf too often. No one will come.

Meaning 1: someone whom one considers to be excessively interested in the (classical) arts.
Sentence 1: She won’t go to a funny film. She’s a real culture vulture.
Sentence 2: They watch only highbrow television. They’re culture vultures.

Meaning 1: affection shown to someone just because of the things, such as food or clothes, they supply.
Sentence 1: She doesn’t love her husband. It’s just cupboard love.
Sentence 2: Her affection for her foster parents is a pretense, simply cupboard love.

Meaning 1: to retreat and die
Meaning 2: to shrink away because one is very embarrassed.
Sentence 1: When I heard you say that, I could have curled up and died.
Sentence 2: Her mother’s praises made her want to curl up.

Meaning 1: to try to win favour from someone.
Sentence 1: The solicitor tried to curry favour with the judge.
Sentence 2: It’s silly to curry favour. Just act yourself.

Meaning 1: to look good
Sentence 1: Tom really cuts a fine figure on the dancefloor.
Sentence 2: Bill cuts a fine figure since he bought some new clothes.

Meaning 1: to bring a story to an end. (A formula which introduces a summary of a story or a joke.)
Sentence 1: Andto cut a long story short, I never got back the money that I lent him.
Sentence 2: If I can cut a long story short, let me say that everything worked out fine.

Meaning 1: fixed
Sentence 1: I find your writing quite boring. It’s too cut and dried.
Sentence 2: The lecture was, as usual, cut and dried. It was the same thing we’ve heard for years.
Sentence 3: Our plans are all cut and dried; you can’t contribute anything now.

Meaning 1: intense competition.(From sword fighting.)
Sentence 1: Peter tired of the cut and thrust of business.
Sentence 2: The cut and thrust of the stock-market is not for John.

Meaning 1: to affect both sides of an issue equally.
Sentence 1: Remember your suggestion that costs should be shared cuts both ways. You will have to pay as well.
Sentence 2: If our side cannot take along supporters to the game, then yours cannot either. The rule has to cut both ways.

Meaning 1: to reduce efforts or expenditures
Meaning 2: to do things poorly or incompletely.
Sentence 1: You cannot cut corners when you are dealing with public safety.
Sentence 2: Don’t cut corners, Sally. Let’s do the thing properly.

Meaning 1: to allow scarcely enough time, money, etc., in order to accomplish something.
Sentence 1: You’re cutting it too fine if you want to catch the bus. It leaves in five minutes.
Sentence 2: Joan had to search her pockets for money for the bus fare. She really cut it fine.

Meaning 1: to have no effect
Sentence 1: That idea cuts no ice. It won’t help at all.
Sentence 2: It cuts no ice that your mother is the director.

Idioms: cut one’s coat according to one’s cloth
Meaning 1: to plan one’s aims and activities in line with one’s resources and circumstances.
Sentence 1: We would like a bigger house, but we must cut our coat according to our cloth.

Idioms: cut one’s coat to suit one’s cloth
Meaning 1: to plan one’s aims and activities in line with one’s resources and circumstances.
Sentence 1: They can’t afford a holiday abroad, they have to cut their coat to suit their cloth.

Idioms: cut one’s eye teeth on something
Meaning 1: to have done something since one was very young
Meaning 2: to have much experience at something.
Sentence 1: Do I know about cars? I cut my eye teeth on cars.
Sentence 2: I cut my eye teeth on Bach. I can whistle everything he wrote.

Meaning 1: to gain one’s early experiences on something.
Sentence 1: You can cut your teeth on this project before getting involved in a more major one.
Sentence 2: The young police officers cut their teeth on minor crimes.

Meaning 1: to ignore someone totally.
Sentence 1: Joan was just about to speak to James when he cut her dead.
Sentence 2: Jean cut her former husband dead.

Meaning 1: to make a person humbler.
Sentence 1: John’s remarks really cut me down to size.
Sentence 2: Jane is too conceited. I think her new managing director will cut her down to size.

Meaning 1: to hurt someone’s feelings very badly.
Sentence 1: Your criticism cut me to the quick.
Sentence 2: Tom’s sharp words to Mary cut her to the quick.

Meaning 1: [for a baby or young person] to grow teeth.
Sentence 1: Billy is cross because he’s cutting teeth.
Sentence 2: Ann cut her first tooth this week.

Meaning 1: physical exercises done every day.
Sentence 1: My brother always feels better after his daily dozen.
Sentence 2: She would rather do a daily dozen than go on a diet.

Meaning 1: the everyday work routine.
Sentence 1: I’m getting very tired of the daily grind.
Sentence 2: When my holiday was over, I had to go back to the daily grind.

Idioms: damn someone or something with faint praise
Meaning 1: to criticize someone or something indirectly by not praising enthusiastically.
Sentence 1: The critic did not say that he disliked the play, but he damned it with faint praise.
Sentence 2: Mrs. Brown is very proud of her son’s achievements but damns her daughter’s with faint praise.

Meaning 1: something which fails to be as successful or exciting as it promised to be.
Sentence 1: The charity ball was a bit of a damp squib.
Sentence 2: The much-publicized protest turned out to be a damp squib.

Meaning 1: to be always ready to tend to someone’s wishes or needs.
Sentence 1: That young woman has three men dancing attendance on her.
Sentence 2: Her father expects her to dance attendance on him day and night.

Meaning 1: an old married couple living happily together. (From a couple so-called in eighteenth-century ballads.)
Sentence 1: Her parents are divorced, but her grandparents are like Darby and Joan.
Sentence 2: It’s good to see so many Darby and Joans at the party, but it needs some young couples to liven it up.

Meaning 1: someone whose abilities, plans, or feelings are little known to others. (From horse-racing.)
Sentence 1: It’s difficult to predict who will win the prize—there are two or three dark horses in the tournament.
Sentence 2: You’re a dark horse! We didn’t know you ran marathons!

Meaning 1: the bottom of the sea, especially when it is the final resting place for someone or something. (From seamen’s name for the evil spirit of the sea.)
Sentence 1: They were going to sail around the world but ended up in Davy Jones’s locker.
Sentence 2: Most of the gold from that trading ship is in Davy Jones’s locker.

Meaning 1: [an instance of] the practice of blatantly or grossly overcharging.
Sentence 1: It’s daylight robbery to charge that amount of money for a hotel room!
Sentence 2: The cost of renting a car at that place is daylight robbery.

Meaning 1: gone forever. (Refers literally to persons and figuratively to ideas and other things.)
Sentence 1: Now that Uncle Bill is dead and buried, we can read his will.
Sentence 2: That way of thinking is dead and buried.

Meaning 1: at the exact center of something
Sentence 1: The arrow hit the target dead center.
Sentence 2: When you put the flowers on the table, put them dead center.

Idioms: dead on one’s or its feet
Meaning 1: exhausted
Sentence 1: Ann is so tired. She’s really dead on her feet.
Sentence 2: He can’t teach well anymore. He’s dead on his feet.
Sentence 3: This inefficient company is dead on its feet.

Idioms: dead set against someone or something
Meaning 1: totally opposed to someone or something.
Sentence 1: I’m dead set against the new rates proposal.
Sentence 2: Everyone is dead set against the MP.

Meaning 1: sleeping very soundly.
Sentence 1: He spent the whole plane journey dead to the world.
Sentence 2: Look at her sleeping. She’s dead to the world.

Meaning 1: having a harmful effect on something
Sentence 1: This road is terribly bumpy. It’s death to tires.
Sentence 2: Stiletto heels are death to those tiles.

Meaning 1: [for something] to fade away or die down.
Sentence 1: I expect that all this excitement about computers will die a natural death.
Sentence 2: Most fads die a natural death.

Meaning 1: to laugh very long and hard.
Sentence 1: The joke was so funny that I almost died laughing.
Sentence 2: The play was meant to be funny, but the audience didn’t exactly die laughing.

Meaning 1: to die of emotional distress, especially grief over a lost love.
Sentence 1: I was not surprised to hear of her death. They say she died of a broken heart.
Sentence 2: In the film, the heroine appeared to die of a broken heart, but the audience knew she was poisoned.

Meaning 1: to suffer from boredom
Sentence 1: I shall die of boredom if I stay here alone all day.
Sentence 2: We sat there and listened politely, even though we were dying of boredom.

Meaning 1: to be responsible for one’s own downfall or ruin.
Sentence 1: The manager tried to get rid of his assistant, but he dug his own grave. He got the sack himself.
Sentence 2: The government has dug its own grave with the new taxation bill. It won’t be re-elected.

Meaning 1: to be asked to social gatherings because of the information one has.
Sentence 1: She’s been dining out on the story of her promotion for months.
Sentence 2: The journalist dines out on all the gossip he acquires.

Meaning 1: extremely cheap.
Sentence 1: Buy some more of those plums. They’re dirt cheap.
Sentence 2: In Italy, the peaches are dirt cheap.

Meaning 1: a look or glance expressing disapproval or dislike.
Sentence 1: I stopped whistling when I saw the dirty look on her face.
Sentence 2: The child who sneaked received dirty looks from the other children.
Sentence 3: Ann gave me a dirty look.
Sentence 4: I gave her a dirty look back.

Meaning 1: to react with surprise
Meaning 2: to have to look twice to make sure that one really saw correctly.
Sentence 1: When the boy led a goat into the park, everyone did a double take.
Sentence 2: When the doctor saw that the man had six toes, she did a double take.

Meaning 1: to make a total reversal of opinion or action.
Sentence 1: Without warning, the government did an about-face on taxation.
Sentence 2: It had done an about-face on the question of rates last year.

Meaning 1: one who prevents others from enjoying a privilege that one does not make use of or enjoy oneself.
Sentence 1: Jane is a real dog in the manger. She cannot drive, but she will not lend anyone her car.
Sentence 2: If Martin were not such a dog in the manger, he would let his brother have that evening suit he never wears.

Meaning 1: to do something well
Meaning 2: to represent or portray something accurately
Meaning 3: to eat or drink a great deal.
Sentence 1: Sally really did justice to the contract negotiations.
Sentence 2: This photograph doesn’t do justice to the beauty of the mountains.
Sentence 3: Bill always does justice to
Sentence 4: the evening meal.

Meaning 1: cooked just right.
Sentence 1: Yummy! This meat is done to a turn.
Sentence 2: I like it done to a turn, not too well done and not too raw.

Meaning 1: a very long time.
Sentence 1: The woman hasn’t been seen for donkey’s ages.

Meaning 1: a very long time.
Sentence 1: We haven’t had a holiday in donkey’s years.

Meaning 1: hard or boring work.
Sentence 1: His wife picks flowers, but he does all the donkeywork in the garden.
Sentence 2: I don’t only baby-sit. I do all the donkeywork around the house.

Meaning 1: to do one’s share of the work
Meaning 2: to do whatever one can do to help.
Sentence 1: Everybody must do their bit to help get things under control.
Sentence 2: I always try to do my bit. How can I help this time?

Meaning 1: the same kind of, usually bad, treatment which one gives to other people.
Sentence 1: Sally is never very friendly. Someone is going to give her a dose of her own medicine someday and ignore her.
Sentence 2: The thief didn’t like getting a dose of his own medicine when his car was stolen.

Meaning 1: to do something to someone’s disadvantage.
Sentence 1: He really did me down when he applied for the same job.
Sentence 2: Don’t expect Mr. Black to help you. He enjoys doing people down.

Meaning 1: to benefit someone.
Sentence 1: A nice hot bath really does me good.
Sentence 2: It would do you good to lose some weight.

Meaning 1: to treat someone generously.
Sentence 1: What a good hotel. The conference has done us proud.
Sentence 2: He certainly did his daughter proud. The wedding reception cost a fortune.

Meaning 1: to make someone feel good emotionally.
Sentence 1: It does my heart good to hear you talk that way.
Sentence 2: When she sent me a get-well card, it really did my heart good.

Meaning 1: to do exactly what needs to be done
Meaning 2: to be satisfactory for a purpose.
Sentence 1: Push the car just a little more to the left. There, that does the trick.
Sentence 2: If you give me two pounds, I’ll have enough to do the trick.

Meaning 1: language or speech that is difficult or impossible to understand.
Sentence 1: This book on English grammar is written in double Dutch. I can’t understand a word.
Sentence 2: Try to find a lecturer who speaks slowly, not one who speaks double Dutch.

Meaning 1: someone who will not easily believe something without strong proof or evidence. (From the biblical account of the apostle Thomas, who would not believe that Christ had risen from the grave until he had touched Him.)
Sentence 1: Mary won’t believe that I have a dog until she sees him. She’s such a doubting Thomas.
Sentence 2: This school is full of doubting Thomases. They want to see his new bike with their own eyes.

Meaning 1: shabby
Sentence 1: The tramp was really down at heel.
Sentence 2: Tom’s house needs paint. It looks down at heel.

Meaning 1: sad faced
Sentence 1: Ever since the party was cancelled, Barbara has been looking down in the mouth.
Sentence 2: Bob has been down in the mouth since his girlfriend left.

Meaning 1: without any money
Sentence 1: Can you lend me twenty pounds? I’ve been down on my luck lately.
Sentence 2: The gambler had to get a job because he had been down on his luck and didn’t earn enough money to live on.

Meaning 1: practical
Sentence 1: Her ideas for the boutique are always very down to earth.
Sentence 2: Those philosophers are anything but down to earth.

Meaning 1: to act very slowly, often deliberately.
Sentence 1: The government are dragging their feet on this bill because it will lose votes.
Sentence 2: If the planning department hadn’t dragged their feet, the building would have been built by now.

Meaning 1: to get no response
Sentence 1: I asked him about Tom’s financial problems, and I just drew a blank.
Sentence 2: We looked in the files for an hour, but we drew a blank.

Idioms: draw a line between something and something else
Meaning 1: to separate two things
Meaning 2: to distinguish or differentiate between two things.
Sentence 1: It’s necessary to draw a line between bumping into people and striking them.
Sentence 2: It’s very hard to draw the line between slamming a door and just closing it loudly.

Meaning 1: to introduce information which diverts attention from the main issue.
Sentence 1: The accountant drew several red herrings to prevent people from discovering that he had embezzled the money.
Sentence 2: The government, as always, will draw a red herring whenever there is a monetary crisis.

Meaning 1: to hit or bite (a person or an animal) and make a wound that bleeds.
Sentence 1: The dog chased me and bit me hard, but it didn’t draw blood.
Sentence 2: The boxer landed just one punch and drew blood immediately.

Meaning 1: a wish or a dream which has become a reality.
Sentence 1: Going to Hawaii is like having a dream come true.
Sentence 2: Having you for a friend is a dream come true.

Meaning 1: dressed in one’s best clothes.
Sentence 1: The applicants for the job were all dressed up to the nines.
Sentence 2: The wedding party were dressed to the nines.

Meaning 1: a scolding.
Sentence 1: After that dressing down, I won’t be late again.
Sentence 2: The boss gave Fred a real dressing down for breaking the machine.

Meaning 1: to work hard to negotiate prices or agreements in one’s own favour.
Sentence 1: All right, sir, you drive a hard bargain. I’ll sell you this car for £12,450.
Sentence 2: You drive a hard bargain, Jane, but I’ll sign the contract.

Meaning 1: to annoy or irritate someone.
Sentence 1: Stop whistling that tune. You’re driving me up the wall.
Sentence 2: All his talk about moving to London nearly drove me up the wall.

Meaning 1: to announce shocking or startling news.
Sentence 1: They really dropped a bombshell when they announced that the president had cancer.
Sentence 2: Friday is a good day to drop a bombshell like that. It gives the business world the weekend to recover.

Meaning 1: to go back or remain back
Sentence 1: As the crowd moved forward, the weaker ones dropped back.
Sentence 2: She was winning the race at first, but soon dropped back.

Meaning 1: to stop or collapse from exhaustion
Sentence 1: If I keep working this way, I’ll drop in my tracks.
Sentence 2: Uncle Bob was working in the garden and dropped in his tracks. We are all sorry that he’s dead.

Meaning 1: to stop being friends with someone, especially with one’s boyfriend or girlfriend.
Sentence 1: Bob finally dropped Jane. I don’t know what he saw in her.
Sentence 2: I’m surprised that she didn’t drop him first.

Meaning 1: to try to forget one’s problems by drinking a lot of alcohol.
Sentence 1: Bill is in the bar drowning his sorrows.
Sentence 2: Jane is at home drowning her sorrows after losing her job.

Meaning 1: an attempt
Sentence 1: We had better have a dry run for the official ceremony tomorrow.
Sentence 2: The children will need a dry run before their procession in the pageant.

Meaning 1: someone who is very enthusiastic
Sentence 1: New volunteers are always eager beavers.
Sentence 2: The young assistant gets to work very early. She’s a real eager beaver.

Meaning 1: careful attention
Sentence 1: The pupils wrote their essays under the eagle eye of the headmaster.
Sentence 2: The umpire kept his eagle eye on the ball.

Meaning 1: someone who gets up or arrives early or starts something very promptly, especially someone who gains an advantage of some kind by so doing.
Sentence 1: The Smith family are early birds. They caught the first ferry.
Sentence 2: I was an early bird and got the best selection of flowers.

Meaning 1: to act very humbly, especially when one has been shown to be wrong
Sentence 1: I think I’m right, but if I’m wrong, I’ll eat humble pie.
Sentence 2: You think you’re so smart. I hope you have to eat humble pie.

Meaning 1: to eat only small amounts of food
Sentence 1: Jane is very slim because she eats like a bird.
Sentence 2: Bill is trying to lose weight by eating like a bird.

Meaning 1: to eat large amounts of food.
Sentence 1: No wonder he’s so fat. He eats like a horse.
Sentence 2: John works like a horse and eats like a horse, so he never gets fat.

Meaning 1: a phrase telling the kind of thing that one would do if a very unlikely event were actually to happen.
Sentence 1: I’ll eat my hat if you get a rise.
Sentence 2: He said he’d eat his hat if she got elected.

Meaning 1: to be very sad (about someone or something)
Meaning 2: to be envious (of someone or something).
Sentence 1: Bill spent a lot of time eating his heart out after his divorce.
Sentence 2: Sally ate her heart out when she had to sell her house.
Sentence 3: Do you like my new thirty six enter the lists watch? Well, eat your heart out. It was the last one in the shop.
Sentence 4: Eat your heart out, Jane! I’ve got a new girlfriend now.

Meaning 1: to have to take back one’s statements
Meaning 2: to confess that one’s predictions were wrong.
Sentence 1: You shouldn’t say that to me. I’ll make you eat your words.
Sentence 2: John was wrong about the election and had to eat his words.

Meaning 1: to do what someone else wants
Sentence 1: haveJust wait! I’ll have everyone eating out of my hands. They’ll do whatever I ask.
Sentence 2: The treasurer has everyone eating out of his hands.
Sentence 3: A lot of people are eating out of his hands.

Idioms: eat someone out of house and home
Meaning 1: to eat a lot of food (in someone’s home)
Meaning 2: to bring someone to the point of financial ruin by eating all the food in the person’s house.
Sentence 1: Billy has a huge appetite. He almost eats us out of house and home.
Sentence 2: When the young people come home from college, they always eat us out of house and home.

Meaning 1: either too much or not enough
Sentence 1: This month is very dry, and last month it rained almost every day. Our weather is either feast or famine.
Sentence 2: Sometimes we are busy, and sometimes we have nothing to do. It’s feast or famine.

Meaning 1: physical exertion
Meaning 2: hard work. (The “grease” may be the sweat that exertion produces.)
Sentence 1: It’ll take some elbow-grease to clean this car.
Sentence 2: Expensive polishes are all very well, but this floor needs elbow-grease.

Meaning 1: a decision made at the last possible minute.
Sentence 1: Eleventh-hour decisions are seldom satisfactory.
Sentence 2: The treasurer’s eleventh-hour decision was made in a great hurry, but it turned out to be correct.

Idioms: enough is as good as a feast
Meaning 1: a saying that means one should be satisfied if one has enough of something to meet one’s needs, and one should not seek more than one needs.
Sentence 1: We have enough money to live on, and enough is as good as a feast.
Sentence 2: I cannot understand why they want a larger house. Enough is as good as a feast.

Meaning 1: to begin to take part in a contest or argument.
Sentence 1: He had decided not to stand for Parliament but entered the lists atthe last minute.
Sentence 2: The family disagreement had almost been resolved when the grandfather entered the lists.

Meaning 1: to go unnoticed
Meaning 2: not to have been noticed. (Usually a way to point out that someone has failed to see or respond to something.)
Sentence 1: I suppose my earlier request escaped your notice, so I’m writing again.
Sentence 2: I’m sorry. Your letter escaped my notice.

Meaning 1: almost everything one can think of.
Sentence 1: When Sally went off to college, she took everything but the kitchen sink.
Sentence 2: When you take a baby on holiday, you have to pack everything but the kitchen sink.

Meaning 1: almost everything one can think of.
Sentence 1: She knows everything from A to Z about decorating.
Sentence 2: The biology exam covered everything from A to Z.

Meaning 1: frequently
Sentence 1: Somebody asks me for money every time I turn around.
Sentence 2: Something goes wrong with Bill’s car every time he turns around.

Meaning 1: everyone without discrimination
Sentence 1: The golf club is very exclusive. They don’t let any Tom, Dick, or Harry join.
Sentence 2: Mary’s sending out very few invitations. She doesn’t want every Tom, Dick, and Harry turning up.

Meaning 1: pregnant. (A euphemism.)
Sentence 1: Tommy’s mother is expecting a child.
Sentence 2: Oh, I didn’t know she was expecting.

Meaning 1: to express sympathy to someone. (A very polite and formal way to tell someone that you are sorry about a death in the family.)
Sentence 1: Please permit me to extend my sympathy to you and your children. I’m very sorry to hear of the death of your husband.
Sentence 2: Let’s extend our sympathy to Bill Jones, whose father died this week.

Meaning 1: person to person
Sentence 1: The discussions will have to be eyeball to eyeball to be effective.
Sentence 2: Tele- phone conversations are a waste of time. We need to talk eyeball to eyeball.

Meaning 1: to receive punishment
Meaning 2: to accept the unpleasant results of one’s actions.
Sentence 1: Mary broke a dining-room window and had to face the music when her father got home.
Sentence 2: After failing a maths test, Tom had to go home and face the music.

Meaning 1: outward appearance
Meaning 2: what something first appears to be. (From the value printed on the “face” of a coin or banknote.)
Sentence 1: Don’t just accept her offer at face value. Think of the implications.
Sentence 2: Joan tends to take people at face value, and so she is always getting hurt.

Meaning 1: a fair share of something
Meaning 2: a fair opportunity of doing something.
Sentence 1: He doesn’t want to do all the overtime. He only wants a fair crack of the whip.
Sentence 2: They were supposed to share the driving equally, but James refused to give Ann a fair crack of the whip.

Meaning 1: fair and just treatment [done to someone].
Sentence 1: It’s hardly fair do’s to treat her like that.
Sentence 2: It’s not a question of fair do’s. He treats everyone in the same way.

Meaning 1: someone or something that it is quite permissible to attack.
Sentence 1: I don’t like seeing articles exposing people’s private lives, but politicians are fair game.
Sentence 2: Journalists always regard film-stars as fair game.

Meaning 1: to laugh heartily.
Sentence 1: We fell about at the antics of the clown.
Sentence 2: The audience were falling about during the last act of the comedy.

Meaning 1: to break into pieces
Sentence 1: This old car is about ready to fall apart at the seams.
Sentence 2: The plan won’t succeed. It’s falling apart at the seams already.

Meaning 1: to come somewhere between two possibilities and so fail to meet the requirements of either.
Sentence 1: The material is not suitable for an academic book, and it is not suitable for a popular one either. It falls between two stools.
Sentence 2: He tries to be both teacher and friend but falls between two stools.

Meaning 1: to give up and quit before the end (of something)
Meaning 2: not to succeed. (As if one became exhausted and couldn’t finish a footrace.)
Sentence 1: John fell by the wayside and didn’t finish college.
Sentence 2: Many people start out to train for a career in medicine, but some of them fall by the wayside.

Meaning 1: to fail to do something properly
Meaning 2: to fail to do one’s job adequately.
Sentence 1: The team kept losing because the coach was falling down on the job.
Sentence 2: Tom was sacked because he fell down on the job.

Idioms: fall foul of someone or something
Meaning 1: to do something that annoys or offends someone or something
Meaning 2: to do something that is contrary to the rules.
Sentence 1: He has fallen foul of the police more than once.
Sentence 2: The political activists fell foul of the authorities.
Sentence 3: I hope I don’t fall foul of your sister. She doesn’t like me.
Sentence 4: John fell foul of the law.

Meaning 1: to cease to be held in favour, especially because of some wrong or foolish action.
Sentence 1: He was the teacher’s prize pupil until he fell from grace by failing the history exam.
Sentence 2: Mary was the favorite grandchild until she fell from grace by running away from home.

Meaning 1: to conform.
Sentence 1: If you are going to work here, you will have to fall into line.
Sentence 2: He likes to do as he pleases. He hates having to fall into line.

Meaning 1: to have confidence in someone’s [including one’s own] ability to be successful.
Sentence 1: We all think she will refuse to go out with him, but he certainly fancies his chances.
Sentence 2: The other contestants are so talented that I don’t fancy his chances at all.

Meaning 1: a thing which is very different from something else.
Sentence 1: What you did was a far cry from what you said you were The song they played was a far cry from what I call music.

Idioms: feast one’s eyes (on someone or something)
Meaning 1: to look at someone or something with pleasure, envy, or admiration.
Sentence 1: Just feast your eyes on that beautiful juicy steak!
Sentence 2: Yes, feast your eyes. You won’t see one like that again for a long time.

Meaning 1: an honour
Meaning 2: something of which one can be proud.
Sentence 1: Getting a new client was really a feather in my cap.
Sentence 2: It was certainly a feather in the journalist’s cap to get an interview with the president.

Meaning 1: to use power and prestige selfishly to provide for oneself, often immorally or illegally.
Sentence 1: The mayor seemed to be helping people, but was really feathering her own nest.
Sentence 2: The building contractor used a lot of public money to feather his nest.

Meaning 1: to feel well and healthy.
Sentence 1: If you want to feel fit, you must eat the proper food and get enough rest.
Sentence 2: I hope I still feel fit when I get old.

Idioms: feel it beneath one (to do something)
Meaning 1: to feel that one would be humbling oneself or reducing one’s status to do something.
Sentence 1: Tom feels it beneath him to scrub the floor.
Sentence 2: Ann feels it beneath her to carry her own luggage.
Sentence 3: I would do it, but I feel it beneath me.

Meaning 1: to feel well and healthy, both physically and mentally.
Sentence 1: A quick swim in the morning makes me feel like a million dollars.
Sentence 2: What a beautiful day! It makes you feel like a million dollars.

Meaning 1: to feel refreshed and renewed, especially after getting well or getting dressed up.
Sentence 1: I bought a new suit, and now I feel like a new person.
Sentence 2: Bob felt like a new person when he got out of the hospital.

Meaning 1: to sense something
Meaning 2: to have an intuition about something.
Sentence 1: The train will be late. I feel it in my bones.
Sentence 2: I failed the test. I feel it in my bones.

Meaning 1: to do nothing or something trivial while something disastrous happens. (From a legend that the emperor Nero played the lyre while Rome was burning.)
Sentence 1: The Opposition doesn’t seem to be doing anything to stop this terrible parliamentarybill. It’s fiddling while Rome burns.
Sentence 2: The doctor should have sent for an ambulance right away instead of examining her. He was just fiddling while Rome burned.

Meaning 1: a good possibility of success, especially if every effort is made.
Sentence 1: They have at least a fighting chance of winning the race.
Sentence 2: The patient could die, but he has a fighting chance since the operation.

Meaning 1: to avoid something
Sentence 1: She fought shy of borrowing money from her father but had to in the end.
Sentence 2: He’s always fought shy of marrying.

Meaning 1: to take the place of some other person and perform satisfactorily in that role. (As if you were wearing the other person’s shoes.)
Sentence 1: I don’t know how we’ll be able to do without you. No one can fill your shoes.
Sentence 2: It’ll be difficult to fill Jane’s shoes. She did her job very well.

Meaning 1: to be exactly the thing that is needed.
Sentence 1: Ah, this steak is great. It really fills the bill.
Sentence 2: This new pair of shoes fills the bill nicely.

Idioms: find it in one’s heart to do something
Meaning 1: to have the courage or compassion to do something
Meaning 2: to persuade oneself to do something.
Sentence 1: She couldn’t find it in her heart to refuse to come home to him.
Sentence 2: Could you really find it in your heart to send her away?

Meaning 1: to become used to a new situation or experience.
Sentence 1: She was lonely at first when she left home, but she is finding her feet now.
Sentence 2: It takes time to learn the office routine, but you will gradually find your feet.

Meaning 1: to find the position or rank to which one is best suited. (As water “seeks its own level.”)
Sentence 1: You cannot force junior staff to be ambitious. They will all find their own level.
Sentence 2: The new pupil is happier in the lower class. It was just a question of letting her find her own level.

Meaning 1: to be able to talk.
Sentence 1: Tom was speechless for a moment. Then he found his tongue.
Sentence 2: Ann was unable to find her tongue. She sat there in silence.

Meaning 1: a real mess
Sentence 1: The dog has eaten the steak we were going to have for dinner. This is a fine kettle of fish!

Meaning 1: a real mess
Sentence 1: This is a pretty kettle of fish. It’s below freezing outside, and the boiler won’t work.

Meaning 1: an unpleasant state of affairs.
Sentence 1: This is a fine state of affairs, and it’s all your fault.
Sentence 2: What a fine state of affairs you’ve got us into.

Meaning 1: to try to get someone to pay you a compliment.
Sentence 1: When she showed me her new dress, I could tell that she was fishing for a compliment.
Sentence 2: Tom was certainly fishing for compliments when he modelled his new haircut for his friends.

Meaning 1: to involve oneself in a difficult, confused, or dangerous situation, especially with a view to gaining an advantage.
Sentence 1: Frank is fishing in troubled waters by buying more shares in that firm. They are supposed to be in financial difficulties.
Sentence 2: The firm could make more money by selling armaments abroad, but they would be fishing in troubled waters.

Meaning 1: splendid
Sentence 1: What a delicious meal. It was fit for a king.
Sentence 2: Our room at the hotel was fit for a king.

Meaning 1: to succeed with difficulty in putting someone into a schedule.
Sentence 1: The doctor is busy, but I can try to fit you into the appointment book.
Sentence 2: Yes, here’s a free appointment. I can fit you in.
