Meaning 1: to arrange to provide some- one with something.
Sentence 1: We fixed John up with a room for the night.
Sentence 2: The usher fixed us up with seats at the front of the theatre.
Sentence 3: We thanked the usher for fixing us up.

Meaning 1: something that draws a lot of attention for a very brief time.
Sentence 1: I’m afraid that my success as a painter was just a flash in the pan.
Sentence 2: Tom had hoped to be a singer, but his career was only a flash in the pan.

Meaning 1: a severe scolding.
Sentence 1: I got a flea in my ear when I tried to give Pat some advice.
Sentence 2: Margaret was only trying to help the old lady, but she came away with a flea in her ear.

Meaning 1: a living human body, especially with reference to its natural limitations
Sentence 1: That’s no way to treat one’s own flesh and blood.
Sentence 2: I want to leave my money to my own flesh and blood.

Meaning 1: an idea or suggestion that is out of touch with reality or possibility.
Sentence 1: What is the point in indulging in flights of fancy about foreign holidays when you cannot even afford the rent?
Sentence 2: We are tired of her flights of fancy about marrying a millionaire.

Meaning 1: to try to continue discussing or arousing interest in something that already has been fully discussed or that is no longer of interest.
Sentence 1: Stop arguing! You have won your point. You are just flogging a dead horse.
Sentence 2: There’s no point in putting job-sharing on the agenda. We’ve already voted against it four times. Why flog a dead horse?

Meaning 1: to spread rumors or suggestions about something, such as a new project, in order to find out people’s attitudes to it.
Sentence 1: The government is flying a kite with these stories of a new airport.
Sentence 2: No official proposal has been made about redundancies. The management is flying a kite by dropping hints.

Meaning 1: irresponsible
Meaning 2: untrustworthy. (Refers to a person who sneaks away secretly in the night.)
Sentence 1: The carpenter we employed was a fly-by-night worker who did a very bad job of work.
Sentence 2: You shouldn’t deal with a fly-by-night merchant.

Meaning 1: a very short, often unexpected visit.
Sentence 1: She paid us a flying visit before leaving town.
Sentence 2: Very few people saw her in the office. It was just a flying visit.

Idioms: fly in the face of someone or something
Meaning 1: to disregard, defy, or show disrespect for someone or something.
Sentence 1: John loves to fly in the face of tradition.
Sentence 2: Ann made it a practice to fly in the face of standard procedures.

Meaning 1: a small, unpleasant matter which spoils some- thing
Sentence 1: We enjoyed the play, but the fly in the ointment was not being able to find our car afterwards.
Sentence 2: It sounds like a good idea, but there must be a fly in the ointment somewhere.

Meaning 1: to be very angry. (Related to a “mad dog”—a dog with rabies—which foams at the mouth.)
Sentence 1: Bob was furious foaming at the mouth. I’ve never seen anyone so angry.
Sentence 2: Bill foamed at the mouth in sheer rage.

Meaning 1: to act according to one’s feelings
Meaning 2: to obey one’s sympathetic or compassionate inclinations.
Sentence 1: I couldn’t decide what to do, so I just followed my heart.
Sentence 2: I trust that you will follow your heart in this matter.

Meaning 1: to go straight ahead, the direction in which one’s nose is pointing
Meaning 2: to follow a smell to its source.
Sentence 1: The town that you want is straight ahead on this motorway. Just follow your nose.
Sentence 2: The chief’s office is right around the corner. Turn left and follow your nose.
Sentence 3: The kitchen is at the back of the building. Just follow your nose.
Sentence 4: There was a bad smell in the basement

Meaning 1: to follow in the same pattern
Meaning 2: to follow someone else’s example. (From card-games.)
Sentence 1: Mary went to work for a bank, and Jane followed suit. Now they are both head cashiers.
Sentence 2: The Smiths went out to dinner, but the Browns didn’t follow suit. They ate at home.

Meaning 1: something to think about.
Sentence 1: I don’t like your idea very much, but it’s food for thought.
Sentence 2: Your lecture was very good. It contained much food for thought.

Meaning 1: a condition of apparent happiness that is based on false assumptions and will not last.
Sentence 1: They think they can live on love alone, but they are living in a fool’s paradise.
Sentence 2: The inhabitants of the island feel politically secure, but they are living in a fool’s paradise. They could be invaded at any time.

Idioms: fools rush in (where angels fear to tread)
Meaning 1: people with little experience or knowledge often get involved in difficult or delicate situations which wiser people would avoid.
Sentence 1: I wouldn’t ask Jean about her divorce, but Kate did. Fools rush in, as they say.
Sentence 2: Only the newest member of the committee questioned the chairman’s decision. Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.

Meaning 1: to pay the bill
Sentence 1: Let’s go out and eat. I’ll foot the bill.
Sentence 2: If the insurance firm goes bankrupt, don’t worry. The government will foot the bill.

Meaning 1: someone or something that one finds attractive or desirable partly because the person or thing is unobtainable. (From the fruit in the garden of Eden that was forbidden to Adam by God.)
Sentence 1: Jim is in love with his sister-in-law only because she’s forbidden fruit.
Sentence 2: The boy watches that programme only when his parents are out. It’s forbidden fruit.

Meaning 1: to force one to do something that one is unwilling to do or sooner than one wants to do it.(Refers to a handful of cards in card-playing)
Sentence 1: We didn’t know what she was doing until Tom forced her hand.
Sentence 2: The committee didn’t want to reveal their plans so soon, but we forced their hand.

Meaning 1: for many days without a break
Sentence 1: We kept on travelling for days on end.
Sentence 2: Doctor, I’ve had this pain for days on end.

Meaning 1: to forget one’s manners or training. (Said in formal situations in reference to bad table manners or bad taste.)
Sentence 1: Sorry, Mother, I forgot myself. I didn’t mean to use a swear-word.
Sentence 2: John, we are going out to dinner tonight. Please don’t forget yourself and gulp down your food.

Meaning 1: to forgive someone (for something) and forget that it ever happened.
Sentence 1: I’m sorry we quarreled, John. Let’s for- give and forget. What do you say?
Sentence 2: It was nothing. We’ll just have to forgive and forget.

Meaning 1: so that (one’s own version of) the facts will be known
Meaning 2: so, there will be a record of a particular fact.
Sentence 1: I’d like to say—for the record—that at no time have I ever accepted a bribe from anyone.
Sentence 2: For the record, I’ve never been able to get anything done around city hall without bribing someone.

Meaning 1: to harm one’s own interests
Sentence 1: He tried to discredit a fellow MP with the prime minister, but just succeeded in fouling his own nest.
Sentence 2: The boss really dislikes Mary. She certainly fouled her own nest when she spread those rumors about him.

Meaning 1: illegal activity
Sentence 1: The police investigating the death suspect foul play.
Sentence 2: Foul play cannot be ruled out.

Meaning 1: casual.
Sentence 1: John is so free and easy. How can anyone be so relaxed?
Sentence 2: Now, take it easy. Just act free and easy. No one will know you’re nervous.

Meaning 1: new places
Sentence 1: I used to like living here, but it’s fresh fields and pastures new for me now.
Sentence 2: Peter has decided to leave teaching. He’s looking for fresh fields and pastures new.
Sentence 3: It’s all very well to seek pastures new but think of the unemployment situation.

Meaning 1: from one place to another or to a series of other places.
Sentence 1: My father was in the army, and we moved from pillar to post, year after year.
Sentence 2: I went from pillar to post trying to find a telephone.

Sentence 1: This looks like a serious problem on the face of it. It probably is minor, however.
Sentence 2: On the face of it, it seems worthless.

Idioms: on the horns of a dilemma
Meaning 1: having to decide between two things, people, etc.
Sentence 1: Mary found herself on the horns of a dilemma. She didn’t know which dress to choose.
Sentence 2: I make up my mind easily. I’m not on the horns of a dilemma very often.

Meaning 1: running around free.
Sentence 1: Look out! There is a bear on the loose from the zoo.
Sentence 2: Most young people enjoy being on the loose when they go to college.

Meaning 1: getting well
Sentence 1: My cold was terrible, but I’m on the mend now.
Sentence 2: What you need is some hot chicken soup. Then you’ll really be on the mend.

Meaning 1: because of a slight possibility that something may happen, might be the case, etc.
Sentence 1: I went to the theatre on the offchance that there were tickets for the show left.
Sentence 2: We didn’t think we would get into the football ground, but we went on the offchance.

Meaning 1: slyly or sneakily.
Sentence 1: He was seeing Mrs. Smith on the sly.
Sentence 2: She was supposed to be losing weight, but she was eating chocolate on the sly.

Meaning 1: at exactly the right place
Meaning 2: in the place where one is needed
Sentence 1: Fortunately the ambulance men were on the spot when the accident happened at the football match.
Sentence 2: I expect the police to be on the spot when and where trouble arises.
Sentence 3: She liked the house so much that she bought it on the spot.
Sentence 4: He was fined on the spot for parking illegally.

Idioms: on the spur of the moment
Meaning 1: suddenly
Sentence 1: We decided to go on the spur of the moment.
Sentence 2: I went on holiday on the spur of the moment.

Meaning 1: because of the support of something, such as a promise or evidence
Sentence 1: On the strength of your comment, I decided to give John another chance.
Sentence 2: On the strength of my neighbour’s testimony, my case was dismissed.

Idioms: on the tip of one’s tongue
Meaning 1: about to be said
Sentence 1: I have his name right on the tip of my tongue. I’ll think of it in a second.
Sentence 2: John had the answer on the tip of his tongue, but Ann said it first.

Meaning 1: standing or walking on the front part of the feet (the balls of the feet) with no weight put on the heels. (This is done to gain height or to walk quietly.)
Sentence 1: I had to stand on tiptoe to see over the fence.
Sentence 2: I came in late and walked on tiptoe so I wouldn’t wake any- body up.

Meaning 1: to uncover a set of problems or complications
Sentence 1: If you start asking questions about the firm’s accounts, you’ll open a can of worms.
Sentence 2: How about clearing up this mess before you open up a new can of worms?

Meaning 1: something, usually a law case or problem, that is simple and straightforward without complications.
Sentence 1: The murder trial was an openandshut case. The defendant was caught with the murder weapon.
Sentence 2: Jack’s death was an openandshut case of suicide. He left a suicide note.

Meaning 1: someone or something that is easy to understand.
Sentence 1: Jane’s an open book. I always know what she is going to do next.
Sentence 2: The council’s intentions are an open book. They want to save money.

Meaning 1: to start (doing something, such as asking questions or criticizing).
Sentence 1: The reporters opened fire on the mayor.
Sentence 2: When the reporters opened fire, the filmstar was smiling, but not for long.
Sentence 3: The soldiers opened fire on the villagers.

Meaning 1: to reveal one’s most private thoughts to someone.
Sentence 1: I always open my heart to my wife when I have a problem.
Sentence 2: It’s a good idea to open your heart every now and then.

Meaning 1: to uncover a lot of unsuspected problems.
Sentence 1: When I asked Jane about her problems, I didn’t know I had opened Pandora’s box.
Sentence 2: You should be cautious with people who are upset. You don’t want to open Pandora’s box.

Meaning 1: unrestricted hunting of a particular game animal.
Sentence 1: It’s always open season for rabbits around here.
Sentence 2: Is it ever open season for deer?

Meaning 1: something which is supposed to be secret, but which is known to a great many people.
Sentence 1: Their engagement is an open secret. Only their friends are supposed to know, but in fact, the whole town knows.
Sentence 2: It’s an open secret that Fred’s looking for a new job.

Meaning 1: to permit or allow something to become a possibility.
Sentence 1: Your policy opens the door to cheating.
Sentence 2: Your statement opens the door to John’s candidacy.

Meaning 1: something necessary or usual at a certain time.
Sentence 1: Warm clothes are the order of the day when camping in the winter.
Sentence 2: Going to bed early was the order of the day when we were young.

Meaning 1: the reverse
Sentence 1: No, it won’t fit that way. Try it the other way round.
Sentence 2: It doesn’t make any sense like that. It belongs the other way round.

Meaning 1: out of working order
Sentence 1: My furnace is out of kilter. I have to call someone to fix it.
Sentence 2: This computer is out of kilter. It doesn’t work.

Meaning 1: improper
Sentence 1: I’m afraid that your behaviour was quite out of line. I do not wish to speak further about this matter.
Sentence 2: Bill, that remark was out of line. Please be more respectful.

Meaning 1: not properly lined up in a line of things
Meaning 2: unreasonable when compared with something else
Meaning 3: not fitting with what is usual.
Sentence 1: One of those books on the shelf is out of line with the others. Please fix it.
Sentence 2: The files are out of line also.
Sentence 3: The cost of this meal is out of line with what other restaurants charge.
Sentence 4: Your request is out of line with company policy.

Meaning 1: without good luck
Sentence 1: If you wanted some icecream, you’re out of luck.
Sentence 2: I was out of luck. I got there too late to get a seat.

Meaning 1: because of necessity
Sentence 1: I bought this hat out of necessity. I needed one, and this was all there was.
Sentence 2: We sold our car out of necessity.

Meaning 1: silly and senseless
Sentence 1: Why did you do that? You must be out of your mind!
Sentence 2: Good grief, Tom! You’re out of your mind!

Meaning 1: not in the correct order
Sentence 1: This book is out of order. Please put it in the right place on the shelf.
Sentence 2: You’re out of order, John. Please get in the queue after Jane.
Sentence 3: My question was declared out of order by the president.
Sentence 4: Ann inquired, “Isn’t a motion to table the question out of order at this time?”

Meaning 1: the actual amount of money spent. (Refers to the money one person pays while doing something on someone else’s behalf. One is usually paid back this money.)
Sentence 1: My outofpocket expenses for the party were nearly £175.
Sentence 2: My employer usually pays all outofpocket expenses for a business trip.

Meaning 1: performing poorly because of a lack of practice.
Sentence 1: I used to be able to play the piano extremely well, but now I’m out of practice.
Sentence 2: The players lost the game because they were out of practice.

Meaning 1: no longer available for sale. (Said of a book or periodical.)
Sentence 1: The book you want is out of print, but perhaps I can find a used copy for you.
Sentence 2: It was published nearly ten years ago, so it’s probably out of print.

Meaning 1: not now available for sale
Meaning 2: not now legally able to be hunted or caught.
Sentence 1: Sorry, oysters are out of season. We don’t have any.
Sentence 2: Watermelon is out of season in the winter.
Sentence 3: Are salmon out of season?
Sentence 4: I caught a trout out of season and had to pay a fine.

Meaning 1: not now operating.
Sentence 1: Both lifts are out of service, so I had to use the stairs.
Sentence 2: The toilet is temporarily out of service.

Meaning 1: not feeling well
Sentence 1: I’ve been out of sorts for a day or two. I think I’m coming down with flu.
Sentence 2: The baby is out of sorts. Maybe she’s cutting a tooth.

Meaning 1: not immediately available in a shop
Sentence 1: Those items are out of stock, but a new supply will be delivered on Thursday.
Sentence 2: I’m sorry, but the red ones are out of stock. Would a blue one do?

Meaning 1: suddenly
Sentence 1: Then, out of the blue, he told me he was leaving.
Sentence 2: Mary appeared on my doorstep out of the blue.

Idioms: out of the corner of one’s eye
Meaning 1: [seeing something] at a glance
Sentence 1: I saw someone do it out of the corner of my eye. It might have been Jane who did it.
Sentence 2: I only saw the accident out of the corner of my eye. I don’t know who is at fault.

Idioms: out of the frying-pan into the fire
Meaning 1: from a bad situation to a worse situation.
Sentence 1: When I tried to argue about my fine for a traffic viola- tion, the judge charged me with contempt of court. I really went out of the fryingpan into the fire.
Sentence 2: I got deeply in debt. Then I really got out of the frying-pan into the fire when I lost my job.

Meaning 1: not possible
Sentence 1: I’m sorry, but leaving early is out of the question.
Sentence 2: You can’t go to France this spring. We can’t afford it. It’s out of the question.

Meaning 1: no longer being considered
Sentence 1: After the first part of the diving competition, three of our team were out of the running.
Sentence 2: After the scandal was made public, I was no longer in the running. I pulled out of the election.

Idioms: out of the swim of things
Meaning 1: not in the middle of activity
Sentence 1: While I had my cold, I was out of the swim of things.
Sentence 2: I’ve been out of the swim of things for a few weeks. Please bring me up to date.

Meaning 1: past a critical phase
Sentence 1: When the patient got out of the woods, everyone relaxed.
Sentence 2: I can give you a better prediction for your future health when you are out of the woods.

Meaning 1: out of nowhere
Sentence 1: Suddenly, out of thin air, the messenger appeared.
Sentence 2: You just made that up out of thin air.

Meaning 1: wonderful
Sentence 1: This pie is just out of this world.
Sentence 2: Look at you! How lovely you look, simply out of this world.

Meaning 1: not at the proper time
Sentence 1: We were permitted to be served out of turn, because we had to leave early.
Sentence 2: Bill tried to register out of turn and was sent away.

Meaning 1: unemployed, temporarily or permanently.
Sentence 1: How long have you been out of work?
Sentence 2: My brother has been out of work for nearly a year.

Meaning 1: [in or into a situation of] doing something differently from the way others do it, and thus taking a chance or a risk.
Sentence 1: She really went out on a limb when she gave him permission to leave early.
Sentence 2: As the only one who supported the plan, Bill was out on a limb.

Meaning 1: out of jail but still under police supervision.
Sentence 1: Bob got out on parole after serving only a few years of his sentence.
Sentence 2: He was out on parole because of good behaviour.

Meaning 1: finished.
Sentence 1: I’m glad that’s over and done with.
Sentence 2: Now that I have college over and done with, I can find a job.

Meaning 1: not if I can stop you
Meaning 2: you’ll have to kill me first (so that I won’t stop you).
Sentence 1: You’ll sell this house over my dead body!
Sentence 2: You want to leave college? Over my dead body!

Meaning 1: over age
Sentence 1: Now that Mary’s forty, she thinks she’s over the hill.
Sentence 2: My grandfather was over eighty before he felt he was over the hill.

Meaning 1: over the difficult part.
Sentence 1: This is a difficult project, but we’re over the hump now.
Sentence 2: I’m halfway through, over the hump, and it looks as though I may finish after all.

Meaning 1: more than one would expect to pay. (From betting in horseracing.)
Sentence 1: We had to pay over the odds for a house in the area where we wanted to live.
Sentence 2: It’s a nice car, but the owner’s asking well over the odds for it.

Meaning 1: to do something in an exaggerated or excessive way
Sentence 1: Jane really went over the top with the dinner she prepared for us. It took her hours to prepare.
Sentence 2: Uncle Jack went completely over the top when he bought my baby’s present. It must have been incredibly expensive.

Meaning 1: very crowded
Meaning 2: containing as many people as possible.
Sentence 1: The theatre was packed out.
Sentence 2: The cinema was packed out twenty minutes before we arrived.

Meaning 1: to send someone away to somewhere, often with the suggestion that one is glad to do so.
Sentence 1: His parents packed him off to boarding-school as soon as possible.
Sentence 2: John finally has left for France. We packed him off last week.

Meaning 1: to draw a lot of people.
Sentence 1: It was a good night at the theatre. The play really packed them in.
Sentence 2: The circus manager knew he could pack them in if he advertised the lion tamer.

Meaning 1: to do (something) by oneself
Sentence 1: I’ve been left to paddle my own canoe since I was a child.
Sentence 2: Sally didn’t stay with the group. She wanted to paddle her own canoe.

Meaning 1: a bother
Sentence 1: This assign- ment is a pain in the neck.
Sentence 2: Your little brother is a pain in the neck.

Meaning 1: looking sick.
Sentence 1: John is looking a little pale around the gills. What’s wrong?

Meaning 1: to try to hide faults or difficulties, often in a hasty or not very successful way.
Sentence 1: The politician tried to paper over the cracks in his party’s economic policy.
Sentence 2: Tom tried to paper over the cracks in his relationship with the boss, but it was not possible.

Meaning 1: typical
Meaning 2: about what one could expect. (This refers to a golf course.)
Sentence 1: So he went off and left you? Well, that’s about par for the course. He’s no friend.
Sentence 2: I worked for days on this project, but it was rejected. That’s par for the course around here.

Meaning 1: without understanding the meaning of what one has learnt, is saying, etc.
Sentence 1: The child learnt the poem by heart and repeated it parrotfashion.
Sentence 2: Jean never thinks for herself. She just repeats what her father says, parrot-fashion.

Meaning 1: an essential part of something
Meaning 2: something that is unavoidably included as part of something else.
Sentence 1: This point is part and parcel of my whole argument.
Sentence 2: Bill refused to accept pain and illness as part and parcel of growing older.

Meaning 1: a point at which people separate and go their own ways.
Sentence 1: Jane and Bob finally came to a parting of the ways and divorced.
Sentence 2: Bill and his parents reached a parting of the ways and he left home.

Meaning 1: the official ideas and attitudes which are adopted by the leaders of a particular group, usually political, and which the other members are expected to accept.
Sentence 1: Tom has left the club. He refused to follow the party line.
Sentence 2: Many politicians agree with the party line without thinking.

Meaning 1: to succeed in being accepted as someone or something.
Sentence 1: The spy was able to pass as a normal citizen.
Sentence 2: The thief was arrested when he tried to pass as a priest.

Meaning 1: to measure up to the required standards.
Sentence 1: I tried my best, but my efforts didn’t pass muster.
Sentence 2: If you don’t wear a suit, you won’t pass muster at that expensive restaurant. They won’t let you in.

Meaning 1: to pass the blame (to someone else)
Meaning 2: to give the responsibility (to someone else).
Sentence 1: Don’t try to pass the buck! It’s your fault, and everybody knows it.
Sentence 2: Some people try to pass the buck whenever they can. They won’t accept responsibility.

Meaning 1: to attempt to collect money for some (charitable) project.
Sentence 1: Bob is passing the hat round to collect money to buy flowers for Ann.
Sentence 2: He’s always passing the hat round for something.

Idioms: pass the time of day (with someone)
Meaning 1: to chat or talk informally with someone.
Sentence 1: I saw Mr. Brown in town yesterday. I stopped and passed the time of day with him.
Sentence 2: No, we didn’t have a serious talk; we just passed the time of day.

Meaning 1: less good or efficient now than someone or something was before.
Sentence 1: This cooker’s past its sellby date. We’ll have to get a new one.

Meaning 1: less good or efficient now than someone or something was before.
Sentence 1: Joan was a wonderful singer, but she’s past her best now.
Sentence 2: This old car’s past it. I’ll need to get a new one.

Idioms: past someone’s or something’s sell-by date
Meaning 1: less good or efficient now than someone or something was before.
Sentence 1: Mary feels she’s past her sell-by date when she sees so many young women joining the company.

Idioms: pay an arm and a leg (for something)
Meaning 1: to pay too much money for something.
Sentence 1: I hate to have to pay an arm and a leg for a tank of petrol.
Sentence 2: If you shop around, you won’t have to pay an arm and a leg.

Idioms: cost an arm and a leg
Meaning 1: to cost too much.
Sentence 1: It cost an arm and a leg, so I didn’t buy it.

Meaning 1: to express loyalty, respect, or support for something insincerely
Sentence 1: You don’t really care about politics. You’re just paying lip service to the candidateThe students pay lip-service to the new rules, but they plan to ignore them in practice.

Meaning 1: to serve a sentence for a crime, usually in prison.
Sentence 1: The judge said that Mr. Simpson had to pay his debt to society.
Sentence 2: Mr. Brown paid his debt to society in prison.

Meaning 1: to pay the fees required to belong to an organization.
Sentence 1: If you haven’t paid your dues, you can’t come to the club picnic.
Sentence 2: How many people have paid their dues?

Idioms: pay someone a back handed compliment
Meaning 1: to give someone an apparent compliment that is really an insult.
Sentence 1: John said that he had never seen me looking better. I think he was paying me a back- handed compliment.
Sentence 2: I’d prefer that someone insulted me directly. I hate it when someone pays me a back-handed compliment, unless it’s a joke.

Meaning 1: to compliment someone.
Sentence 1: Sally thanked me for paying her a compliment.
Sentence 2: When Tom did his job well, I paid him a compliment.

Meaning 1: to pay a great deal of money for something.
Sentence 1: Bob paid the earth for that ugly old sideboard.
Sentence 2: You have to pay the earth for property in that area.

Meaning 1: to provide the money for something and so have some control over how the money is spent. (From the expression “He who pays the piper calls the tune.”)
Sentence 1: The parents at a fee-paying school pay the piper and so should have a say in how the school is run.
Sentence 2: Hotel guests pay the piper and should be treated politely.

Meaning 1: to choose very carefully from a number of possibilities
Sentence 1: You must take what you are given. You can- not pick and choose.
Sentence 2: Meg is so beautiful. She can pick and choose from a whole range of suitors.

Meaning 1: to start an argument with someone
Sentence 1: Are you trying to pick a quarrel with me?
Sentence 2: No, I’m not trying to pick a quarrel.

Meaning 1: to criticize something severely
Meaning 2: to find all the flaws or fallacies in an argument.
Sentence 1: The solicitor picked holes in the witness’s story.
Sentence 2: They will pick holes in your argument.

Meaning 1: to criticize someone or something constantly
Sentence 1: Stop picking on me!
Sentence 2: Why are you always picking on the office junior?

Meaning 1: something very easy.
Sentence 1: No, it won’t be any trouble. It’s a piece of cake.
Sentence 2: Climbing this is easy! Look here, a piece of cake.

Meaning 1: a supposed future reward which one is not likely to get. (From “You’ll get pie in the sky when you die,” a line from a song by U.S. radical labour organizer Joe Hill.)
Sentence 1: The firm have promised him a large reward, but I think it’s just pie in the sky.
Sentence 2: Don’t hold out for a big reward, you know—pie in the sky.

Meaning 1: a person who is in a position between two opposing groups.
Sentence 1: Jack and Tom share a secretary who is always piginthemiddle because they are always disagreeing with each other.
Sentence 2: Fred’s mother is piggyinthemiddle when Fred and his father start to argue. She tries to please both of them.

Meaning 1: a saying indicating that something is extremely unlikely to happen.
Sentence 1: Pam might marry Tom, but there again, pigs might fly.
Sentence 2: Do you really believe that Jack will lend us his car? Yes, and pigs might fly.

Meaning 1: to climb in or get in roughly.
Sentence 1: Okay, children, pile in!
Sentence 2: The children piled into the car and slammed the door.

Meaning 1: to live on very little money, sometimes to save money.
Sentence 1: Bob has to pinch and scrape all the time because of his low wages.
Sentence 2: Students have to pinch and scrape to buy books.

Idioms: pin one’s faith on someone or something
Meaning 1: to put one’s hope, trust, or faith in someone or something.
Sentence 1: I’m pinning my faith on your efforts.
Sentence 2: Don’t pin your faith on Tom. He’s not dependable.

Meaning 1: a tingling feeling in some part of one’s body.
Sentence 1: I’ve got pins and needles in my legs.
Sentence 2: Mary gets pins and needles if she crosses her arms for long.

Meaning 1: to be quiet
Sentence 1: Okay, you lot, pipe down!
Sentence 2: I’ve heard enough from you. Pipe down!

Meaning 1: a wish or an idea which is impossible to achieve or carry out. (From the dreams or visions induced by the smoking of an opium pipe.)
Sentence 1: Going to the West Indies is a pipedream. We’ll never have enough money.
Sentence 2: Your hopes of winning a lot of money are just a silly pipedream.

Meaning 1: beaten in the final stages of a race or competition
Meaning 2: defeated in some activity at the last minute.
Sentence 1: Tom led the race for most of the time, but he was pipped at the post by his rival.
Sentence 2: Jane nearly bought that house, but she was pipped at the post by the present owner.

Meaning 1: to get busy and help (with something).
Sentence 1: Pick up a paintbrush and pitch in and help.
Sentence 2: Why don’t some of you pitch in? We need all the help we can get.

Idioms: pit someone or something against someone or something
Meaning 1: to set someone or something in opposition to someone or something.
Sentence 1: The rules of the tournament pit their team against ours.
Sentence 2: John pitted Mary against Sally in the tennis match.
Sentence 3: In the illegal dog fight, large dogs were pitted against small ones.

Meaning 1: [for one] to scheme in a way that pits two sides against each other (for one’s own gain).
Sentence 1: I told my brother that Mary doesn’t like him. Then I told Mary that my brother doesn’t like her. They broke up, so now I can have the car this weekend. I succeeded in playing both ends against the middle.
Sentence 2: If you try to play both ends against the middle, you’re likely to get in trouble with both sides.

Meaning 1: to capture and release someone over and over
Meaning 2: to treat a person in one’s control in such a way that the person does not know what is going to happen next.
Sentence 1: The police played cat and mouse with the suspect until they had sufficient evidence to make an arrest.
Sentence 2: Tom has been playing cat and mouse with Ann. Finally she got tired of it and broke up with him.

Meaning 1: to put forward arguments against or objections to a proposition, which one may actually agree with purely to test the validity of the proposition. (The devil’s advocate was given the role of opposing the canonization of a saint in the mediaeval Church to prove that the grounds for canonization were sound.)
Sentence 1: I agree with your plan. I’m just playing devil’s advocate so you’ll know what the opposition will say.
Sentence 2: Mary offered to play devil’s advocate and argue against our case so that we would find out any flaws in it.

Meaning 1: no longer of interest or influence.
Sentence 1: Jane’s political ideas are all played out.
Sentence 2: That particular religious sect is played out now.

Meaning 1: to do something by the rules or in a fair and just manner.
Sentence 1: John won’t do business with Bill any more because Bill doesn’t play fair.
Sentence 2: You moved the golf ball with your foot! That’s not playing fair!

Idioms: play fast and loose (with someone or something)
Meaning 1: to act carelessly, thoughtlessly, and irresponsibly.
Sentence 1: I’m tired of your playing fast and loose with me. Leave me alone.
Sentence 2: Bob played fast and loose with Sally’s affections.

Meaning 1: to be with two lovers who wish to be alone.
Sentence 1: I’m not going to the cinema with Tom and Jean. I hate playing gooseberry.
Sentence 2: Come on! Let’s go home! Bob and Mary don’t want us playing gooseberry.

Meaning 1: to be coy and excessively shy
Meaning 2: to make it difficult for someone to talk to one or be friendly.
Sentence 1: Why can’t we go out? Why do you play hard to get?
Sentence 2: Sally annoys all the boys because she plays hard to get.

Idioms: play havoc with someone or something
Meaning 1: to cause a lot of damage to something
Sentence 1: The road-works played havoc with the traffic.
Sentence 2: A new baby can play havoc with one’s household routine.

Meaning 1: to do exactly what an opponent wants one to do, without one realizing it
Meaning 2: to assist someone in a scheme without realizing it.
Sentence 1: John is doing exactly what I hoped he would. He’s playing into my hands.
Sentence 2: John played into my hands by taking the coins he found in my desk. I caught him and had him arrested.

Idioms: play one’s cards close to one’s chest
Meaning 1: to work or negotiate in a careful and private manner.
Sentence 1: It’s hard to figure out what John is up to because he plays his cards close to his chest.

Meaning 1: to work or negotiate correctly and skilfully.
Sentence 1: If you play your cards right, you can get whatever you want.
Sentence 2: She didn’t play her cards right, so she didn’t get promotion.

Meaning 1: to use one’s most powerful or effective strategy or device.
Sentence 1: I won’t play my trump card until I have tried every- thing else.
Sentence 2: I thought that the whole situation was hopeless until Mary played her trump card and told us her uncle would lend us the money.

Meaning 1: to make use of something for one’s own ends
Meaning 3: to manage something for a desired effect.
Sentence 1: The shop assistant played on my sense of responsibility in trying to get me to buy the book.
Sentence 2: See if you can get her to confess by playing upon her sense of guilt.

Meaning 1: to allow political concerns to dominate in matters where principles should prevail.
Sentence 1: Look, I came here to discuss this trial, not play politics.
Sentence 2: They’re not making reasonable decisions. They’re playing politics.

Meaning 1: to pretend to be inactive, unobserved, asleep, or dead.
Sentence 1: I knew that Bob wasn’t asleep. He was just playing possum.
Sentence 2: I can’t tell if this animal is dead or just playing possum.

Meaning 1: not to take risks
Meaning 2: to act in a safe manner.
Sentence 1: You should play safe and take your umbrella.
Sentence 2: If you have a cold or the flu, play safe and go to bed.

Meaning 1: to be in a subordinate position to someone.
Sentence 1: I’m tired of playing second fiddle to John.
Sentence 2: I’m better trained than he is, and I have more experience. I shouldn’t play second fiddle.

Meaning 1: to date many different people rather than going steady with just one.
Sentence 1: Tom wanted to play the field, so he said goodbye to Ann.
Sentence 2: He said he wanted to play the field rather than get married while he was still young.

Meaning 1: to act in a silly manner play safe to amuse other people.
Sentence 1: The teacher told Tom to stop playing the fool and sit down.
Sentence 2: Fred likes playing the fool, but we didn’t find him funny last night.

Meaning 1: to behave or act in a fair and honest way.
Sentence 1: You shouldn’t try to disturb your opponent’s concentration. That’s not play- ing the game.
Sentence 2: Listening to other people’s phone calls is certainly not playing the game.

Meaning 1: to invest in the shares market. (As if it were a game or as if it were gambling.)
Sentence 1: Would you rather put your money in the bank or play the market?
Sentence 2: I’ve learned my lesson playing the mar- ket. I lost a fortune.

Meaning 1: to perform in a manner that will get the strong approval of the audience
Meaning 2: to perform in a manner that will get the approval of the less sophisticated members of the audience.
Sentence 1: John is a competent actor, but he has a tendency to play to the gallery.
Sentence 2: When he made the rude remark, he was just playing to the gallery. He wanted others to find him amusing.

Meaning 1: to trick or confuse someone.
Sentence 1: I thought I saw a camel over there. I think that my eyes are playing tricks on me.
Sentence 2: Please don’t play tricks on your little brother. It makes him cry.

Meaning 1: to cause trouble
Sentence 1: My leg is playing up. It really aches.
Sentence 2: Her arthritis always plays up in this cold, damp weather.

Meaning 1: to annoy someone.
Sentence 1: That child played me up. He was naughty all day.
Sentence 2: The pupils played the substitute teacher up the entire day.

Meaning 1: to try to gain someone’s favour
Meaning 3: to flatter someone or to pretend to admire someone to gain favour.
Sentence 1: Bill is always playing up to the teacher.
Sentence 2: Ann played up to Bill as if she wanted him to marry her.

Meaning 1: to do something very risky or dangerous.
Sentence 1: The teacher was playing with fire by threatening a pupil.
Sentence 2: I wouldn’t talk to Bob that way if I were you—unless you like playing with fire.

Meaning 1: to increase one’s courage a bit
Meaning 2: to become brave enough to do something.
Sentence 1: Come on, Ann, make the dive. Pluck up your courage and do it.
Sentence 2: Fred plucked up courage and asked Jean for a date.

Meaning 1: the appropriate but chance receiving of rewards or punishments by those deserving them.
Sentence 1: It was poetic justice that Jane won the race after Mary tried to get her banned.
Sentence 2: The car rob- bers stole a car with no petrol. That’s poetic justice.

Meaning 1: to blame someone
Meaning 2: to identify some- one as the guilty person.
Sentence 1: Don’t point the finger at me! I didn’t take the money.
Sentence 2: The manager refused to point the finger at anyone in par- ticular and said the whole staff were sometimes guilty of being late.

Meaning 1: to make fun of someone
Sentence 1: Stop poking fun at me! It’s not nice.
Sentence 2: Bob is always poking fun.

Meaning 1: [the instance of] someone with a fault accusing someone else of having the same fault.
Sentence 1: Ann is always late, but she was rude enough to tell everyone when I was late. Now that’s the pot calling the kettle black!
Sentence 2: You’re calling me thoughtless? That’s really a case of the pot calling the kettle black.

Meaning 1: considering the amount of money involved
Meaning 2: considering the cost. (Often seen in advertising.)
Sentence 1: Pound for pound, you cannot buy a better car.
Sentence 2: Pound for pound, this detergent washes cleaner and brighter than any other product on the market.

Meaning 1: to walk through the streets looking for a job.
Sentence 1: I spent two months pounding the streets after the fac- tory I worked for closed.
Sentence 2: Look, Bob. You’d better get on with your work unless you want to be out pounding the streets.

Meaning 1: to discourage doing something
Sentence 1: When my father said I couldn’t have the car, he poured cold water on my plans.

Meaning 1: to discourage doing something
Sentence 1: John threw cold water on the whole project and refused to participate.

Meaning 1: to waste money
Sentence 1: What a waste! You’re just pouring money down the drain.
Sentence 2: Don’t buy any more of that low-quality material. That’s just pouring money down the drain.

Meaning 1: to calm things down. (If oil is poured on to rough seas during a storm, the water will become more calm.)
Sentence 1: That was a good thing to say to John. It helped to pour oil on trou- bled waters. Now he looks happy.
Sentence 2: Bob is the kind of person who always pours oil on troubled waters.

Meaning 1: the person who controls the one who is apparently in charge.
Sentence 1: Mr. Smith appears to run the shop, but his brother is the power behind the throne.
Sentence 2: They say that the mayor’s husband is the power behind the throne.

Meaning 1: the people who are in authority.
Sentence 1: The powers that be have decided to send back the immigrants.
Sentence 2: I have applied for a licence, and the powers that be are considering my application.

Meaning 1: to do what you advise other people to do.
Sentence 1: If you’d practise what you preach, you’d be better off.
Sentence 2: You give good advice. Why not practise what you preach?

Idioms: praise someone or something to the skies
Meaning 1: to give someone much praise.
Sentence 1: He wasn’t very good, but his friends praised him to the skies.
Sentence 2: They liked your pie. Everyone praised it to the skies.

Meaning 1: to praise or recommend something to someone who is already in favour of it.
Sentence 1: Mary was preaching to the converted when she tried to persuade Jean to become a feminist. She’s been one for years.
Sentence 2: Bob found himself preaching to the con- verted when he was telling Jane the advantages of living in the coun- try. She hates city life.

Meaning 1: calmness and the ability to act sensibly in an emergency or difficult situation.
Sentence 1: Jane had the presence of mind to phone the police when the child disappeared.
Sentence 2: The child had the pres- ence of mind to take a note of the car’s number-plate.

Idioms: press gang someone into doing something
Meaning 1: to force someone into doing something.
Sentence 1: Aunt Jane press-ganged me into helping with the church fête.
Sentence 2: The boss press- ganged us all into working late.

Meaning 1: to listen more closely.
Sentence 1: At the sound of my voice, my dog pricked up her ears.
Sentence 2: I pricked up my ears when I heard my name mentioned.

Meaning 1: the best or most important place or space.
Sentence 1: Jack’s parents gave pride of place in their living-room to his sports trophy.
Sentence 2: The art gallery promised to give pride of place to Mary’s painting of the harbour.

Meaning 1: to take special pride in something.
Sentence 1: Ann prides herself on her apple pies.
Sentence 2: John prides himself on his ability to make people feel at ease.

Meaning 1: the force that sets something going
Meaning 2: someone or something that starts something off.
Sentence 1: The assistant manager was the prime mover in getting the manager sacked.
Sentence 2: Discontent with his job was the prime mover in John’s deciding to emigrate.

Meaning 1: to twist one’s face into a strange expression, typically to show one’s dislike, to express ridicule, or to make someone laugh.
Sentence 1: The comedian pulled faces to amuse the children.

Meaning 1: to succeed in an act of deception.
Sentence 1: She was pulling a fast one when she said she had a headache and had to go home.
Sentence 2: Don’t try to pull a fast one with me! I know what you’re doing.

Meaning 1: to become calm or steady
Sentence 1: Now, calm down. Pull yourself together.
Sentence 2: I’ll be all right as soon as I can pull myself together. I just can’t stop weeping.

Idioms: pull oneself up by one’s bootstraps
Meaning 1: to achieve (something) through one’s own efforts.
Sentence 1: He’s wealthy now, but he pulled himself up by his bootstraps.
Sentence 2: The orphan pulled himself up by his bootstraps to become a doctor.

Meaning 1: [for a boxer] to strike with light blows to enable the other boxer to win
Meaning 2: to hold back in one’s criticism or attack.
Sentence 1: Bill has been barred from the boxing ring for pulling his punches.
Sentence 2: “I never pulled my punches in my life!” cried Tom.
Sentence 3: I didn’t pull any punches. I told her just what I thought of her.
Sentence 4: The teacher doesn’t pull any punches when it comes to discipline.

Meaning 1: to make an effort to improve one’s behaviour or performance.
Sentence 1: If you don’t want to be expelled from school, you’ll have to pull your socks up.
Sentence 2: The firm will have to pull its socks up in order to stay in business.

Meaning 1: to use all one’s energy and effort in order to achieve something. (From the stops of a pipe-organ. The more that are pulled out, the louder it gets.)
Sentence 1: You’ll have to pull out all the stops if you’re going to pass the exam.
Sentence 2: The doctors will pull out all the stops to save the child’s life.

Meaning 1: to kid, fool, or trick someone.
Sentence 1: You don’t mean that. You’re just pulling my leg.
Sentence 2: Don’t believe him. He’s just pulling your leg.

Idioms: pull something out of a hat
Meaning 1: to produce something as if by magic.
Sentence 1: This is a serious prob- lem, and we just can’t pull a solution out of a hat.

Idioms: pull something out of thin air
Meaning 1: to produce something as if by magic.
Sentence 1: I’m sorry, but I don’t have a pen. What do you want me to do, pull one out of thin air?

Meaning 1: to use influence (with someone to get something done or gain an advantage).
Sentence 1: I can borrow the hall easily by pulling strings.
Sentence 2: Is it possible to get anything done around here without pulling strings?

Idioms: pull the rug out from under someone’s feet
Meaning 1: to do something suddenly which leaves someone in a weak position
Sentence 1: The news that his wife had left him pulled the rug out from under him.
Sentence 2: The boss certainly pulled the rug out from under Bob’s feet when he lowered his salary.

Idioms: pull the wool over someone’s eyes
Meaning 1: to deceive someone.
Sentence 1: You can’t pull the wool over my eyes. I know what’s going on.
Sentence 2: Don’t try to pull the wool over her eyes. She’s too smart.

Meaning 1: to expect continued good fortune
Meaning 2: to expect to continue to escape bad luck.
Sentence 1: You’re okay so far, but don’t push your luck.
Sentence 2: Bob pushed his luck once too often when he tried to flirt with the new secretary. She slapped him.

Idioms: put a brave face on it
Meaning 1: to try to appear happy or satisfied when faced with misfortune or danger.
Sentence 1: We’ve lost all our money, but we must put a brave face on it for the sake of the children.
Sentence 2: Jim’s lost his job and is worried, but he’s putting a brave face on it.

Idioms: put all one’s eggs in one basket
Meaning 1: to risk everything at once
Meaning 2: to depend entirely on one plan, venture, etc. (Often negative.)
Sentence 1: Don’t put all your eggs in one basket. You shouldn’t invest all your money in one business.
Sentence 2: John only applied to the one college he wanted to go to. He put all his eggs in one basket.

Meaning 1: to suggest something, usually something that is bad or unfortunate for someone or to someone (who would not have thought of it otherwise).
Sentence 1: Jack can’t afford a holiday abroad. Please don’t put ideas into his head.
Sentence 2: Bob would get along all right if his chums didn’t put ideas into his head.

Idioms: put in a good word for someone
Meaning 1: to say something to someone in support of someone.
Sentence 1: I hope you get the job. I’ll put in a good word for you.
Sentence 2: You might get the part in the film if Mike puts in a good word for you.

Meaning 1: to pretend
Meaning 2: to act as if something were true.
Sentence 1: Ann wasn’t really angry. She was just putting it on.
Sentence 2: I can’t believe she was just putting it on. She really looked mad.

Meaning 1: to act superior.
Sentence 1: Stop putting on airs. You’re just human like the rest of us.
Sentence 2: Ann is always putting on airs. You’d think she was a queen.

Meaning 1: to deceive or trick someone.
Sentence 1: He tried to put one across the old lady by pretending to be her long- lost nephew.
Sentence 2: Meg thought she’d put one across her parents by claim- ing to spend the night at her friend’s house.

Meaning 1: to rebuke someone
Meaning 2: to remind one of one’s (lower) rank or station.
Sentence 1: My employer put me in my place for criticizing her.
Sentence 2: Lady Jane put the butler in his place when he grew too familiar.

Meaning 1: to prepare to do one’s best
Meaning 2: to make the best attempt possible to make a good impression.
Sentence 1: When you apply for a position, you should always put your best foot forward.
Sentence 2: Since you failed last time, you must put your best foot forward now.

Meaning 1: to be adamant about something.
Sentence 1: Ann put her foot down about what kind of car she wanted.
Sentence 2: She doesn’t put her foot down very often, but when she does, she really means it.

Meaning 1: to say something which one regrets
Meaning 2: to say something tactless, insulting, or hurtful.
Sentence 1: When I told Ann that her hair was more beautiful than I had ever seen it, I really put my foot in it. It was a wig.
Sentence 2: I put my foot in it by mistaking John’s girlfriend for his wife.

Idioms: put one’s hand to the plough
Meaning 1: to begin to do a big and important task
Sentence 1: If John would only put his hand to the plough, he could do an excellent job of work.
Sentence 2: You’ll never accomplish anything if you don’t put your hand to the plough.

Meaning 1: to put one’s business or personal affairs into good order.
Sentence 1: There was some trouble at work and the manager was told to put his house in order.
Sentence 2: Every now and then, I have to put my house in order. Then life becomes more manageable.

Meaning 1: to interfere by giving unasked for advice.
Sentence 1: You don’t need to put your oar in. I don’t need your advice.

Idioms: put one’s shoulder to the wheel
Meaning 1: to take up a task
Sentence 1: You won’t accomplish anything unless you put your shoulder to the wheel.
Sentence 2: I put my shoulder to the wheel and finished the task quickly.

Meaning 1: to make one demonstrate what one can do
Meaning 2: to test someone’s abilities or capacity.
Sentence 1: The teacher put the children through their paces before the exam.
Sentence 2: I auditioned for a part in the play, and the director really put me through my paces.

Meaning 1: to start thinking in a serious manner.
Sentence 1: Let’s put on our thinking-caps and decide where to go on holiday.
Sentence 2: It’s time to put on our thinking-caps, children, and choose a name for the dog.

Meaning 1: to gain weight
Sentence 1: I have to go on a diet because I’ve been putting on a little weight lately.
Sentence 2: The doctor says I need to put on some weight.

Meaning 1: to attempt to find out something without being too obvious.
Sentence 1: I wanted to get a new position, so I put out some feelers.
Sentence 2: We’d like to move house and so we’ve put out feelers to see what’s on the market.

Meaning 1: to put an end to something
Meaning 2: to prevent someone from doing something
Meaning 3: to prevent something from happening. (From the practice of book-keepers of writing “paid” in the account book when a bill has been settled.)
Sentence 1: Jean’s father’s objections put paid to John’s thoughts of marrying her.
Sentence 2: Lack of money put paid to our holiday plans.

Idioms: put someone in mind of someone or something
Meaning 1: to remind someone of someone or something.
Sentence 1: Mary puts me in mind of her mother when she was that age.
Sentence 2: This place puts me in mind of the village where I was brought up.

Meaning 1: to give someone all the necessary facts about something.
Sentence 1: They put the police in the picture about how the accident happened.
Sentence 2: Would someone put me in the picture about what went on in my absence?

Meaning 1: to respect or admire someone too much
Sentence 1: He has put her on a pedestal and thinks she can do no wrong.
Sentence 2: Don’t put me on a pedestal. I’m only human.

Meaning 1: to ask someone embarrassing questions
Meaning 2: to put someone in an uncomfortable or difficult position.
Sentence 1: Don’t put me on the spot. I can’t give you an answer.
Sentence 2: We put Bob on the spot and demanded that he do everything he had promised.

Idioms: put someone or something out to pasture
Meaning 1: to retire someone or something. (Originally said of a horse which was too old to work.)
Sentence 1: Please don’t put me out to pasture. I have lots of good years left.
Sentence 2: This car is very old and keeps breaking down. It’s time to put it out to pasture.

Idioms: put someone’s nose out of joint
Meaning 1: to cause someone to feel slighted or insulted.
Sentence 1: I’m afraid I put his nose out of joint by not inviting him to the picnic.
Sentence 2: Jane’s nose was put out of joint when her baby brother was born.

Meaning 1: to give someone a difficult or exhausting time.
Sentence 1: They are really putting me through the wringer at school.
Sentence 2: We all put Bob through the wringer over this contract.

Meaning 1: to show someone up
Sentence 1: Your excellent efforts put us all to shame.
Sentence 2: I put him to shame by telling everyone about his bad behaviour.

Meaning 1: to test someone
Meaning 2: to see what someone can achieve.
Sentence 1: I think I can jump that far, but no one has ever put me to the test.
Sentence 2: I’m going to put you to the test now!

Meaning 1: to cause someone to do something
Meaning 2: to bribe someone to do something
Meaning 3: to give someone the idea of doing something.
Sentence 1: Who put you up to it?
Sentence 2: Nobody put me up to it. I thought it up myself.

Idioms: put someone wise to someone or something
Meaning 1: to inform someone about someone or something.
Sentence 1: I put her wise to the way we do things around here.
Sentence 2: I didn’t know she was taking money. Mary put me wise to her.

Meaning 1: to delay or postpone something
Sentence 1: I’m afraid that we’ll have to put your project on ice for a while.

Meaning 1: to write something down.
Sentence 1: You have a great idea for a novel. Now put it on paper.
Sentence 2: I’m sorry, I can’t dis- cuss your offer until I see something in writing. Put it on paper, and then we’ll talk.

Meaning 1: to accomplish something
Sentence 1: This is a very hard thing to explain to a large audience. I hope I can put it over.
Sentence 2: This is a big request for money. I go before the board of directors this afternoon, and I hope I can put it over.

Meaning 1: to state something firmly and explicitly.
Sentence 1: To put it plainly, I want you out of this house immediately.
Sentence 2: Thank you. I think you’ve put your feelings quite plainly.

Meaning 1: to correct something
Meaning 2: to alter a situation to make it more fair.
Sentence 1: I’m sorry that we overcharged you. We’ll try to put it right.

Idioms: Put that in your pipe and smoke it!
Meaning 1: It is final, and you have to live with it!
Sentence 1: Well, I’m not going to do it, so put that in your pipe and smoke it!
Sentence 2: I’m sick of you, and I’m leaving. Put that in your pipe and smoke it!

Idioms: put the cart before the horse
Meaning 1: to have things in the wrong order
Meaning 2: to have things confused and mixed up.
Sentence 1: You’re eating your dessert! You’ve put the cart before the horse.
Sentence 2: Slow down and get organized. Don’t put the cart before the horse!
Sentence 3: John puts the cart before the horse in most of his projects.

Idioms: put the cat among the pigeons
Meaning 1: to cause trouble or a disturbance, especially by doing or saying something suddenly or unexpectedly.
Sentence 1: Meg put the cat among the pigeons by announcing that she was leaving home.

Meaning 1: to find the answer to something from the information available
Meaning 2: to reach an understanding of something.
Sentence 1: Well, I put two and two together and came up with an idea of who did it.
Sentence 2: Don’t worry. John won’t figure it out. He can’t put two and two together.

Meaning 1: [someone who is] easily influenced by someone else
Meaning 2: [someone who is] excessively willing to do what someone else wishes.
Sentence 1: Bob’s wife is putty in his hands. She never thinks for herself.
Sentence 2: Jane is putty in her mother’s hands. She always does exactly what her mother says.

Meaning 1: to appear to be brave (even if one is not).
Sentence 1: Mary is frightened, but she’s putting up a brave front.
Sentence 2: If she weren’t putting up a front, I’d be more frightened than I am.

Meaning 1: to make use of someone to an unreasonable degree
Meaning 2: to take advantage of someone for one’s own benefit.
Sentence 1: My mother was always put upon by her neighbours. She was too nice to refuse their requests for help.
Sentence 2: Jane feels put upon by her husband’s parents. They’re always coming to stay with her.

Meaning 1: to speak for another person without permission.
Sentence 1: Stop putting words into my mouth. I can speak for myself.
Sentence 2: The solicitor was scolded for putting words into the witness’s mouth.

Idioms: Put your money where your mouth is!
Meaning 1: a command to stop talking or boasting and make a bet, or to stop talking and provide money for something which one claims to support.
Sentence 1: I’m tired of your bragging about your skill at betting. Put your money where your mouth is!
Sentence 2: You talk about betting, but you don’t bet. Put your money where your mouth is!

Meaning 1: to get into a queue
Sentence 1: Will you all please queue up?
Sentence 2: It’s time to go from here to the theatre. Please queue up.

Meaning 1: quick to draw a gun and shoot
Sentence 1: Some of the old cowboys were known to be quick on the draw.
Sentence 2: Wyatt Earp was particularly quick on the draw.
Sentence 3: John gets the right answer before anyone else. He’s really quick on the draw.
Sentence 4: Sally will probably win the quiz game. She’s really quick on the draw.

Meaning 1: quick to understand
Sentence 1: Just because I’m not quick on the uptake, it doesn’t mean I’m stupid.
Sentence 2: Mary understands jokes before anyone else because she’s so quick on the uptake.

Meaning 1: in an advantageous or favourable position with someone.
Sentence 1: You’ll be quids in with Jean if you can charm her mother.
Sentence 2: Fred’s quids in with the boss after his successful export deal.

Meaning 1: to hurry to beat a deadline
Meaning 2: to hurry to achieve something by a certain time
Meaning 3: a task which must be finished within a certain time
Meaning 4: a situation in which one must hurry to complete something on time.
Sentence 1: We had to race against time to finish the work before the deadline.
Sentence 2: You don’t need to race against time. Take all the time you want.
Sentence 3: It was a race against time to finish before the deadline.
Sentence 4: The examination was a race against time, and Tom could not finish it.

Meaning 1: to try very hard to think of something.
Sentence 1: I racked my brains all afternoon, but couldn’t remember where I put the book.
Sentence 2: Don’t waste any more time racking your brains. Go and borrow the book from the library.

Meaning 1: to rain very hard.
Sentence 1: It’s raining cats and dogs. Look at it pour!
Sentence 2: I’m not going out in that storm. It’s raining cats and dogs.

Meaning 1: cancelled or postponed because of rain.
Sentence 1: Oh, the weather looks awful. I hope the picnic isn’t rained off.
Sentence 2: It’s starting to drizzle now. Do you think the game will be rained off?

Meaning 1: to shock or surprise people mildly by doing or saying something.
Sentence 1: What you just said may raise a few eyebrows, but it shouldn’t make anyone really angry.
Sentence 2: John’s sudden marriage to Ann raised a few eyebrows.

Meaning 1: to set higher goals for oneself.
Sentence 1: When you’re young, you tend to raise your sights too high.
Sentence 2: On the other hand, some people need to raise their sights higher.

Meaning 1: to come together to support someone or something.
Sentence 1: The family rallied round Jack when he lost his job.
Sentence 2: The former pupils rallied round their old school when it was in danger of being closed.

Meaning 1: to shout angrily and wildly.
Sentence 1: Bob rants and raves when anything displeases him.
Sentence 2: Father rants and raves if we arrive home late.

Meaning 1: to rebuke or punish someone.
Sentence 1: She rapped his knuckles for whispering too much.
Sentence 2: Don’t rap my knuckles. I didn’t do it.

Meaning 1: to receive punishment.
Sentence 1: I got my knuckles rapped for whispering too much.

Meaning 1: extremely keen to act or do something.
Sentence 1: Jane can’t wait to start her job. She’s rarin’ to go.
Sentence 2: Mary is rarin’ to go and can’t wait for her university term to start.

Meaning 1: a fierce struggle for success, especially in one’s career or business.
Sentence 1: Bob’s got tired of the rat race. He’s retired and gone to live in the country.
Sentence 2: The money market is a rat race, and many peo- ple who work in it die of the stress.

Meaning 1: to infer something (from something). (Usually figurative. Does not necessarily refer to written or printed information.)
Sentence 1: After listening to what she said, if you read between the lines, you can begin to see what she really means.
Sentence 2: Don’t believe everything you hear. Learn to read between the lines.

Meaning 1: to understand someone very well.
Sentence 1: I’ve got John figured out. I can read him like a book.
Sentence 2: Of course I understand you. I read you like a book.

Meaning 1: to guess what someone is thinking.
Sentence 1: You’ll have to tell me what you want. I can’t read your mind, you know.
Sentence 2: If I could read your mind, I’d know what you expect of me.

Meaning 1: to give someone a severe scolding. (Under the Riot Act of , an assembly of people could be dispersed by magistrates reading the act to them.)
Sentence 1: The manager read me the Riot Act for coming in late.
Sentence 2: The teacher read the pupils the Riot Act for their failure to do their homework.

Meaning 1: to attach or attribute a new or different meaning to something
Meaning 2: to find a meaning that is not intended in something.
Sentence 1: This statement means exactly what it says. Don’t try to read anything else into it.
Sentence 2: Am I reading too much into your comments?

Meaning 1: [for something unpleasant] to appear or become obvious after lying hidden.
Sentence 1: Jealousy reared its ugly head and destroyed their marriage.
Sentence 2: The question of money always rears its ugly head in matters of business.

Meaning 1: to welcome someone eagerly.
Sentence 1: I’m certain they wanted us to stay for dinner. They received us with open arms.

Meaning 1: to welcome someone eagerly.
Sentence 1: When I came home from school, the whole family welcomed me with open arms.

Meaning 1: one of the universities built in England in the late nineteenth century, contrasted with Oxford and Cambridge Universities. (Derogatory.)
Sentence 1: John’s tutor ridicules the redbrick uni- versities.
Sentence 2: Alice is a snob. She refuses to go to a redbrick university.

Meaning 1: a piece of information or suggestion introduced to draw attention away from the truth or real facts of a situation. (A red herring is a type of strong-smelling smoked fish that was once drawn across the trail of scent to mislead hunting dogs and put them off the scent).
Sentence 1: The detectives were fol- lowing a red herring, but they’re on the right track now.
Sentence 2: Jack and Mary were hoping to confuse their parents with a series of red her- rings so that the parents wouldn’t realize that they had eloped.

Meaning 1: over strict attention to the wording and details of rules and regulations, especially by government or public departments. (From the colour of the tape used by government departments to tie up bundles of documents.)
Sentence 1: Because of red tape, it took weeks for Frank to get a visa.
Sentence 2: Red tape prevented Jack’s wife from joining him abroad.

Meaning 1: to become calm and composed.
Sentence 1: I found it difficult to regain my composure after the argument.
Sentence 2: Here, sit down and relax so that you can regain your composure.

Meaning 1: to enjoy one’s success and not try to achieve more.
Sentence 1: Don’t rest on your laurels. Try to continue to do great things!
Sentence 2: I think I’ll rest on my laurels for a time before attempting anything new.

Meaning 1: a ticket (for a plane, train, bus, etc.) which allows one to go to a destination and return.
Sentence 1: A return ticket will usually save you some money.
Sentence 2: How much is a return ticket to Harrogate?

Idioms: ride roughshod over someone or something
Meaning 1: to treat someone or something with disdain or scorn.
Sentence 1: Tom seems to ride roughshod over his friends.
Sentence 2: You shouldn’t have come into our country to ride roughshod over our laws and our traditions.

Meaning 1: risking failure or an accident, usually owing to overconfidence.
Sentence 1: Tom drives too fast, and he seems too sure of him- self. He’s riding for a fall.
Sentence 2: Bill needs to stop borrowing money. He’s riding for a fall.

Meaning 1: ideally suited to one’s interests or abilities.
Sentence 1: Skiing is right up my street. I love it.
Sentence 2: This kind of thing is right up John’s street.

Meaning 1: [for something] to cause someone to remember something or to seem familiar.
Sentence 1: I’ve never met John Frank- lin, but his name rings a bell.
Sentence 2: The face in the photograph rang a bell. It was my cousin.

Meaning 1: to bring something to an end
Meaning 2: to declare something to be at an end.
Sentence 1: It’s time to ring down the curtain on our relationship. We have nothing in common any more.
Sentence 2: We’ve tried our best to make this company a success, but it’s time to ring down the curtain.

Meaning 1: to celebrate the beginning of the New Year at midnight on December .
Sentence 1: We are planning a big affair to ring in the New Year.
Sentence 2: How did you ring in the New Year?

Meaning 1: to end a telephone call.
Sentence 1: I must ring off now and get back to work.
Sentence 2: James rang off rather suddenly and rudely when Alice contradicted him.

Meaning 1: to record the cost of an item on a cash register
Meaning 2: to call someone on the telephone.
Sentence 1: The cashier rang up each item and told me how much money I owed.
Sentence 2: Please ring this chewing-gum up first, and I’ll put it in my handbag.
Sentence 3: Please ring up Ann and ask her if she wants to come over.
Sentence 4: Just ring me up any time.

Meaning 1: to record the cost of an item on a cash register
Meaning 2: to call someone on the telephone.
Sentence 1: Please ring this chewing-gum up first, and I’ll put it in my handbag.
Sentence 2: Please ring up Ann and ask her if she wants to come over.
Sentence 3: Just ring me up any time.

Meaning 1: to do or arrange things in different ways to achieve variety. (From bell ringing.)
Sentence 1: Jane doesn’t have many clothes, but she rings the changes by adding different-coloured scarves to her basic outfits.
Sentence 2: Aunt Mary rings the changes in her small flat by rearranging the furniture.

Meaning 1: to sound or seem true or likely. (From testing the quality of metal or glass by striking it and listening to the noise made.).
Sentence 1: The pupil’s excuse for being late doesn’t ring true.
Sentence 2: Do you think that Mary’s explanation for her absence rang true?

Meaning 1: a very old age.
Sentence 1: Mr. Smith died last night, but he was a ripe old ageninety-nine.
Sentence 2: All the Smiths seem to live to a ripe old age.

Meaning 1: to get out of bed and be lively and energetic.
Sentence 1: Come on, children! Rise and shine! We’re going to the seaside.
Sentence 2: Father always calls out “Rise and shine!” in the morning when we want to go on sleeping.

Meaning 1: to meet the challenge of an event
Meaning 2: to try extra hard to do a task.
Sentence 1: John was able to rise to the occasion and make the conference a success.
Sentence 2: It was a big challenge, but he rose to the occasion.

Meaning 1: to risk physical harm play safe to accomplish something.
Sentence 1: Look at that traffic! I refuse to risk my neck just to cross the street to buy a paper.
Sentence 2: I refuse to risk my neck at all.

Meaning 1: someone who drives carelessly and selfishly.
Sentence 1: Look at that road-hog driving in the middle of the road and stop- ping other drivers getting past him.
Sentence 2: That road-hog nearly knocked the children over. He was driving too fast.

Meaning 1: to take from one person in order to give to another.
Sentence 1: Why borrow money to pay your bills? That’s just robbing Peter to pay Paul.
Sentence 2: There’s no point in robbing Peter to pay Paul. You will still be in debt.

Meaning 1: to cause trouble
Meaning 2: to disturb a situation which is oth- erwise stable and satisfactory. (Often negative.)
Sentence 1: Look, Tom, every- thing is going fine here. Don’t rock the boat!
Sentence 2: You can depend on Tom to mess things up by rocking the boat.

Meaning 1: [for something, such as a time or a day] to approach rapidly. (Said by someone who wants the time or the day to arrive sooner than is possible. Usually a command.)
Sentence 1: Roll on Saturday! I get the day off.
Sentence 2: Roll on spring! We hate the snow.

Meaning 1: to win a race or competition easily.
Sentence 1: Our team romped home in the relay race.
Sentence 2: Jack romped home in the elec- tion for president of the club.

Meaning 1: unable to move because of fear or surprise.
Sentence 1: Joan stood rooted to the spot when she saw the ghostly figure.
Sentence 2: Mary was rooted to the spot when the thief snatched her bag.

Meaning 1: to live in discomfort
Meaning 2: to live in uncomfortable conditions without the usual amenities.
Sentence 1: The students are rough- ing it in a shack with no running water.
Sentence 2: Bob and Jack had nowhere to live, so they had to rough it in a tent until they found somewhere.

Meaning 1: to attack someone verbally.
Sentence 1: Jane suddenly rounded on Tom for arriving late.
Sentence 2: Peter rounded on Meg, asking what she’d done with the money.

Meaning 1: to get along fairly well with someone.
Sentence 1: Jack and Fred manage to rub along with each other, although they’re not best friends.
Sentence 2: Jim just about rubs along with his in-laws.

Meaning 1: deliberately to make someone’s unhappiness, shame, or misfortune worse.
Sentence 1: Don’t rub salt in the wound by telling me how enjoyable the party was.
Sentence 2: Jim is feeling miserable about losing his job, and Fred is rubbing salt in the wound by saying how good his replacement is.

Meaning 1: to associate with someone
Sentence 1: I don’t care to rub shoulders with some- one who acts like that!
Sentence 2: I rub shoulders with John every day at work. We are good friends.

Meaning 1: to remind one of something one has done wrong
Meaning 2: to remind one of something bad or unfortunate that has happened. (From a method of house training animals.)
Sentence 1: When Bob failed his exam, his brother rubbed his nose in it.
Sentence 2: Mary knows she shouldn’t have broken off her engagement. Don’t rub her nose in it.

Idioms: rub someone up the wrong way
Meaning 1: to irritate someone.
Sentence 1: I’m sorry I rubbed you up the wrong way. I didn’t mean to upset you.
Sentence 2: Don’t rub her up the wrong way!

Meaning 1: to upset or annoy someone. (A bird’s feathers become ruffled if it is angry or afraid.)
Sentence 1: You certainly ruf- fled Mrs. Smith’s feathers by criticizing her garden.
Sentence 2: Try to be tact- ful and not ruffle people’s feathers.

Meaning 1: to be the boss or manager, especially at home.
Sentence 1: Who rules the roost at your house?
Sentence 2: Our new office man- ager really rules the roost.

Meaning 1: to have a body temperature higher than normal
Sentence 1: I ran a fever when I had the flu.

Meaning 1: to be in a race with time
Meaning 2: to be in a great hurry to get something done before a particular time.
Sentence 1: This morn- ing, Bill set a new track record running against the clock. He lost the actual race this afternoon, however.
Sentence 2: The front runner was running against the clock. The others were a lap behind.

Meaning 1: to run a ship or an organization in an orderly, efficient, and disciplined manner.
Sentence 1: The new office manager really runs a tight ship.
Sentence 2: The headmaster runs a tight ship.

Meaning 1: to try and escape by running.
Sentence 1: The guard’s not looking. Let’s run for it!
Sentence 2: The convict tried to run for it, but the warder caught him.

Meaning 1: to run away to save one’s life.
Sentence 1: The dam has burst! Run for your life!
Sentence 2: The zoo-keeper told us all to run for our lives.

Meaning 1: [for feelings] to be in a state of excitement or anger.
Sentence 1: Feelings were running high as the general election approached.
Sentence 2: The mood of the crowd was running high when they saw the man beat the child.

Meaning 1: for a characteristic to appear in all (or most) members of a family.
Sentence 1: My grandparents lived well into their nineties, and longevity runs in the family.
Sentence 2: My brothers and I have red hair. It runs in the family.

Meaning 1: common or average
Sentence 1: The restaurant we went to was nothing special—just run of the mill.
Sentence 2: The service was good, but the food was run of the mill or worse.

Meaning 1: to get out of control.
Sentence 1: The dandelions have run riot on our lawn.

Idioms: run someone or something to earth
Meaning 1: to find something after a search. (From a fox-hunt chasing a fox into its hole.)
Sentence 1: Jean finally ran her long-lost cousin to earth in Paris.
Sentence 2: After months of searching, I ran a copy of Jim’s book to earth.

Meaning 1: to keep someone very busy.
Sentence 1: This busy season is running us all ragged at the shop.
Sentence 2: What a busy day. I ran myself ragged.

Meaning 1: to become worn out and uncared for.
Sentence 1: The estate has gone to seed since the old man’s death.

Meaning 1: to act hurriedly without enough care or thought. (From horse-riding.)
Sentence 1: Jack’s always rushing his fences. He should think things out first.
Sentence 2: Think carefully before you buy that expensive house. Don’t rush your fences.

Meaning 1: something that is regarded by some people with such respect and veneration that they don’t like it being criticized by any- one in any way. (From the fact that the cow is regarded as sacred in India.)
Sentence 1: University education is a sacred cow in the Smith family. Fred is regarded as a failure because he left school at sixteen.
Sentence 2: Don’t talk about eating meat to Pam. Vegetarianism is one of her sacred cows.

Meaning 1: safe and whole or healthy.
Sentence 1: It was a rough trip, but we got there safe and sound.
Sentence 2: I’m glad to see you here safe and sound.

Meaning 1: to finish something quickly and easily.
Sentence 1: The test was not difficult. I sailed through it.
Sentence 2: Bob sailed through his homework in a short amount of time.

Meaning 1: to pretend to be something that one is not. (Originally nautical, referring to a pirate ship disguised as a merchant ship.)
Sentence 1: John has been sailing under false colours. He’s really a spy.
Sentence 2: I thought you were wearing that uniform because you worked here. You are sailing under false colours.

Meaning 1: the most worthy of people
Meaning 2: a very good or worthy person. (A biblical reference.)
Sentence 1: Mrs. Jones is the salt of the earth. She is the first to help anyone in trouble.
Sentence 2: Frank’s mother is the salt of the earth. She has five children of her own and yet fosters three others.

Meaning 1: something that occurs or has occurred in the same way often.
Sentence 1: Jim’s got no money. It’s the same old story. He’s spent it all on clothing.
Sentence 2: The firm are getting rid of staff. It’s the same old story—a shortage of orders.

Meaning 1: rescued from a difficult or dangerous situation just in time by something which brings the situation to a sudden end. (From the sounding of a bell marking the end of a round in a boxing match.)
Sentence 1: James didn’t know the answer to the question, but he was saved by the bell when the teacher was called away from the room.
Sentence 2: I couldn’t think of anything to say to the woman at the bus- stop, but I was saved by the bell by my bus arriving.

Meaning 1: to refrain from talking, explaining, or arguing.
Sentence 1: There is no sense in trying to convince her. Save your breath.
Sentence 2: Tell her to save her breath. He won’t listen to her.

Meaning 1: to save someone from injury, embarrassment, or punishment.
Sentence 1: I saved my skin by getting the job done on time.
Sentence 2: Thanks for saving my skin. If you hadn’t given me an alibi, the police would have arrested me.

Idioms: save something for a rainy day
Meaning 1: to reserve something, usually money, for some future need.
Sentence 1: I’ve saved a little money for a rainy day.
Sentence 2: Keep some sweets for a rainy day.

Meaning 1: to say something so softly that hardly anyone can hear it.
Sentence 1: John was saying something under his breath, and I don’t think it was very pleasant.
Sentence 2: I’m glad he said it under his breath. If he had said it out loud, it would have caused an argument.

Meaning 1: to give a signal to begin
Sentence 1: I’m ready to start anytime you say the word.
Sentence 2: We’ll all shout “Happy birthday!” when I say the word.

Meaning 1: to scare someone severely
Sentence 1: That loud noise scared me stiff.
Sentence 2: The robber jumped out and scared us stiff.

Idioms: scrape the bottom of the barrel
Meaning 1: to select from among the worst
Meaning 2: to choose from what is left over.
Sentence 1: You’ve bought a dreadful old car. You really scraped the bottom of the barrel to get that one.
Sentence 2: The worker you sent over was the worst I’ve ever seen. Send me another—and don’t scrape the bottom of the barrel.

Meaning 1: to do a favour for someone in return for a favour done for you.
Sentence 1: You scratch my back, and I’ll scratch yours.
Sentence 2: We believe that the manager has been scratching the treasurer’s back.

Meaning 1: just to begin to find out about something
Meaning 2: to examine only the superficial aspects of something.
Sentence 1: The investi- gation of the firm’s books showed some inaccuracies. It is thought that the investigators have just scratched the surface.
Sentence 2: We don’t know how bad the problem is. We’ve only scratched the surface.

Meaning 1: to get one’s courage together
Meaning 2: to force oneself to be brave.
Sentence 1: I suppose I have to screw up my courage and go to the dentist.
Sentence 2: I spent all morning screwing up my courage to take my driver’s test.

Meaning 1: to be very thrifty
Meaning 2: to live on very little money, often to save up for something.
Sentence 1: We had to scrimp and save to send the children to college.
Sentence 2: The Smiths scrimp and save all year to go on a foreign holiday.
