Meaning 1: easy and natural for someone.
Sentence 1: Being polite is second nature to Jane.
Sentence 2: Driving is no problem for Bob. It’s second nature to him.

Meaning 1: better than anyone or anything else.
Sentence 1: This is an excellent car—second to none.
Sentence 2: Mary is an excellent teacher—sec- ond to none.

Meaning 1: to see two of everything instead of one.
Sentence 1: When I was driving, I saw two people on the road instead of one. I’m seeing double. There’s something wrong with my eyes.
Sentence 2: Mike thought he was see- ing double when he saw Mary with her sister. He didn’t know she had a twin.

Meaning 1: to view something in the same way (as someone else). (Usually negative.)
Sentence 1: John and Ann never see eye to eye about any- thing. They always disagree.

Meaning 1: one must believe something that one sees.
Sentence 1: I never would have thought that a cow could swim, but seeing is believing.
Sentence 2: I can hardly believe we are in Paris, but there’s the Eiffel Tower, and seeing is believing.

Meaning 1: to be angry.
Sentence 1: Whenever I think of the needless destruction of trees, I see red.
Sentence 2: Bill really saw red when the tax bill arrived.

Meaning 1: to accompany someone home.
Sentence 1: Bill agreed to see his aunt home after the film.
Sentence 2: You don’t need to see me home. It’s perfectly safe, and I can get there on my own.

Idioms: see something with half an eye
Meaning 1: to see or understand very easily.
Sentence 1: You could see with half an eye that the children were very tired.
Sentence 2: Anyone could see with half an eye that the work was badly done.

Meaning 1: to see flashing lights after receiving a blow to the head.
Sentence 1: I saw stars when I bumped my head on the attic ceiling.
Sentence 2: The lit- tle boy saw stars when he fell head first on to the concrete.

Meaning 1: to understand something clearly at last.
Sentence 1: After a lot of studying and asking many questions, I finally saw the light.
Sentence 2: I know that geometry is difficult. Keep working at it. You’ll see the light pretty soon.

Idioms: see the light at the end of the tunnel
Meaning 1: to foresee an end to one’s problems after a long period of time.
Sentence 1: I had been horribly ill for two months before I began to see the light at the end of the tunnel.
Sentence 2: We were in debt for years, but then we saw the light at the end of the tunnel.

Meaning 1: [for something] to be finished or produced. (Often negative.)
Sentence 1: The product will never see the light of day.
Sentence 2: His inventions will never see the light of day. They are too impractical.

Idioms: see the writing on the wall
Meaning 1: to know that something unpleasant or disastrous is certain to happen. (From a biblical reference.)
Sentence 1: If you don’t improve your performance, they’ll sack you. Can’t you see the writing on the wall?
Sentence 2: Jack saw the writing on the wall when the firm reduced his salary.

Meaning 1: to cheat someone by selling the person something that is inferior or worthless.
Sentence 1: Jack sold me a pup when I bought a bike from him. It broke down in two days.
Sentence 2: The salesman sold Jane a pup when he persuaded her to buy the second-hand washing-machine. Water pours out of it.

Meaning 1: to underestimate someone or something
Meaning 2: to fail to see the good qualities of someone or some- thing.
Sentence 1: This is a very good restaurant. Don’t sell it short.
Sentence 2: When you say that John isn’t interested in music, you’re selling him short. Did you know he plays the violin quite well?

Meaning 1: to ridicule or make fun of some- one or something
Sentence 1: John is always sending Jane up by mocking the way she walks.
Sentence 2: The drama group sent their lecturers up.

Meaning 1: to send someone away
Sentence 1: I couldn’t stand him any more, so I sent him packing.
Sentence 2: The maid proved to be so incompetent that I had to send her packing.

Meaning 1: to refuse to speak to or associate with someone or a group of people as a punishment.
Sentence 1: The other children sent Tom to Coventry for telling tales to the teacher.
Sentence 2: Fred was sent to Coventry by his fellow workers for breaking the strike.

Idioms: separate the men from the boys
Meaning 1: to separate the competent ones from those who are less competent
Meaning 2: to separate the brave or strong ones from those who are less brave or strong.
Sentence 1: This project is very complex. It’ll separate the men from the boys.

Idioms: separate the sheep from the goats
Meaning 1: to divide people into two groups in order to distinguish the good from the bad, etc.
Sentence 1: Working in a place like this really separates the sheep from the goats.
Sentence 2: We can’t go on with the game until we separate the sheep from the goats.

Idioms: separate the wheat from the chaff
Meaning 1: to separate what is of value from what is useless.
Sentence 1: Could you have a look at this furniture and separate the wheat from the chaff?
Sentence 2: The difficult exam will separate the wheat from the chaff among the pupils.

Meaning 1: [for someone or something] to be experimented on.
Sentence 1: Try it on someone else! I don’t want to serve as a guinea pig!
Sentence 2: Jane agreed to serve as a guinea pig. She’ll be the one to try out the new flavour of icecream.

Meaning 1: to announce something.
Sentence 1: John served notice that he was leaving the company.
Sentence 2: I’m serving notice that I’ll resign as sec- retary next month.

Meaning 1: to go or enter somewhere.
Sentence 1: If I were you, I wouldn’t set foot in that town.
Sentence 2: I wouldn’t set foot in her house! Not after the way she spoke to me.

Idioms: set great store by someone or something
Meaning 1: to have positive expectations for someone or something
Meaning 2: to have high hopes for someone or something.
Sentence 1: I set great store by my computer and its ability to help me in my work.
Sentence 2: We set great store by John because of his quick mind.

Idioms: set one back on one’s heels
Meaning 1: to surprise, shock, or overwhelm someone.
Sentence 1: Her sudden announcement set us all back on our heels.
Sentence 2: The manager scolded me, and that really set me back on my heels.

Meaning 1: [for a sour or bitter taste] to irritate one’s mouth
Meaning 2: [for a person or a noise] to be irritating or get on one’s nerves.
Sentence 1: Have you ever eaten a lemon? It’ll set your teeth on edge.
Sentence 2: Vinegar sets my teeth on edge.
Sentence 3: Please don’t scrape your finger-nails on the blackboard! It sets my teeth on edge!
Sentence 4: Here comes Bob. He’s so annoying. He really sets my teeth on edge.

Meaning 1: to explain something to someone.
Sentence 1: I don’t think you understand about taxation. Let me set you straight.
Sentence 2: Ann was confused, so I set her straight.

Meaning 1: to put right a mistake or misunderstanding
Meaning 2: to make sure that an account, etc., is correct.
Sentence 1: The manager thought Jean was to blame, but she soon set the record straight.
Sentence 2: Jane’s mother heard that Tom is a married man, but he set the record straight. He’s divorced.

Meaning 1: to place plates, glasses, napkins, etc., on the table before a meal.
Sentence 1: I’m tired of setting the table. Ask someone else to do it.

Meaning 1: to do exciting things that bring fame and glory. (Frequently negative.)
Sentence 1: I’m not very ambitious. I don’t want to set the world on fire.
Sentence 2: You don’t have to set the world on fire. Just do a good job.

Meaning 1: to attack someone or something violently.
Sentence 1: The dogs set upon the bear and chased it up a tree.
Sentence 2: Bill set upon Tom and struck him hard in the face.

Meaning 1: to establish one’s place of work somewhere.
Sentence 1: Mary set up shop in a small office building in Oak Street.

Meaning 1: reminders of someone or something
Sentence 1: The police officer said, “You can’t set up shop right here on the pavement!” When I met Jim’s mother, I thought “shades of Aunt Mary.” “Shades of school,” said Jack as the university lecturer rebuked him for being late.

Meaning 1: to be afraid
Sentence 1: I was shaking in my shoes because I had to go and see the manager.
Sentence 2: Stop quaking in your shoes, Bob. I’m not going to sack you.

Meaning 1: a kind of funny story which relies for its humour on its length and its sudden ridiculous ending.
Sentence 1: Don’t let John tell a shaggy-dog story. It’ll go on for hours.
Sentence 2: Mary didn’t get the point of Fred’s shaggy-dog story.

Meaning 1: with equal shares.
Sentence 1: I kept five and gave the other five to Mary—share and share alike.
Sentence 2: The two roommates agreed that they would divide expenses—share and share alike.

Meaning 1: dishonest or illegal methods or behaviour.
Sentence 1: I’m sure that Jim’s firm was guilty of sharp practice in getting that export order.
Sentence 2: The Smith brothers accused their competitors of sharp prac- tice, but they couldn’t prove it.

Meaning 1: to change one’s opinions or arguments, often without being challenged or opposed.
Sentence 1: At first Jack and I were on opposite sides, but he suddenly shifted his ground and started agree- ing with me.
Sentence 2: Jim has very fixed views. You won’t find him shifting his ground.

Meaning 1: in good order
Meaning 2: neat and tidy. (A nautical term. Bristol was a major British port.)
Sentence 1: You had better get this room shipshape before your mother gets home.
Sentence 2: Mr. Jones always keeps his garden shipshape and Bristol fashion.

Idioms: ships that pass in the night
Meaning 1: people who meet each other briefly by chance and are unlikely to meet again.
Sentence 1: Mary would have liked to see Jim again, but to him, they were ships that passed in the night.
Sentence 2: When you travel a lot on business, your encounters are just so many ships that pass in the night.

Meaning 1: to neglect one’s job or task.
Sentence 1: The guard was sacked for shirking his duty.
Sentence 2: You cannot expect to continue shirking your duty without someone noticing.

Meaning 1: brief (and pleasant because of briefness).
Sentence 1: That was a good sermon—short and sweet.
Sentence 2: I don’t care what you say, as long as you keep it short and sweet.

Meaning 1: something acting as a warning. (A naval term.)
Sentence 1: The student was sent a letter warning him to attend lectures, but he ignored the shot across the bows.
Sentence 2: Fred’s solicitor sent Bob a letter as a shot across the bows to get him to pay the money he owed Fred.

Meaning 1: a forced wedding. (From the bride’s father having threatened the bridegroom with a shot gun to force him to marry.)
Sentence 1: Mary was six months pregnant when she married Bill. It was a real shot-gun wedding.
Sentence 2: Bob would never have mar- ried Jane if she hadn’t been pregnant. Jane’s father saw to it that there was a shot-gun wedding.

Meaning 1: a boost
Sentence 1: Thank you for cheering me up. Your visit was a real shot in the arm.
Sentence 2: Your friendly greeting card was just what I needed—a real shot in the arm.

Meaning 1: a random or wild guess or try.
Sentence 1: I don’t know how I guessed the right answer. It was just a shot in the dark.
Sentence 2: I was lucky to take on such a good worker as Sally. When I employed her, it was just a shot in the dark.

Meaning 1: a vote expressed by people raising their hands.
Sentence 1: We were asked to vote for the candidates for captain by a show of hands.
Sentence 2: Jack wanted us to vote on paper, not by a show of hands, so that we could have a secret ballot.

Idioms: show oneself in one’s true colours
Meaning 1: to show what one is really like or what one is really thinking.
Sentence 1: Jane always pretends to be sweet and gentle, but she showed herself in her true colours when she lost the match.
Sentence 2: Mary’s drunken husband didn’t show himself in his true colours until after they were married.

Meaning 1: to reveal one’s intentions to someone. (From card-games.)
Sentence 1: I don’t know whether Jim’s intending to marry Jane or not. He’s not one to show his hand.
Sentence 2: If you want to get a rise, don’t show the boss your hand too soon.

Meaning 1: to show what one can do
Meaning 2: to demonstrate one’s abilities. (From horses demonstrating their skill and speed.)
Sentence 1: The runners had to show their paces for a place in the relay team.
Sentence 2: All the singers had to show their paces to be selected for the choir.

Meaning 1: to act in an angry or threatening manner.
Sentence 1: We thought Bob was meek and mild, but he really showed his teeth when Jack insulted his girlfriend.
Sentence 2: The enemy forces didn’t expect the coun- try they invaded to show its teeth.

Meaning 1: to be present at a gathering just so that the organization to which one belongs will be represented, or just to show others that one has attended. (From a ship flying its country’s flag.)
Sentence 1: The firm wants all the salesmen to attend the international confer- ence in order to show the flag.
Sentence 2: As many as possible of the family should attend the wedding. We must show the flag.

Meaning 1: to reveal fear or cowardice. (From the fact that a white tail feather was a sign of inferior breeding in a fighting cock.)
Sentence 1: Jim showed the white feather by refusing to fight with Jack.
Sentence 2: The enemy army showed the white feather by running away.

Meaning 1: to stop working or operating, for the day or forever.
Sentence 1: It’s five o’clock. Time to shut up shop.
Sentence 2: I can’t make any money in this town. The time has come to shut up shop and move to another town.

Meaning 1: formally and officially signed
Meaning 2: [for a formal document to be] executed.
Sentence 1: Here is the deed to the property—signed, sealed, and delivered.
Sentence 2: I can’t begin work on this project until I have the contract signed, sealed, and delivered.

Meaning 1: to do something that will lead to one’s ruin, downfall, or death. (As if one were signing a paper which called for one’s own death.)
Sentence 1: I wouldn’t ever gamble a large sum of money. That would be signing my own death-warrant.
Sentence 2: The killer signed his own death-warrant when he walked into the police station and gave himself up.

Meaning 1: the time of year, usually in the summer, when there is a lack of important news, and newspapers contain articles about unimportant or trivial things instead.
Sentence 1: It must be the silly season. There’s a story here about peculiarly shaped potatoes.
Sentence 2: There’s a piece on the front page about people with big feet. Talk about the silly season.

Meaning 1: to praise someone highly and enthusiastically.
Sentence 1: The boss is singing the praises of his new secretary.
Sentence 2: The theatre critics are singing the praises of the young actor.

Meaning 1: fail or succeed.
Sentence 1: After I’ve studied and learned all I can, I have to take the test and sink or swim.
Sentence 2: It’s too late to help John now. It’s sink or swim for him.

Meaning 1: to forget or to agree to set aside disagreements of opinion, attitude, etc.
Sentence 1: We decided to sink our differences and try to be friends for Mary’s sake.
Sentence 2: Individual members of the team must sink their dif- ferences and work for the success of the team.
Sentence 3: You two must sink your differences, or your marriage will fail.

Meaning 1: to admire someone greatly
Meaning 2: to be influenced by someone’s teaching
Sentence 1: Jack sat at the feet of Picasso when he was studying in Europe.
Sentence 2: Tom would love to sit at the feet of the musician Yehudi Menuhin.

Meaning 1: to remain inactive when other people are doing something
Meaning 2: to ignore a situation which calls for help.
Sentence 1: Bob sat idly by even though everyone else was hard at work.
Sentence 2: I can’t sit by while all those people need food.

Meaning 1: to do nothing
Sentence 1: When we needed help from Mary, she just sat on her hands.
Sentence 2: We need the co-opera- tion of everyone. You can’t sit on your hands!

Meaning 1: in a risky or explosive situation
Meaning 2: in a situation where something serious or dangerous may happen at anytime.
Sentence 1: Things are very tense at work. The whole office is sitting on a powder keg.
Sentence 2: The fire at the oilfield seems to be under control for now, but all the workers there are sitting on a powder keg.

Meaning 1: feeling wonderful
Sentence 1: Wow, I feel on top of the world.
Sentence 2: Since he got a new job, he’s on top of the world.
Sentence 3: I’ve been sitting on top of the world all week because I passed my exams.

Meaning 1: living in comfort or luxury
Sentence 1: My uncle died and left enough money for me to be sit- ting pretty for the rest of my life.
Sentence 2: Now that I have a good job, I’m sitting pretty.

Idioms: six of one and half a dozen of the other
Meaning 1: about the same one way or another.
Sentence 1: It doesn’t matter to me which way you do it. It’s six of one and half a dozen of the other.
Sentence 2: What difference does it make? They’re both the same—six of one and half a dozen of the other.

Meaning 1: a supposed power to know or feel things that are not perceptible by the five senses of sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch.
Sentence 1: My sixth sense told me to avoid going home by my usual route. Later I discovered there had been a fatal accident on it.
Sentence 2: Meg’s sixth sense told her not to trust Tom, even though he seemed honest enough.

Meaning 1: to pass lightly over something, trying to avoid drawing attention or avoid taking something into considera- tion.
Sentence 1: Sally prefers to skate over her reasons for leaving her job.
Sentence 2: Meg skated over the reason for her quarrel with Dick.

Meaning 1: in a risky situation.
Sentence 1: If you try that you’ll really be on thin ice. That’s too risky.
Sentence 2: You’re skating on thin ice if you criticize the lecturer. He has a hot temper.

Meaning 1: a hidden and shocking secret. (Often in the plural.)
Sentence 1: You can ask anyone about how reliable I am. I don’t mind. I don’t have any skeletons in the cupboard.
Sentence 2: My uncle was in jail for a day once. That’s our family’s only skeleton in the cupboard.

Meaning 1: to criticize something severely.
Sentence 1: The critics slated the place.
Sentence 2: The teacher slated the pupil’s performance.

Meaning 1: a share of something.
Sentence 1: There’s not much work around and so everyone must get a slice of the cake.
Sentence 2: The firm makes huge profits, and the workers want a slice of the cake.

Meaning 1: an error in speaking where a word is pro- nounced incorrectly, or where something is said which the speaker did not mean to say.
Sentence 1: I didn’t mean to tell her that. It was a slip of the tongue.
Sentence 2: I failed to understand the instructions because the speaker made a slip of the tongue at an important point.

Meaning 1: the hours immediately after midnight.
Sentence 1: The dance went on to the small hours.
Sentence 2: Jim goes to bed in the small hours and gets up at lunch-time.

Meaning 1: [for a book] to show signs of being revised and researched carefully and to lack spontaneity.
Sentence 1: I preferred her ear- lier spontaneous novels. The later ones smell of the lamp.
Sentence 2: The stu- dent has done a lot of research, but has few original ideas. His essay smells of the lamp.

Meaning 1: a low and deceitful person.
Sentence 1: Sally said that Bob couldn’t be trusted because he was a snake in the grass.

Meaning 1: something bothers one.
Sentence 1: Her criticism stuck in my craw.
Sentence 2: I knew that everything I said would stick in his craw and upset him.

Meaning 1: said when someone whose name has just been mentioned appears or is heard from.
Sentence 1: Well, speak of the devil! Hello, Tom. We were just talking about you.
Sentence 2: I had just mentioned Sally when—speak of the devil—she walked in the door.

Meaning 1: to say frankly what one thinks (about something).
Sentence 1: Please let me speak my mind, and then you can do what- ever you wish.
Sentence 2: You can always depend on John to speak his mind. He’ll let you know what he really thinks.

Meaning 1: to say something unwise or imprudent
Meaning 2: to say something at the wrong time.
Sentence 1: Excuse me if I’m speaking out of turn, but what you are proposing is quite wrong.
Sentence 2: What Bob said about the boss was true, even though he was speaking out of turn.

Meaning 1: [for people] to have similar ideas, tastes, etc.
Sentence 1: Jane and Jack get along very well. They really speak the same language about almost everything.
Sentence 2: Bob and his father don’t speak the same language when it comes to politics.

Meaning 1: to urinate. (From the former cost of admission to the cubicles in public lavatories.)
Sentence 1: Stop the car. The little girl needs to spend a penny.
Sentence 2: The station toilets are closed and I have to spend a penny.

Meaning 1: very clean.
Sentence 1: I have to clean up the house and get it spick and span for the party on Friday night.
Sentence 2: I love to have everything around me spick and span.

Meaning 1: to spoil someone’s plans
Meaning 2: to make it impossible for someone to carry out a course of action. (From driving a metal spike into the touch hole of an enemy gun to render it useless.)
Sentence 1: The boss was going to sack Sally publicly, but she spiked his guns by resigning.
Sentence 2: Jack intended borrowing his father’s car when he was away, but his father spiked his guns by locking it in the garage.

Meaning 1: to spend a lot of money on something in an extravagant way.
Sentence 1: Jack splashed out on a new car that he couldn’t afford.
Sentence 2: Let’s splash out on a really good meal out.

Meaning 1: to quibble
Meaning 2: to try to make petty distinctions.
Sentence 1: They don’t have any serious differences. They are just splitting hairs.
Sentence 2: Don’t waste time splitting hairs. Accept it the way it is.

Meaning 1: to divide the difference (with someone else).
Sentence 1: You want to sell for £120, and I want to buy for £100. Let’s split the difference and close the deal at £110.
Sentence 2: I don’t want to split the difference. I want £120.

Idioms: spoil the ship for a ha’porth of tar
Meaning 1: to risk ruining something valuable by not buying something relatively inexpensive but essential for it.
Sentence 1: Meg spent a lot of money on a new dress but refused to buy shoes. She certainly spoilt the ship for a ha’porth of tar.
Sentence 2: Bob bought a new car but doesn’t get it serviced because it’s too expensive. He’ll spoil the ship for a ha’porth of tar.

Meaning 1: to treat someone with too much care or help
Meaning 2: to teach someone with methods that are too easy and do not stimulate the learner to independent thinking.
Sentence 1: The teacher spoon-feeds the pupils by dictation notes on the novel instead of getting the children to read the books themselves.
Sentence 2: You mustn’t spoon-feed the new recruits by telling them what to do all the time. They must use their initiative.

Meaning 1: a reasonably good chance.
Sentence 1: If you hurry, you have a sporting chance of catching the bus.
Sentence 2: The firm has only a sporting chance of getting the export order.

Meaning 1: exactly right or accurate.
Sentence 1: Jack’s assessment of the state of the firm was spot on.
Sentence 2: Mary’s description of the stolen car was spot on.

Meaning 1: to do too many things, so that one can do none of them well.
Sentence 1: It’s a good idea to get involved in a lot of activities, but don’t spread yourself too thin.
Sentence 2: I’m too busy these days. I’m afraid I’ve spread myself too thin.

Meaning 1: a fair and honest transaction
Sentence 1: All the workers want is a square deal, but their boss underpays them.
Sentence 2: You always get a square deal with that travel firm.

Meaning 1: a nourishing, filling meal.
Sentence 1: All you’ve eaten today is junk food. You should sit down to a square meal.
Sentence 2: The tramp hadn’t had a square meal in weeks.

Idioms: square peg in a round hole
Meaning 1: a misfit
Meaning 2: one who is poorly adapted to one’s surroundings.
Sentence 1: John just can’t seem to get along with the people he works with. He’s just a square peg in a round hole.
Sentence 2: I’m not a square peg in a round hole. It’s just that no one understands me.

Idioms: stack the cards (against someone or something)
Meaning 1: to arrange things against someone or something
Meaning 2: to make it difficult for someone to succeed. (Originally from card-playing. Usually in the passive.)
Sentence 1: I can’t make any progress at my office. The cards are stacked against me.
Sentence 2: The cards seem to be stacked against me. I am having very bad luck.

Meaning 1: to have a chance.
Sentence 1: Do you think I stand a chance of winning first place?
Sentence 2: Everyone stands a chance of catching the disease.

Meaning 1: to admit that one has been wrong.
Sentence 1: I realize that I accused him wrongly. I stand corrected.
Sentence 2: We appreciate now that our conclusions were wrong. We stand corrected.

Meaning 1: to withdraw from a competition or a position.
Sentence 1: John has stood down from the election for president of the club.
Sentence 2: It is time our chairman stood down and made room for a younger person.

Meaning 1: a subject that regularly and over a period of time causes amusement whenever it is mentioned.
Sentence 1: Uncle Jim’s driving was a standing joke. He used to drive incredibly slowly.
Sentence 2: Their mother’s inability to make a decision was a standing joke in the Smith family all their lives.

Meaning 1: to hold rigidly to formal manners. (Often in the negative.)
Sentence 1: Please help yourself to more. Don’t stand on ceremony.
Sentence 2: We are very informal around here. Hardly anyone stands on ceremony.

Meaning 1: to be useful or beneficial to someone.
Sentence 1: This is a fine overcoat. I’m sure it’ll stand you in good stead for many years.
Sentence 2: I did the managing director a favour which I’m sure will stand me in good stead.

Meaning 1: to seem reasonable
Meaning 2: [for a fact or conclusion] to survive careful or logical evaluation.
Sentence 1: It stands to reason that it’ll be colder in January than it is in June.
Sentence 2: It stands to reason that Bill left in a hurry, because he didn’t pack his clothes.

Meaning 1: to start out again afresh
Meaning 2: to ignore the past and start over again.
Sentence 1: James started off with a clean slate when he went to a new school.
Sentence 2: When Bob got out of jail, he started off with a clean slate.

Meaning 1: to start something
Sentence 1: Jack started the ball rolling by asking for volunteers.

Meaning 1: to get some process going
Sentence 1: Tom started the project, and we kept the ball rolling.

Meaning 1: to get some sort of an advantage over someone without being noticed.
Sentence 1: I got the contract because I was able to steal a march on my competitor.
Sentence 2: You have to be clever and fast to steal a march on anyone.

Meaning 1: to prevent someone from receiving the public recognition expected upon the announcement of an achievement, by making the announcement in public before the intended receiver of the recognition can do so.
Sentence 1: I stole Mary’s thunder by telling her friends about Mary’s engagement to Tom before she could do so herself.
Sentence 2: Someone stole my thunder by leaking my announcement to the press.

Meaning 1: to give the best or most popular performance in a show, play, or some other event
Sentence 1: The lead in the play was very good, but the butler stole the show.
Sentence 2: Ann always tries to steal the show when she and I make a presentation.

Meaning 1: to take over the job or position of someone who has died
Meaning 2: to gain an advantage by someone’s death.
Sentence 1: The only hope of promotion in that firm is to step into dead men’s shoes.

Meaning 1: to move into a space or vacancy
Meaning 2: to fulfil a needed role or function that has been left vacant.
Sentence 1: When Ann resigned as president, I stepped into the breach.
Sentence 2: A number of people asked me to step into the breach and take her place.

Meaning 1: to interfere with or offend someone.
Sentence 1: When you’re in public office, you have to avoid stepping on anyone’s toes.

Meaning 1: to be left alone to suffer one’s anger or disappointment.
Sentence 1: John has such a terrible temper. When he got angry with us, we just let him go away and stew in his own juice.
Sentence 2: After John stewed in his own juice for a while, he decided to come back and apologize to us.

Meaning 1: to put up with or endure a situation, however difficult.
Sentence 1: This job’s boring, but we’re sticking it out until we find something more interesting.
Sentence 2: I know the children are being annoying, but can you stick it out until their mother returns?

Meaning 1: to take a risk.
Sentence 1: Why should I stick my neck out to do something for her? What’s she ever done for me?
Sentence 2: He made a risky investment. He stuck his neck out because he thought he could make some money.

Idioms: stick out like a sore thumb
Meaning 1: to be very prominent or unsightly
Sentence 1: Bob is so tall that he sticks out like a sore thumb in a crowd.
Sentence 2: The house next door needs painting. It sticks out like a sore thumb.

Meaning 1: to remain firm in one’s opinions and convictions
Meaning 2: to stand up for one’s rights.
Sentence 1: I’ll stick to my guns on this matter. I’m sure I’m right.
Sentence 2: Bob can be persuaded to do it our way. He probably won’t stick to his guns on this point.

Meaning 1: to create trouble or difficulties.
Sentence 1: By find- ing pupils copying from each other, you’ve really stirred up a hornets’ nest.
Sentence 2: Bill stirred up a hornets’ nest when he discovered the theft.

Meaning 1: an uproar about something trivial or unimportant.
Sentence 1: This isn’t a serious problem—just a storm in a teacup.
Sentence 2: Even a storm in a teacup can take a lot of time to get settled.

Meaning 1: right away
Sentence 1: We’ll have to go straight away.
Sentence 2: Straight away I knew something was wrong.

Meaning 1: sincerely
Sentence 1: Sally always speaks straight from the shoulder. You never have to guess what she really means.
Sentence 2: Bill told the staff the financial facts— straight from the shoulder and brief.

Meaning 1: an indication or sign of what might happen in the future.
Sentence 1: The student’s argument with the lecturer was a straw in the wind in terms of student-teacher relations. The students are plan- ning a strike.
Sentence 2: Two or three people getting the sack represents just a straw in the wind. I think the whole work-force will have to go.

Meaning 1: to walk around after sitting down or lying down for a time.
Sentence 1: We wanted to stretch our legs during the theatre interval.
Sentence 2: After sitting in the car all day, the travellers decided to stretch their legs.

Meaning 1: to reach an agreement on a price (for something).
Sentence 1: They argued for a while and finally struck a bargain.
Sentence 2: They were unable to strike a bargain, so they left.

Meaning 1: to cause someone to remember [someone or something]
Meaning 2: to remind someone of [someone or something]
Sentence 1: The woman in the portrait struck a chord, and I realized that she was my grandmother.
Sentence 2: His name strikes a chord, but I don’t know why.

Meaning 1: to find a compromise position
Meaning 2: to arrive at a position halfway between two unacceptable extremes.
Sentence 1: Ann likes very spicy food, but Bob doesn’t care for spicy food at all. We are trying to find a restaurant which strikes a happy medium.
Sentence 2: Tom is either very happy or very sad. He can’t seem to strike a happy medium.

Meaning 1: to achieve the desired effect
Meaning 2: to do something suitable or pleasing. (A musical reference.)
Sentence 1: Meg struck the right note when she wore a dark suit to the interview.
Sentence 2: The politician’s speech failed to strike the right note with the crowd.

Idioms: strike while the iron is hot
Meaning 1: to do something at the best possible time
Meaning 2: to do something when the time is ripe.
Sentence 1: He was in a good mood, so I asked for a loan of £200. I thought I’d better strike while the iron was hot.
Sentence 2: Please go to the bank and settle this matter now! They are willing to be reasonable. You’ve got to strike while the iron is hot.

Meaning 1: nonsense.
Sentence 1: Come on! Don’t give me all that stuff and nonsense!
Sentence 2: I don’t understand this book. It’s all stuff and nonsense as far as I am concerned.

Meaning 1: something that prevents or obstructs progress.
Sentence 1: We’d like to buy that house, but the high price is the stumblingblock.
Sentence 2: Jim’s age is a stumblingblock to getting another job. He’s over sixty.

Meaning 1: to make something unpleasant more pleasant. (From the sugar coating on some pills to disguise the bitter taste of the medicine.)
Sentence 1: Mary’s parents wouldn’t let her go out and tried to sugar the pill by inviting some of her friends around.

Meaning 1: to be very appropriate for someone.
Sentence 1: This kind of employment suits me to a T.

Meaning 1: the idea that the most able or fit will survive (while the less able and less fit will perish). (This is used literally as a part of the theory of evolution.)
Sentence 1: In college, it’s the survival of the fittest. You have to keep working in order to survive and graduate.
Sentence 2: I don’t look after my house-plants very well, but the ones I have are really flourishing. It’s the survival of the fittest, I suppose.

Meaning 1: to forget one’s pride and accept something humiliating.
Sentence 1: I had to swallow my pride and admit that I was wrong.
Sentence 2: When you’re a pupil, you find yourself swallowing your pride quite often.

Idioms: swallow something hook, line, and sinker
Meaning 1: to believe something completely. (These terms refer to fishing and fooling a fish into being caught.)
Sentence 1: I made up a story about why I was so late. They all swallowed it hook, line, and sinker.
Sentence 2: I feel like a fool. I swallowed the trick hook, line, and sinker.

Meaning 1: to go around in an idle and irresponsible way.
Sentence 1: Mrs. Smith’s swanning around abroad while her husband’s in hospital here.
Sentence 2: Mary’s not looking for a job. She’s just swanning around visiting all her friends.

Meaning 1: the last work or performance of a playwright, musician, actor, etc., before death or retirement.
Sentence 1: His portrayal of Lear was the actor’s swansong.
Sentence 2: We didn’t know that her performance last night was the singer’s swan-song.

Meaning 1: to try to hide something unpleasant, shameful, etc., from the attention of others.
Sentence 1: The boss said he couldn’t sweep the theft under the carpet, that he’d have to call in the police.

Meaning 1: to do the opposite of what everyone else does
Sentence 1: Bob tends to do what everybody else does. He isn’t likely to swim against the tide.
Sentence 2: Mary always swims against the tide. She’s a very contrary person.

Meaning 1: a situation where a small or minor part is controlling the whole thing.
Sentence 1: John was just employed yesterday, and today he’s bossing everyone around. It’s a case of the tail wagging the dog.
Sentence 2: Why is this minor matter being given so much importance? It’s the tail wagging the dog!

Idioms: take a leaf out of someone’s book
Meaning 1: to behave or to do something in the way that someone else would
Meaning 2: to use someone as an example.
Sentence 1: Take a leaf out of your brother’s book and work hard.
Sentence 2: Eventually June took a leaf out of her friend’s book and started dress- ing smartly.

Meaning 1: to make a try at something, sometimes without much hope of success.
Sentence 1: I don’t know if I can do it, but I’ll take a stab at it.
Sentence 2: Come on, Mary. Take a stab at catching a fish. You might end up liking fishing.
Sentence 3: Would you like to have a stab at this problem?

Meaning 1: to become irrational.
Sentence 1: What are you doing? Have you taken leave of your senses?
Sentence 2: What a terrible situa- tion! It’s enough to make one take leave of one’s senses.

Meaning 1: to accept the punishment or the bad fortune which one deserves.
Sentence 1: I know I did wrong, and I know I have to take my medicine.
Sentence 2: Billy knew he was going to be punished, and he didn’t want to take his medicine.

Idioms: take someone down a peg (or two)
Meaning 1: to reprimand someone who is acting in too arrogant a way.
Sentence 1: The teacher’s scolding took Bob down a peg or two.
Sentence 2: He was so rude that someone was bound to take him down a peg.

Meaning 1: to scold or reprimand someone.
Sentence 1: The teacher took John to task for his bad behaviour.
Sentence 2: I lost a big contract, and the managing director took me to task in front of everyone.

Meaning 1: to take over and care for a person.
Sentence 1: John wasn’t doing well at school until an older pupil took him under her wing.
Sentence 2: I took the new workers under my wing, and they learned the job in no time.

Meaning 1: to assume something or regard something as being understood and accepted without reading it out, stating it, or checking it.
Sentence 1: Can we take the minutes of the meeting as read, or should I read them?
Sentence 2: I think we can take their agreement as read, but I’ll check with them if you like.

Meaning 1: to accept something as natural or expected.
Sentence 1: The argument surprised him, but he took it in his stride.
Sentence 2: It was a very rude remark, but Mary took it in her stride.

Meaning 1: to endure something unpleasant without fighting back.
Sentence 1: He insulted me publicly. You don’t expect me to take that lying down, do you?
Sentence 2: I’m not the kind of person who’ll take something like that lying down.

Meaning 1: to experience and endure a blow stoically.
Sentence 1: The bad news was a real shock, but John took it on the chin.
Sentence 2: The worst luck comes my way, but I always end up taking it on the chin.

Meaning 1: to take something very seriously.
Sentence 1: John took the criticism to heart and made an honest effort to improve.
Sentence 2: I know Bob said a lot of cruel things to you, but he was angry. You shouldn’t take those things to heart.

Idioms: take the rough with the smooth
Meaning 1: to accept the bad things along with the good things.
Sentence 1: We all have disappointments. You have to learn to take the rough with the smooth.
Sentence 2: There are good days and bad days, but every day you take the rough with the smooth. That’s life.

Idioms: take the wind out of someone’s sails
Meaning 1: to put an end to someone’s boasting or arrogance and make the person feel embarrassed
Meaning 2: to take an advantage away from someone.
Sentence 1: John was bragging about how much money he earned until he learned that most of us make more. That took the wind out of his sails.
Sentence 2: Learning that one has been totally wrong about something can really take the wind out of one’s sails.

Idioms: take the words (right) out of one’s mouth
Meaning 1: [for someone else] to say what you were going to say.
Sentence 1: John said exactly what I was going to say. He took the words out of my mouth.
Sentence 2: I agree with you. You took the words right out of my mouth.

Idioms: take up the cudgels on behalf of someone or something
Meaning 1: to support or defend someone or something.
Sentence 1: We’ll have to take up the cudgels on behalf of Jim or he’ll lose the debate.
Sentence 2: Meg has taken up the cudgels on behalf of an environmental movement.

Meaning 1: a place or meeting where things are discussed, but action may or may not be taken.
Sentence 1: Many people think the City Chambers is just a talking-shop.
Sentence 2: The firm’s board meeting is always just a talking-shop. The chairman makes all the decisions himself.

Meaning 1: to talk a lot, usually quickly.
Sentence 1: The old friends talk nineteen to the dozen when they meet once a year.
Sentence 2: You won’t get Jean to stop chattering. She always talks nineteen to the dozen.

Meaning 1: the subject of gossip
Meaning 2: someone or something that everyone is talking about.
Sentence 1: Joan’s argument with the town council is the talk of the town.
Sentence 2: Fred’s father is the talk of the town since the police arrested him.

Meaning 1: to talk nonsense.
Sentence 1: John doesn’t know anything about gardening. He’s just talking through his hat.
Sentence 2: Jean said that the Smiths are emigrating, but she’s talking through her hat.

Idioms: talk until one is blue in the face
Meaning 1: to talk until one is exhausted.
Sentence 1: I talked until I was blue in the face, but I couldn’t change her mind.
Sentence 2: She had to talk until she was blue in the face to convince him.

Meaning 1: having the same faults or bad points as someone else.
Sentence 1: Jack and his brother are tarred with the same brush. They’re both crooks.
Sentence 2: The Smith children are tarred with the same brush. They’re all lazy.

Idioms: teach one’s grandmother to suck eggs
Meaning 1: to try to tell or show someone more knowledgeable or experienced than oneself how to do something.
Sentence 1: Don’t suggest showing Mary how to knit. It will be teaching your grandmother to suck eggs. She’s an expert.
Sentence 2: Don’t teach your grandmother to suck eggs. Jack has been playing tennis for years.

Meaning 1: I do not believe you (maybe the marines will).
Sentence 1: That’s silly. Tell it to the marines.

Meaning 1: that there is no belief (maybe the marines will believe).
Sentence 1: I don’t care how good you think your reason is. Tell that to the marines!

Meaning 1: to tell secrets or spread rumours. (Does not refer only to schoolchildren.)
Sentence 1: I wish that John would keep quiet. He’s telling tales out of school again.
Sentence 2: If you tell tales out of school a lot, people won’t know when to believe you.

Meaning 1: to be thankful for one’s luck.
Sentence 1: You can thank your lucky stars that I was there to help you.
Sentence 2: I thank my lucky stars that I studied the right things for the test.

Meaning 1: in large numbers or amounts and at a rapid rate.
Sentence 1: The enemy soldiers came thick and fast.
Sentence 2: New problems seem to come thick and fast.

Meaning 1: not easily upset or hurt
Sentence 1: Tom won’t worry about your insults. He’s completely thick-skinned.
Sentence 2: Jane’s so thick-skinned she didn’t realize Fred was being rude to her.

Meaning 1: a minor or unimportant event or act that is the first stage in something more serious or unfortunate.
Sentence 1: If you let Pam stay for a few days, it will be the thin end of the wedge. She’ll stay for ages.
Sentence 2: The boss thinks that if he gives his secretary a rise, it will be the thin end of the wedge and all the staff will demand the same.

Meaning 1: few in number
Sentence 1: Jobs in that area are thin on the ground.
Sentence 2: Butterflies are thin on the ground here now.

Meaning 1: easily upset or hurt
Sentence 1: You’ll have to handle Mary’s mother carefully. She’s very thin-skinned.
Sentence 2: Jane weeps easily when people tease her. She’s too thin-skinned.

Meaning 1: through all sorts of severe difficulties.
Sentence 1: I came through hell and high water to get to this meeting. Why don’t you start on time?
Sentence 2: You’ll have to go through hell and high water to accomplish your goal, but it’ll be worth it.

Meaning 1: through good times and bad times.
Sentence 1: We’ve been together through thick and thin and we won’t deserteach other now.
Sentence 2: Over the years, we went through thick and thin and enjoyed every minute of it.

Meaning 1: to become very angry
Meaning 2: to put on a display of anger.
Sentence 1: Sally threw a fit when I showed up without the things she asked me to buy.
Sentence 2: My dad threw a fit when I got home three hours late.

Meaning 1: to give or hold a party for someone.
Sentence 1: Mary was leaving town, so we threw a party for her.
Sentence 2: Do you know a place where we could throw a party?

Idioms: throw a spanner in the works
Meaning 1: to cause problems for someone’s plans.
Sentence 1: I don’t want to throw a spanner in the works, but have you checked your plans with a solicitor?
Sentence 2: When John refused to help us, he really threw a spanner in the works.

Meaning 1: to become very careless.
Sentence 1: Jane, who is usually quite cautious, threw caution to the winds and went wind- surfing.
Sentence 2: I don’t mind taking a little chance now and then, but I’m not the type of person who throws caution to the winds.

Meaning 1: to challenge (someone) to an argument or (figurative) combat.
Sentence 1: When Bob challenged my conclusions, he threw down the gauntlet. I was ready for an argument.
Sentence 2: Frowning at Bob is the same as throwing down the gauntlet. He loves to get into a fight about anything.

Meaning 1: to waste additional money after wasting money once.
Sentence 1: I bought a used car and then had to spend £300 on repairs. That was throwing good money after bad.
Sentence 2: The Browns are always throwing good money after bad. They bought a plot of land which turned out to be swamp, and then had to pay to have it filled in.

Meaning 1: to give up or abandon a course of action. (From a player giving up in a card-game.)
Sentence 1: I got tired of the ten- nis competition and threw in my hand.
Sentence 2: John spent only one year at university and then threw in his hand.

Meaning 1: to charge someone with, or convict someone of, as many crimes as possible
Meaning 2: to reprimand or punish someone severely.
Sentence 1: I made the police officer angry, so he took me to the station and threw the book at me.
Sentence 2: The judge threatened to throw the book at me if I didn’t stop insulting the police officer.

Meaning 1: to get a lift from a passing motorist
Meaning 2: to make a sign with one’s thumb that indicates to passing drivers that one is asking for a lift.
Sentence 1: My car broke down on the motorway, and I had to thumb a lift to get back to town.

Meaning 1: get a lift from motorist passing by
Meaning 2: make a sign with one’s thumb that indicates to passing drivers that one is asking for a lift
Sentence 1: Sometimes it’s dangerous to hitch a lift with a stranger.

Idioms: thumb one’s nose at someone or something
Meaning 1: to make a rude gesture of disgust, touching the end of one’s nose with one’s thumb (Both literal and figurative uses.)
Sentence 1: The tramp thumbed his nose at the lady and walked away.
Sentence 2: You can’t just thumb your nose at people who give you trouble. You’ve got to learn to get along with them.

Meaning 1: to interest someone
Sentence 1: I have an interesting proposal here which I think will tickle your fancy.
Sentence 2: The idea of dancing doesn’t exactly tickle my fancy.

Meaning 1: to move along at a quiet, even pace, without either stopping or going quickly. (From an engine ticking over.)
Sentence 1: The firm didn’t make large profits, but it’s ticking over.
Sentence 2: We must try to keep our finances ticking over until the recession ends.

Meaning 1: dominated by one’s mother
Sentence 1: Tom is still tied to his mother’s apron- strings.
Sentence 2: Isn’t he a little old to be tied to his mother’s apron-strings?

Meaning 1: to make someone confused or upset.
Sentence 1: The speaker tied herself in knots trying to explain her diffi- cult subject in simple language.
Sentence 2: I was trying to be tactful, but I just tied myself in knots.

Meaning 1: to get married.
Sentence 1: Well, I hear that you and John are going to tie the knot.
Sentence 2: My parents tied the knot almost forty years ago.

Meaning 1: to manage to spend less money.
Sentence 1: Things are beginning to cost more and more. It looks as though we’ll all have to tighten our belts.
Sentence 2: Times are hard, and prices are high. I can tighten my belt for only so long.

Meaning 1: for a very long time. (Cows are returned to the barn at the end of the day.
Sentence 1: We could discuss thisuntil the cows come home and still reach no decisions.
Sentence 2: He could drink beer until the cows come home.

Meaning 1: for a very long time
Sentence 1: There has been a church in the village time out of mind.
Sentence 2: The Smith family have lived in that house time out of mind.

Meaning 1: to give someone privileged or useful information in a secret or private manner.
Sentence 1: John tipped Mary the wink that there was a vacancy in his department.
Sentence 2: Jack got his new house at a good price. A friend tipped him the wink that it was going on the market.

Meaning 1: to weigh some amount.
Sentence 1: Tom tips the scales at nearly 14 stone.
Sentence 2: I’ll be glad when I tip the scales at a few pounds less.

Meaning 1: to do what one is expected or required to do
Sentence 1: You’ll get ahead, Sally. Don’t worry. Just toe the line, and everything will be okay.
Sentence 2: John finally got the sack. He just couldn’t learn to toe the line.

Meaning 1: insincere
Sentence 1: Ann made a tongue-in-cheek remark to John, and he got angry because he thought she was serious.
Sentence 2: The play seemed very serious at first, but then everyone saw that it was tongue-in-cheek, and the audience began laughing.

Meaning 1: to the very end. (Originally nautical. This originally had nothing to do with bitterness.).
Sentence 1: I kept trying to the bitter end.
Sentence 2: It took me a long time to get through college, but I worked hard at it all the way to the bitter end.

Meaning 1: exactly as instructed
Sentence 1: I didn’t make an error. I followed your instructions to the letter.
Sentence 2: We didn’t prepare the recipe to the letter, but the cake still turned out very well.

Meaning 1: very uncertain or critical.
Sentence 1: Things were touch-and- go at the office until a new manager was employed.
Sentence 2: Jane had a seri- ous operation, and everything was touch-and-go for several hours.

Meaning 1: to refer to a sensitive matter which will upset someone.
Sentence 1: When you talk to him, avoid talking about money. It’s best not to touch a sore point if possible.

Meaning 1: to refer to a sensitive matter which will upset someone.
Sentence 1: I seem to have touched a sore spot. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you.
Sentence 2: When you talk to him, avoid talking about money. It’s best not to touch a sore point if possible.

Meaning 1: a phrase said to cancel out imaginary bad luck.
Sentence 1: My stereo has never given me any trouble—touch wood.
Sentence 2: We plan to be in London by tomorrow evening—touch wood.

Meaning 1: to use a fact or a situation to one’s advantage.
Sentence 1: Tom was able to trade on the fact that he had once been in the army.
Sentence 2: John traded on his poor eyesight to get a seat closer to the stage.

Meaning 1: keeping one’s promise.
Sentence 1: True to his word, Tom appeared at exactly eight o’clock.
Sentence 2: We’ll soon know if Jane is true to her word. We’ll see if she does what she promised.

Meaning 1: to behave in a bold, disobedient, or unlawful manner to discover whether such behaviour will be allowed.
Sentence 1: Tony knew he wouldn’t get away with working only four days a week. He was just trying it on by asking the boss.
Sentence 2: The children really try it on when their mother’s out.

Meaning 1: to try to do something one has recently become qualified to do. (Like a young bird uses its wings to try to fly.)
Sentence 1: John just got his driver’s licence and wants to borrow the car to try his wings.
Sentence 2: I learned to skin-dive, and I want to go to the seaside to try my wings.

Meaning 1: to do something annoying which may cause someone to lose patience
Meaning 2: to cause someone to be annoyed.
Sentence 1: Stop whistling. You’re trying my patience. Very soon I’m going to lose my temper.
Sentence 2: Some pupils think it’s fun to try the teacher’s patience.

Meaning 1: to eat something with hunger and enjoyment.
Sentence 1: The children really tucked into the icecream.
Sentence 2: Jean would like to have tucked into the cream cakes, but she’s on a strict diet.

Meaning 1: suddenly to understand or realize something.
Sentence 1: I suddenly tumbled to the reason for his behaviour.
Sentence 2: When will Meg tumble to the fact that her husband is dishonest?

Idioms: turn a blind eye to someone or something
Meaning 1: to ignore something and pretend you do not see it.
Sentence 1: The usherette turned a blind eye tothe little boy who sneaked into the theatre.
Sentence 2: How can you turn a blind eye to all those starving children?

Meaning 1: to make someone conceited.
Sentence 1: John’s com- pliments really turned Sally’s head.
Sentence 2: Victory in the competition is bound to turn Tom’s head. He’ll think he’s too good for us.

Meaning 1: to use something in such a way that it is to one’s advantage
Meaning 2: to make good use of a situation, expe- rience, etc.
Sentence 1: Pam turned her illness to good account and did a lot of reading.
Sentence 2: Many people turn their retirement to good account and take up interesting hobbies.

Meaning 1: to make an advantage for oneself out of something (which might otherwise be a disadvantage).
Sentence 1: Sally found a way to turn the problem to her advantage.
Sentence 2: The icecream shop manager was able to turn the hot weather to her advantage.

Meaning 1: to choose not to respond to abuse or to an insult.
Sentence 1: When Bob got angry with Mary and shouted at her, she just turned the other cheek.
Sentence 2: Usually I turn the other cheek when some- one is rude to me.

Meaning 1: to cause a reversal in someone’s plans
Meaning 2: to reverse a situation and put someone in a different position, especially in a less advantageous position.
Sentence 1: I went to Jane’s house to help get ready for a surprise party for Bob. It turned out that the surprise party was for me! Jane really turned the tables on me!
Sentence 2: Turn- ing the tables like that requires a lot of planning and a lot of secrecy.

Meaning 1: to cause a reversal in the direction of events
Meaning 2: to cause a reversal in public opinion.
Sentence 1: It looked as though the team was going to lose, but near the end of the game, our star player turned the tide by scoring a goal.
Sentence 2: At first, people were opposed to our plan. After a lot of discussion, we were able to turn the tide and get them to agree with us.

Meaning 1: to turn upside down.
Sentence 1: The boat turned turtle, and everyone got soaked.
Sentence 2: The car ran off the road and turned turtle in the ditch.

Meaning 1: to do the right or required thing, often unexpectedly or at the last minute.
Sentence 1: I thought our team would let us down, but they turned up trumps in the second half of the match.
Sentence 2: We always thought the boss was mean, but he turned up trumps and made a large contribution to Mary’s leaving present.

Meaning 1: very common
Sentence 1: People with qualifications like yours are two a penny. You should take another training course.

Meaning 1: at a dead end
Meaning 2: on a route that leads nowhere.
Sentence 1: I have been trying to find out something about my ances- tors, but I’m up a blind alley. I can’t find anything.
Sentence 2: The police are up a blind alley in their investigation of the crime.

Meaning 1: active and lively.
Sentence 1: The children are always up and doing early in the morning.
Sentence 2: If Jean wants to be at work early, it’s time she was up and doing.

Meaning 1: rising up in anger.
Sentence 1: The citizens were up in arms, pounding on the gates of the palace, demanding justice.
Sentence 2: My father was really up in arms when he got his rates bill this year.

Meaning 1: undecided
Sentence 1: I don’t know what Sally plans to do. Things were sort of up in the air the last time we talked.
Sentence 2: Let’s leave this question up in the air until next week. Then we will make a decision.
Sentence 3: Jane speaks like that because she pretends to be from the upper crust, but her father was a miner.
Sentence 4: James is from the upper crust, but he is penniless.

Meaning 1: of the upper class
Meaning 2: belonging to or typical of the upper class.
Sentence 1: Pam has a grating upper-crust voice.
Sentence 2: Many people dislike Bob because of his snobbish, upper-crust attitude.

Meaning 1: to spoil or ruin something.
Sentence 1: Tom really upset the applecart by telling Mary the truth about Jane. Now the two women are no longer friends.
Sentence 2: We were going abroad, but the children upset the applecart by getting the mumps.

Meaning 1: doing something bad or criminal.
Sentence 1: I could tell from the look on Tom’s face that he was up to no good.
Sentence 2: There are three boys in the front garden. I don’t know what they are doing, but I think they are up to no good.

Idioms: use every trick in the book
Meaning 1: to use every method possible.
Sentence 1: I used every trick in the book, but I still couldn’t manage to get a ticket to the game on Saturday.
Sentence 2: Bob used every trick in the book to get Mary to go out with him, but he still failed. She simply refuses to go out with him.

Meaning 1: to disappear without leaving a trace.
Sentence 1: My money gets spent so fast. It seems to vanish into thin air.
Sentence 2: When I came back, my car was gone. I had locked it, and it couldn’t have vanished into thin air!

Meaning 1: to get rid of one’s feelings of anger caused by someone or something by attacking someone or something else.
Sentence 1: Because Jack didn’t get the job, he was angry, and he vented his spleen by shouting at his wife.
Sentence 2: Peter kicked his car to vent his spleen for losing the race.

Meaning 1: a difficult problem about which there is a lot of discussion without a solution being found.
Sentence 1: The two brothers quarrelled over the vexed question of which of them should take charge of their father’s firm.
Sentence 2: We’ve seen a house that we like, but there’s the vexed question of where we’ll get the money from.

Meaning 1: someone or something that is responsible for something bad or wrong.
Sentence 1: I wondered who told the newspapers about the local scandal. I discovered that Joan was the villain of the piece.
Sentence 2: We couldn’t think who had stolen the meat. The dog next door turned out to be the villain of the piece.

Meaning 1: ready or prepared to do something, especially to take over someone else’s job or position. (From waiting at the side of the stage to go on.)
Sentence 1: Mr. Smith retires as manager next year, and Mr. Jones is just waiting in the wings.
Sentence 2: Jane was waiting in the wings, hoping that a member of the hockey team would drop out and she would get a place on the team.

Meaning 1: to be in a situation where one must be very cautious.
Sentence 1: I’ve been walking a tightrope all day trying to please both bosses. I need to relax.
Sentence 2: Our business is about to fail. We’ve been walking a tightrope for three months, trying to control our cash flow.

Meaning 1: to be very happy
Sentence 1: Ann was walking on air when she got the job.
Sentence 2: On the last day of school, all the chil- dren are walking on air.

Meaning 1: to be very cautious.
Sentence 1: The manager is very hard to deal with. You really have to walk on eggs.
Sentence 2: I’ve been walking on eggs ever since I started working here. There’s a very large staff turnover.

Meaning 1: we may be overheard.
Sentence 1: Let’s not discuss this mat- ter here. Walls have ears, you know.
Sentence 2: Shhh. Walls have ears. Some- one may be listening.

Meaning 1: to want to have both of two seemingly incompatible things
Meaning 2: to want to have it both ways.
Sentence 1: John wants it both ways. He can’t have it both ways.
Sentence 2: You like marriage and you like freedom. You want it both ways.

Idioms: warm the cockles of someone’s heart
Meaning 1: to make someone feel pleased and happy.
Sentence 1: It warms the cockles of my heart to hear you say that.
Sentence 2: Hearing that old song again warmed the cockles of her heart.

Meaning 1: including all the faults and disadvantages.
Sentence 1: Jim has many faults, but Jean loves him, warts and all.
Sentence 2: The place where we went on holiday had some very run-down parts, but we liked it, warts and all.

Meaning 1: [something] past and forgotten.
Sentence 1: Please don’t worry about it any more. It’s all water under the bridge.
Sentence 2: I can’t change the past. It’s water under the bridge.

Meaning 1: to have more than one set of responsibilities
Meaning 2: to hold more than one office.
Sentence 1: The mayor is also the police chief. She wears more than one hat.
Sentence 2: I have too much to do to wear more than one hat.

Meaning 1: to stay too long (at an event to which one has been invited)
Sentence 1: Tom visited the Smiths so often that he wore out his welcome.
Sentence 2: At about midnight, I decided that I had worn out my welcome, so I went home.

Meaning 1: to weep a great many tears.
Sentence 1: The girls wept buckets at the sad film.
Sentence 2: Mary wept buckets when her dog died.

Meaning 1: to consider one’s own words carefully when speaking.
Sentence 1: I always weigh my words when I speak in public.
Sentence 2: John was weighing his words carefully because he didn’t want to be misunderstood.

Meaning 1: [for a worrying matter] to be constantly in a person’s thoughts
Meaning 2: [for something] to be bothering someone’s thinking.
Sentence 1: This problem has been weighing on my mind for many days now.
Sentence 2: I hate to have things weighing on my mind. I can’t sleep when I’m worried.

Meaning 1: having a great deal of knowledge about something.
Sentence 1: Jane’s husband is well up in computers.
Sentence 2: Joan’s well up in car maintenance. She took lessons at night-school.

Meaning 1: taking part in clever but sometimes dishonest or immoral business deals.
Sentence 1: John loves wheeling and deal- ing in the money markets.
Sentence 2: Jack’s got tired of all the wheeling and dealing of big business and retired to run a pub in the country.

Meaning 1: circumstances, often secret or personal, which all have an effect on each other and lead to a complicated, confusing situation.
Sentence 1: This is not a staightforward matter of choosing the best person for the job. There are wheels within wheels and one of the applicants is the boss’s son-in-law.
Sentence 2: I don’t know why Jane was accepted by the college and Mary wasn’t. There must have been wheels within wheels, because Mary has better qualifications.

Meaning 1: at exactly the right time.
Sentence 1: I’ll tell her the good news when the time is ripe.
Sentence 2: When the time is ripe, I’ll bring up the subject again.

Meaning 1: to expect or look for something with no hope of getting it.
Sentence 1: I’m afraid you’ll have to whistle for it if you want to borrow money. I don’t have any.
Sentence 2: Jane’s father told her to whistle for it when she asked him to buy her a car.

Meaning 1: something which is useless and which is either a nuisance or expensive to keep up. (From the gift of a white elephant by the Kings of Siam to courtiers who displeased them, knowing the cost of the upkeep would ruin them.)
Sentence 1: Bob’s father-in-law has given him an old Rolls-Royce, but it’s a real white elephant. He has no place to park it and can’t afford the petrol for it.
Sentence 2: Those antique vases Aunt Mary gave me are white elephants. They’re ugly and take ages to clean.

Meaning 1: the whole lot.
Sentence 1: They didn’t even sort through the books. They just threw out the whole shoot- ing match.
Sentence 2: All these tables are damaged. Take the whole bang shooting match away and replace them.

Meaning 1: to be successful
Meaning 2: to win a competition, argument, etc. (Originally meaning to win a battle.)
Sentence 1: Our team didn’t play well at first, but we won the day in the end.
Sentence 2: Hard work carried the day, and James passed his exams.

Meaning 1: to succeed.
Sentence 1: After many setbacks, we won through in the end.

Meaning 1: knowledgeable of how a situation should have been dealt with only after it has passed.
Sentence 1: I know now I should have agreed to help him, but that’s being wise after the event. At the time I thought he was just being lazy.
Sentence 2: Jack now realizes that he shouldn’t have married Mary when they had nothing in common, but he didn’t see it at the time. He’s now wise after the event.

Meaning 1: to express the hope that someone will enjoy having or doing something, usually while being glad that one does not have to have it or do it.
Sentence 1: I wish you joy of that old car. I had one just like it and spent a fortune on repairs for it.
Sentence 2: Mary wished us joy of going to Nepal on holiday. She preferred some- where more comfortable.

Idioms: with all one’s heart and soul
Meaning 1: very sincerely.
Sentence 1: Oh Bill, I love you with all my heart and soul, and I always will!
Sentence 2: She thanked us with all her heart and soul for the gift.

Meaning 1: [for something] to decline or fade away at an early stage of development. (Also used literally in reference to grapes or other fruit.)
Sentence 1: You have a great plan, Tom. Let’s keep it alive. Don’t let it wither on the vine.
Sentence 2: The whole project withered on the vine when the contract was cancelled.

Meaning 1: [saying something] repeatedly or continually.
Sentence 1: Bob was out in the garden raking leaves and cursing with every other breath.
Sentence 2: The child was so grateful that she was thanking me with every other breath.

Meaning 1: easily and excellently.
Sentence 1: John passed his geom- etry test with flying colours.
Sentence 2: Sally qualified for the race with flying colours.

Idioms: within an inch of doing something
Meaning 1: very close to doing something.
Sentence 1: I came within an inch of losing my job.
Sentence 2: Bob came within an inch of hitting Mike across the face.

Idioms: within an inch of one’s life
Meaning 1: very close to death.
Sentence 1: When Mary was seriously ill in the hospital, she came within an inch of her life.
Sentence 2: The thug beat up the old man to within an inch of his life.

Meaning 1: close enough to hear someone call out.
Sentence 1: When the boat came within hailing distance, I asked if I could borrow some petrol.
Sentence 2: We weren’t within hailing distance, so I couldn’t hear what you said to me.

Meaning 1: without showing surprise or emotion
Sentence 1: I knew I had insulted her, and she turned to me and asked me to leave without batting an eye.
Sentence 2: The child can tell lies without batting an eye.

Meaning 1: without purpose, order, or reason.
Sentence 1: The teacher said my report was disor- ganized. My paragraphs seemed to be without rhyme or reason.
Sentence 2: Everything you do seems to be without rhyme or reason.
Sentence 3: This pro- cedure seems to have no rhyme or reason.

Idioms: with the best will in the world
Meaning 1: however much one wishes to do something, or however hard one tries to do something.
Sentence 1: With the best will in the world, Jack won’t be able to help Mary get the job.
Sentence 2: With the best will in the world, they won’t finish the job in time.

Meaning 1: someone will regret something very much.
Sentence 1: Woe betide John if he’s late. Mary will be angry.
Sentence 2: Woe betide the students if they don’t work harder. They will be asked to leave college.

Meaning 1: to be inadequate, insubstantial, or ill-conceived.
Sentence 1: Sorry, your ideas won’t hold water. Nice try, though.
Sentence 2: The solicitor’s case wouldn’t hold water, so the defendant was released.

Idioms: work one’s fingers to the bone
Meaning 1: to work very hard.
Sentence 1: I worked my fingers to the bone so you children could have everything you needed. Now look at the way you treat me!
Sentence 2: I spent the day working my fin- gers to the bone, and now I want to relax.

Meaning 1: exhausted and thin, often from overwork.
Sentence 1: Working all day and looking after the children in the evening has left Pam worn to a shadow.
Sentence 2: Ruth’s worn to a shadow worrying about her son, who’s very ill.

Meaning 1: Unfortunately!
Sentence 1: I have an exam tomorrow, worse luck!
Sentence 2: We ran out of money on holiday, worse luck!

Meaning 1: to take someone by surprise, placing the person in a difficult situation.
Sentence 1: The chairman of the committee wrong- footed his opponents by calling a meeting when most of them were on holiday and had no time to prepare for it.
Sentence 2: The teacher wrongfooted the class by giving the test a day early.

Meaning 1: the time at which something is due to begin
Sentence 1: We’ll know whether the new computer system works effectively at zero hour, when we switch over to it.
Sentence 2: The runners are getting nervous as zero hour approaches. The starter’s gun will soon go off.

Meaning 1: to take advantage of a chance to do something
Sentence 1: Rohan did not know that why did he not jump at the opportunity.

Meaning 1: make use of a chance to do something.
Sentence 1: Rohan should have leapt at the opportunity.

Meaning 1: wrinkle one’s brow
Sentence 1: The woman knitted her brow and asked us what we wanted from her.

Meaning 1: let go off any excess energy or anger.
Sentence 1: Whenever John gets a little angry he blows of steam.

Meaning 1: lose the opportunity
Sentence 1: When I was younger, I wanted to become a doctor, but I let the chance slip by.

Meaning 1: to reveal a secret or a surprise by accident
